title: ~거든요 [geondeunyo] (You see; Explaining)
short_explanation: Used for explaining or giving background information to the listener.
long_explanation: '~거든요 [geondeunyo]' is a grammar point used in Korean language when the speaker wants to provide additional information or background to the listener, usually as an explanation or justification for a particular situation. It is used when the speaker believes the information might be new or surprising to the listener, or when the speaker wants to disclose personal feelings or thoughts. This expression is often used in casual conversation and is more commonly heard in spoken language than written.

examples.kr: 나 학교에 오래전에 다녔거든요, 그래서 현재 교육 시스템이 어떻게 바뀌었는지 잘 모르겠어요.
examples.romaji: Na hakgyoe oraejeone daningeondeunyo, geuraeseo hyeonjae gyoyuk siseutemi eotteoke bakkwinji jal moreugesseoyo.
examples.en: You see, I attended school a long time ago, so I don't really know how the current educational system has changed.

examples.kr: 제가 지각한 것은 버스가 늦었거든요, 그래서 시간을 맞추지 못했어요.
examples.romaji: Jega jigaghan geoseun beoseuga neujeotgeondeunyo, geuraeseo siganeul matchuji motaesseoyo.
examples.en: The reason I was late is because the bus was delayed, so I couldn't make it on time.

examples.kr: 저는 커피를 마시지 않아요. 커피에 카페인이 많이 들어있거든요, 그래서 잠을 못 잡니다.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun keopireul masiji anhayo. Keopie kapeini mani deureoitgeondeunyo, geuraeseo jameul mot japnida.
examples.en: I don't drink coffee. You see, coffee contains a lot of caffeine, so it keeps me from sleeping.

examples.kr: 하루종일 집에 있어서 지루해요. 날씨가 너무나도 춥거든요, 그래서 밖에 나갈 수 없어요.
examples.romaji: Harujongil jibe isseoseo jiruhaeyo. Nalssiga neomunado chupgeondeunyo, geuraeseo bagge nagal su eopseoyo.
examples.en: I'm bored being in the house all day. You see, the weather is so cold, so I can't go outside.

title: ~게 되다 [ge dweda] (End up doing)
short_explanation: Used to express an action that ends up happening due to certain circumstances or changes.
long_explanation: '~게 되다 [ge dweda]' is a common Korean grammar structure that is used to express an occurrence of an action that was not planned or intended originally, but ended up happening due to certain circumstances or changes. It is often used in contexts where a circumstance, decision, or action leads to an outcome or state. The resulting state or action is usually unexpected, unintended, or unplanned.
formation: Verb in the falling tone + 게 + 되다

examples.kr: 저는 공부를 집중하다가 잠이 들게 되었어요, 참 기분이 이상해요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun gongbu-reul jipjunghada-ga jami deul-ge doeeosseoyo, cham gibuni isanghaeyo.
examples.en: I ended up falling asleep while studying, it feels weird.

examples.kr: 처음에는 일주일동안 한국어를 배우려고 했는데, 나중에는 한 달 동안 배우게 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Cheoeumen-eun ilju-il dongan hangugeoleul baeuryeogo haessneunde, najungeneun han dal dongan baeuge doeeosseoyo.
examples.en: At first, I was going to learn Korean for a week, but in the end, I ended up learning it for a month.

examples.kr: 우리는 원래 여름에 결혼하려고 했지만, 겨울에 결혼하게 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Urineun weonlae yeoleume gyeolhonharyeogo haetjiman, gyeoul-e gyeolhonhage doeeosseoyo.
examples.en: We originally planned to get married in the summer, but we ended up getting married in the winter.

examples.kr: 처음에는 회사에서 너무 많이 일하게 되었어요 그래서 가족을 자주 볼 수가 없었어요.
examples.romaji: Cheoeumeneun hoisaeseo neomu man-i ilhage doeeosseoyo geulaeseo gajog-eul jaju bol suga eobseosseoyo.
examples.en: At first, I ended up working too much at the company, so I couldn't see my family often.

title: ~게 하다 [ge hada] (Make/let someone do)
short_explanation: Used to express feeling that someone caused or made another to do something.
long_explanation: '~게 하다' is a sentence ending used in Korean to indicate that someone made, let, caused, or allowed someone else to do something. It expresses the feeling that the action in the sentence was not done independently, but was influenced or prompted by someone else. This structure can be used to convey a variety of feelings, such as compulsion, obligation, permission, or influence.

examples.kr: 세탁기 가격이 너무 비싸서, 가게 주인이 저에게 할인을 해 주어서 사게 해주었어요.
examples.romaji: Setakgi gakyeogi neomu bissaseo, gage juin-i jeoege halin-eul hae jueoseo sage haejueoss-eoyo.
examples.en: The washing machine was so expensive that the store owner gave me a discount and let me buy it.

examples.kr: 그녀는 저를 기쁘게 하여 행복하게 활동하게 했습니다.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun jeoreul gippeuge hayeo haengbokajeogeuro hwaldonghage haessseubnida.
examples.en: She made me happy and let me act happily.

examples.kr: 어머니는 저에게 영어를 배울 수 있도록 도서관에 데려가게 해주었습니다.
examples.romaji: Eomeonineun jeo-ege yeong-eoleul baeul su issdolog doseogwan-e telyeogage haejueossseubnida.
examples.en: My mother made me study English by taking me to the library.

examples.kr: 우리 팀원들은 저를 승진하게 하는데 도움을 주었습니다.
examples.romaji: Uri tim-wondeul-eun jeoleul seungjinhage hanundedo-eumi suicideu-eossseubnida.
examples.en: Our team members helped me to get promoted.

title: ~게 해서는 안 되다 [ge haeseoneun an dweda] (Shouldn't make/let someone do)
short_explanation: Used to convey the meaning 'shouldn't make someone do' or 'shouldn't let someone do' something.
long_explanation: '~게 해서는 안 되다 [ge haeseoneun an dweda]' is a Korean grammar point used to express the message that one 'shouldn't make someone do' or 'shouldn't let someone do' a certain action. It is typically used to express an opinion, objective advice or it can also be used to convey criticism of neglect or carelessness. Most often, this grammar point is used in contexts involving someone's treatment of others.

examples.kr: 자기 시험에만 집중하게 해서는 안 되어요, 다른 사람들의 공부에도 신경을 써야 해요.
examples.romaji: Jagi siheomeman jipjunghage haeseoneun an dwoeyo, dareun saramdeul-ui gongbu-edo singyeong-eul sswayahaeyo.
examples.en: You shouldn't only make them focus on their own tests, they should also care about others' study.

examples.kr: 진행하게 해서는 안 됩니다, 계획을 먼저 확인해야 합니다.
examples.romaji: Jinhaenghage haeseoneun an doemnida, gyehoeg-eul meonjeo hwaginhaeya hamnida.
examples.en: You shouldn't let it proceed, checking the plan should come first.

examples.kr: 어린이들을 TV 시청만 하게 해서는 안 됩니다, 독서 등 다른 활동도 있어야 합니다.
examples.romaji: Eolinideuleul TV sichongman hage haeseoneun an doemnida, dokseo deung dareun hwaldongdo isseoya hamnida.
examples.en: You shouldn't just let children watch TV, they should also have other activities like reading.

examples.kr: 고객을 기다리게 해서는 안 됩니다, 서비스가 빨라야 합니다.
examples.romaji: Gogaegeul gidarige haeseoneun an doemnida, seobiseuga pparayahamnida.
examples.en: You shouldn't make customers wait, the service should be fast.

title: 겠다 [getda] (will, guess, hope, wish)
short_explanation: '겠다 [getda]' is a verb ending that is used to express future '(will)', conjecture or inference '(guess)', or strong wish or hope '(hope, wish)'.
long_explanation: '겠다 [getda]' is a versatile verb ending in Korean that can express multiple meanings depending on the context. When it represents the future tense, it can often translate as 'will'. However, when it is used to infer or conjecture based on an observation, it can be translated as 'guess' or 'must be'. Lastly, it can also be used to express a strong desire or wish, somewhat equivalent to 'hope' or 'wish' in English.

examples.kr: 오늘 밤에 비가 오겠다, 왜냐하면 지금 구름이 크고 어두워 보이기 때문이에요.
examples.romaji: Oneul bame biga ogetda, waenya hamin jigeum gureumi keugo eoduwo boigi ttaemunieyo.
examples.en: It will probably rain tonight because the clouds currently look large and dark.

examples.kr: 그 분이 저한테 화를 내시겠어요. 왜냐하면 저는 그분의 지시에 따르지 않았기 때문입니다.
examples.romaji: Geu buni jeohante hwale naesigetseoyo. Waenya hamin, jeoneun geubunui jisie ttareuji anhatgi ddaemunibnida.
examples.en: That person will probably be angry with me because I did not follow their instructions.

examples.kr: 이 책을 다 읽으면 한국어를 더 잘 알게 될 겠어요, 많은 새로운 단어들과 문법들이 이 책에 나와 있어요.
examples.romaji: I chaageul da ilgeumyeon hangugeoleul deo jal alge doel getseoyo, manheun saeloun dan eodeulgwa munbeopdeuli i chaege nawa isseoyo.
examples.en: I guess I will know Korean better once I finish reading this book, as it contains many new words and grammars.

examples.kr: 다음 주가 오면 나는 새로운 스포츠 클럽에 가입하겠어요, 새로운 활동을 시작하고 싶어서요.
examples.romaji: Daum juga omyeon naneun saeloun seupocheu keullobeu e gaibhagetseoyo, saeloun hwaldongeul sijakhago sipeoseoyo.
examples.en: I hope to join a new sports club when next week comes, as I want to start a new activity.

title: ~고 말다 [go malda] (Ended up doing)
short_explanation: Used to express an unexpected or undesirable result; 'ended up doing'.
long_explanation: '~고 말다 [go malda]' is a grammar format used in Korean to emphasize an end result or outcome, often unexpected or unfortunate, resulting from certain actions or situations. Translated to English, it would be equivalent to 'ended up...' or 'in the end...'. The subject of the sentence is usually the person who experiences or causes the unexpected or undesirable outcome.

examples.kr: 오랜 시간을 기다렸는데 나는 결국 혼자 먹고 말았어요, 친구들이 오지 않았어요.
examples.romaji: Oraen siganeul gidaryeossneunde naneun gyeolguk honja meokgo marasseoyo, chingudeuli oji anhasseoyo.
examples.en: I waited for a long time but ended up eating alone since my friends didn't come.

examples.kr: 제가 어제 너무 늦게 잠들어서 결국 지각하고 말았어요.
examples.romaji: Jega eoje neomu neutge jamdeureoseo gyeolguk jigakago marasseoyo.
examples.en: I fell asleep too late yesterday and ended up being late.

examples.kr: 그는 공부를 계속 미루고 미루다가 결국 시험에서 떨어지고 말았어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun gongbureul gyesok mirugo mirudaga gyeolguk siheomeseo tteoreojigo marasseoyo.
examples.en: He kept putting off studying and in the end, he ended up failing the test.

examples.kr: 나는 달리기를 계속 했지만 결국 첫 번째 자리을 얻지 못하고 말았어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun dalligireul gyesok haetjiman gyeolguk cheot beonjjae jari-eul eodji mothago marasseoyo.
examples.en: I kept running but in the end, I ended up not getting the first place.

title: ~고 보니 [go boni] (After doing, I noticed)
short_explanation: This grammar form expresses the idea of 'after going through this, I realize/notice'.
long_explanation: The grammar form '~고 보니 [go boni]' is used to mention an unexpected realization which occurs after the completion of an action. It provides the speaker with a way to express a discovery or realization made after experiencing or performing something. This structure is often used when the speaker gains a new perspective or understanding about something.

examples.kr: 그림을 다 그리고 보니 그게 진짜 재미있었어요.
examples.romaji: Geurimeul da geurigo boni geuge jinjja jaemiisseosseoyo.
examples.en: After I finished drawing the picture, I realized it was really fun.

examples.kr: 고향에 돌아가고 보니 세월의 흔적을 많이 느꼈어요.
examples.romaji: Gohyange doragago boni seweolui heunjeogeul manhi neukkyeosseoyo.
examples.en: After I went back to my hometown, I noticed a lot of traces of time.

examples.kr: 친구와 이별한 다음에는 그의 중요성을 알게 되었습니다.
examples.romaji: Chinguwa ibyeolhan daeumeun geui jungyoseongeul alge doeeossseubnida.
examples.en: After parting with my friend, I realized his importance.

examples.kr: 책을 다 읽고 보니 많은 것을 배울 수 있었어요.
examples.romaji: Chaegueul da ilggo boni maneun geoseul baeul su isseosseoyo.
examples.en: After I finished reading the book, I realized I could learn a lot from it.

title: ~고 싶다 [go sipda] (Want to)
short_explanation: Used to express desire or want to do something.
long_explanation: '~고 싶다 [go sipda]' is a verb ending used in Korean to express a desire or a wish to do something. It is akin to saying 'I want to ---' in English. It is commonly used to express personal wishes or desires and can be used with both action verbs and stative verbs. When you use this structure, you are talking about something you want to do, but are not necessarily going to do.

examples.kr: 저는 한국어를 배우고 싶어요, 그래서 매일 공부하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun hangugeoreul baeugo sip-eoyo, geuraeseo maeil gongbu-hago iss-eoyo.
examples.en: I want to learn Korean, so I study every day.

examples.kr: 친구가 내일 영화를 보고 싶다고 말했어요, 그래서 영화 표를 사려고 합니다.
examples.romaji: Chingu-ga naeil yeonghwa-reul bogo sipdago malhaess-eoyo, geuraeseo yeonghwa pyo-reul saryeo-go habnida.
examples.en: My friend said she wants to see a movie tomorrow, so I am going to buy movie tickets.

examples.kr: 오늘 밤 집에 가고 싶지 않아서 친구 집에서 묵을 거예요.
examples.romaji: Oneul bam jib-e gago sipji anh-aseo chingu jib-eseo mugeul geoyeyo.
examples.en: I don't want to go home tonight, so I'm going to stay at my friend's house.

examples.kr: 요리를 배우고 싶어서 요리 학교에 가고 싶었어요.
examples.romaji: Yori-reul baeugo sip-eoseo yori hakgyo-e gago sip-yeoss-eoyo.
examples.en: I wanted to learn cooking so I wanted to go to a cooking school.

title: ~고 있다 [go itda] (In the process of doing)
short_explanation: Used to express an action that is currently ongoing or a state that continues.
long_explanation: '~고 있다 [go itda]' is a grammar pattern used in Korean to express that an action is currently in progress or a state continues. This form corresponds to the English present progressive tense such as 'is doing', 'are doing', etc. However, it can also indicate a state that continues, not just actions. So it can be used to describe a person's physical characteristics or emotions that continue over time.

examples.kr: 그녀는 햇빛 아래에서 책을 읽고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun haetbit araeseo chaeg-eul ilg-go iss-eoyo.
examples.en: She is reading a book under the sunlight.

examples.kr: 꽃들이 바람에 흔들리고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Kkotdeuli baram-e heundeul-ri-go iss-eoyo.
examples.en: The flowers are swaying in the wind.

examples.kr: 일년 내내 그는 스트레스를 받고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Illyeon naenae geuneun seuteureseureul bad-go iss-eoyo.
examples.en: He has been under stress for a whole year.

examples.kr: 우리 아버지는 여전히 유럽을 여행하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Uri abeoji-neun yeojeonhi yureob-eul yeohaengha-go iss-eoyo.
examples.en: My father is still traveling around Europe.

title: ~고자 하다 [goja hada] (In order to)
short_explanation: Used to express the purpose or intention of an action; 'in order to', 'for the purpose of'.
long_explanation: '~고자 하다 [goja hada]' is a verb ending that is used in the Korean language to indicate the aim or the purpose for carrying out a certain action or behavior. It conveys a sense of planning or intending, similar to 'in order to' or 'for the purpose of' in English. It is used to show an intentional goal or target and is often found in formal and written contexts.

examples.kr: 저는 한국어 능력을 향상시키고자 하다 매일 한국 드라마를 보고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun hangug-eo neunglyeog-eul hyangsangsi kigoja hada maeil han-gug deu la ma-reul bogo iss-eoyo.
examples.en: In order to improve my Korean skills, I watch Korean dramas every day.

examples.kr: 당신의 건강을 챙기고자 하다 매일 아침 일찍 일어나서 운동을 해야 해요.
examples.romaji: Dangsin-ui geongang-eul chaenggi gojahada maeil achim iljjik ileonaseo undong-eul haeya haeyo.
examples.en: In order to take care of your health, you should get up early every morning and exercise.

examples.kr: 기업의 환경 보호를 이행하고자 하다 그들은 제품의 친환경 포장을 도입했어요.
examples.romaji: Gieob-ui hwangyeong boho-reul ihaeng gojahada geudeul-eun jepum-ui chin hwangyeong pojang-eul do-ibhaess-eoyo.
examples.en: In order to fulfill the company's environmental protection, they introduced eco-friendly packaging for their products.

examples.kr: 그녀는 진정한 행복을 찾고자 하다 먼 나라로 여행을 갔어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeo-neun jinjeonghan haengbok-eul chatgoja hada meon nala-lo yeohaeng-eul gass-eoyo.
examples.en: In order to find true happiness, she traveled to a far-off country.

title: ~곤 하다 [gon hada] (Often do)
short_explanation: Used to express the repetition or frequency of an action or state.
long_explanation: '~곤 하다 [gon hada]' is a grammar pattern used in Korean to express a habit or a repetitive action. It denotes actions that are done often or recurring states. It is generally attached to the end of action verbs and suggests a certain frequency or habitual pattern in the past which continues to the present time.

examples.kr: 나는 마음이 힘들 때 종종 책을 읽곤 해요, 그래서 그리운 마음을 달래곤 해요.
examples.romaji: Naneun maeumi himdeul ttae jongjong chaeg-eul ilggon haeyo, geuraeseo geuliun maeumeul dallagon haeyo.
examples.en: I often read books when I feel down, so I often soothe my longing heart.

examples.kr: 아침에 일어나면 항상 창문을 열곤 하다, 신선한 공기를 맞이하곤 해요.
examples.romaji: Achime ileonamyeon hangsang changmuneul yeolgon hada, sinseonhan gong-gileul majihagon haeyo.
examples.en: I often open the window when I wake up in the morning, to greet the fresh air.

examples.kr: 그녀는 새로운 레시피를 발견하면 그것을 시도곤 하다, 그래서 새로운 요리를 항상 만들곤 해요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun saeroun resipireul balgyeonhamyeon geugeoseul sidogon hada, geuraeseo saeroun yorireul hangsang mandeulgon haeyo.
examples.en: Whenever she discovers a new recipe, she often tries it out, so she often cooks new dishes.

examples.kr: 저는 운동 후에 항상 스트레칭을 하곤 해서 근육이 뻣뻣해지는 것을 방지곤 해요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun undong hue hangsang seuteureching-eul hagon haeseo geun-yug-i ppeotppeothaejineun geos-eul bangjigon haeyo.
examples.en: After exercising, I often do stretching to prevent my muscles from getting stiff.

title: ~기도 하다 [gido hada] (Sometimes do)
short_explanation: This grammatical expression is used when expressing occasional or sometimes actions.
long_explanation: '~기도 하다 [gido hada]' is a Korean grammar point used to indicate an action that one sometimes, occasionally does. This is a casual expression and usually implies that the action isn't a common occurrence. It is often used when mentioning two mutually exclusive actions that a person occasionally does. It is therefore often paired with '도' in the same sentence to emphasis diversity in actions.

examples.kr: 저는 보통 축구를 보지만, 때때로 야구를 보기도 해요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun botong chuggureul bojiman, ttaettaero yagureul bogido haeyo.
examples.en: I usually watch football, but sometimes I also watch baseball.

examples.kr: 그녀는 요리를 잘하지만, 그럼에도 불구하고 배울 것이 많이 남아서 요리수업에 가기도 해요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun yorireul jalhajiman, geureumedo bulguhago baewul geosi mani namaseo yorisueobe gagi do haeyo.
examples.en: Even though she cooks well, there's still a lot for her to learn so she sometimes goes to cooking class.

examples.kr: 우리는 주로 산을 등반하는데, 가끔 강가에서 피크닉을 즐기기도 해요.
examples.romaji: Urineun juro saneul deungbanhaneunde, gakkeum ganggaeseo pikeunigeul jeulgigido haeyo.
examples.en: We usually climb mountains, but occasionally we enjoy picnics by the river.

examples.kr: 제가 보통 이른 아침에 일어나지만, 때로는 늦잠을 자기도 해요.
examples.romaji: Jega botong ireun achime ileonajiman, ttaeroneun neutjameul jagido haeyo.
examples.en: I usually wake up early in the morning, but sometimes I sleep in.

title: ~기로 [giro] (Decided to)
short_explanation: Used to indicate a decision or agreement to do something.
long_explanation: The '~기로 [giro]' ending is used in Korean to express a decision or an agreement that has been made to do something. It particularly refers to a resolution, decision or promise that has been established in advance. This pattern often used to talk about personal decisions, promises between individuals, public announcements or plans.

examples.kr: 그녀는 다음 주에 시험을 보기로 결정했어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun daeum jue siheomeul bogiro gyeoljeonghaess-eoyo.
examples.en: She decided to take the test next week.

examples.kr: 나는 내일 친구들과 영화를 보기로 약속했어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun naeil chingudeulgwa yeonghwareul bogiro yaksokhaess-eoyo.
examples.en: I promised to watch a movie with my friends tomorrow.

examples.kr: 우리 부모님은 내년에 새 집으로 이사하기로 결정했어요.
examples.romaji: Uri bumonim-eun naenyeon-e sae jib-euro isagiro gyeoljeonghaess-eoyo.
examples.en: Our parents have decided to move to a new house next year.

examples.kr: 우리는 다음 회의에서 이 문제를 논의하기로 했어요.
examples.romaji: Ulineun da-eum hoeui-eseo i munjeleul non-uihagiro haess-eoyo.
examples.en: We decided to discuss this issue at the next meeting.

title: ~기로 되다 [giro dweda] (It's decided to)
short_explanation: This is used to express 'it's decided to' or 'it's arranged to'.
long_explanation: '~기로 되다 [giro dweda]' structure is used when you want to express that something is decided or arranged. The main verb is changed into the verb nominalization form by attaching '~기' to the verb stem, and it is followed by the verb '되다'.

examples.kr: 회사에서 월요일에 회의하기로 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Hoesaeseo woryoil-e hoesuihagi-ro doeeoss-eoyo.
examples.en: It has been arranged to have a meeting at the company on Monday.

examples.kr: 우리는 내일 오후 3시에 만나기로 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Ulineun naeil ohu 3si-e mannagi-ro doeeoss-eoyo.
examples.en: We've decided to meet at 3 pm tomorrow.

examples.kr: 그녀와의 결혼은 내년에 하기로 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeowaui gyeolhoneun naenyeon-e hagi-ro doeeoss-eoyo.
examples.en: It's been decided that we will get married next year.

examples.kr: 다음 주에 친구들과 여행 가기로 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Da-eum ju-e chingu-deulgwa yeohaeng gagi-ro doeeoss-eoyo.
examples.en: It's been decided that we will go on a trip with friends next week.

title: ~기로 하다 [giro hada] (Decide to)
short_explanation: This phrase is used to express 'decide to' or 'agree to' something. It indicates the action that the speaker has decided to carry out or is promising to perform in the future.
long_explanation: The phrase '~기로 하다' is used when the speaker wants to communicate that they have made a decision about something, and express the intention to stick to this decision in the future. This is often used in conversations to share decisions or plans. It is also used to describe promises or agreements between people. The decision or promise is usually one with some level of importance or seriousness.
formation: Verb in infinitive form + 기로 하다

examples.kr: 우리는 다음 주에 여행 가기로 했어요, 날씨가 좋으면 바다로 갈까해요.
examples.romaji: Urineun daeum jue yeohaeng gagi giro haesseoyo, nalssiga joh-eumyeon badalo galkka haeyo.
examples.en: We decided to go on a trip next week, if the weather is good, we might go to the beach.

examples.kr: 나는 내일 헬스장에 가기로 했어요. 운동을 시작해서 건강해지기로 했어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun naeil helseujange gagi giro haesseoyo. Undong-eul sijak-haeseo geonganghaejigi giro haesseoyo.
examples.en: I decided to go to the gym tomorrow. I decided to start exercising and become healthier.

examples.kr: 서윤은 미래에 자기 스스로의 직장을 가질 기로 했습니다.
examples.romaji: Seo Yun-eun milae-e jagi seuseuro-ui jigjang-eul gajil giro haessseubnida.
examples.en: Seo Yoon decided to have her own job in the future.

examples.kr: 우리 그룹은 사업 확장을 위해 더 많은 직원을 고용하기로 결정했습니다.
examples.romaji: Uri geurup-eun saeob hwagjang-eul wihae deo manh-eun jig-won-eul goyonghagi giro gyeoljeonghaessseubnida.
examples.en: Our group has decided to hire more employees for business expansion.

title: ~기 시작하다 [gi sijakhada] (Begin to)
short_explanation: Used to express the beginning of an action.
long_explanation: '~기 시작하다 [gi sijakhada]' is a grammar pattern used in Korean to indicate the start of an action. It is often translated into English as 'begin to'. When a verb stem is followed by ~기 시작하다, it allows the speaker to describe an event or action that has just started or will begin in the near future.

examples.kr: 그녀는 5살 때 피아노를 치기 시작했어요. 그래서 지금은 피아노를 정말 잘 칩니다.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun 5 sal ttae pianoreul chigi sijakhayeo. geuraeseo jigeumeun pianoreul jeongmal jal chapnida.
examples.en: She began to play the piano at the age of 5. So now, she plays the piano really well.

examples.kr: 나는 아침에 일어나자마자 커피를 마시기 시작했어요. 커피 없이는 하루를 시작할 수 없습니다.
examples.romaji: Naneun achime ireonajamaja keopireul masigi sijakhayeo. Keopi eobsineun harureul sijakhal su eobsseubnida.
examples.en: I begin to drink coffee as soon as I wake up in the morning. I can't start the day without coffee.

examples.kr: 우리는 처음 회의를 시작할 때부터 심각한 문제에 대해 이야기하기 시작했어요.
examples.romaji: Urineun cheoeum hoeuireul sijakhal ttaebuteo simgakhan munje-e daehae iyagigi sijakhayeo.
examples.en: We began to talk about serious issues right from the beginning of the meeting.

examples.kr: 저는 한국어를 배우기 시작한지 1년이 지났고, 아직도 많이 배워야 합니다.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun hangugeoreul baeugi sijakhanji 1 nyeoni jinatgo, ajikdo mani baeowoya habnida.
examples.en: It's been one year since I started to learn Korean, and I still have a lot to learn.

title: ~기 위해서 [gi wihaeseo] (In order to)
short_explanation: This grammar point is used to express the purpose or reason for doing something, translated as 'in order to' or 'for the purpose of'.
long_explanation: ~기 위해서 [gi wihaeseo] is a Korean grammar point that denotes the purpose or reason behind a certain action. It is equivalent to 'in order to' or 'for the purpose of' in English. This structure is used when you want to explain the reason for doing something, specifically about a future action. It combines a verb in the ~기 form followed by 위해서, creating a clause that explains the purpose of an action.

examples.kr: 영어를 잘하게 되기 위해서 매일 아침에 영어 듣기 연습을 하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Yeongeoreul jalhage doegi wihaeseo maeil achime yeongeo deudgi yeonseubeul hago isseoyo.
examples.en: In order to become good at English, I'm practicing listening to English every morning.

examples.kr: 운동선수가 되기 위해서 학교 후에 항상 훈련에 참여해요.
examples.romaji: Undongseonsuga doegi wihaeseo hakgyo hue hangsang hunryeone chamyeohaeyo.
examples.en: In order to become a sports player, I always participate in training after school.

examples.kr: 시험에 합격하기 위해서 많은 시간을 공부하는데 투자했어요.
examples.romaji: Siheome hapgyeokhagi wihaeseo manheun siganeul gongbuhaneunde tujahayeo.
examples.en: I invested a lot of time studying in order to pass the exam.

examples.kr: 행복한 삶을 살기 위해서 자기 자신을 사랑하는 것이 중요해요.
examples.romaji: Haengbokhan salmeul salgi wihaeseo jagi jasineul saranghaneun geosi jungyohaeyo.
examples.en: In order to live a happy life, it's important to love oneself.

title: ~기는 [gineun] (But)
short_explanation: Used to indicate a contrast or exception; typically similar to 'but' in English.
long_explanation: The grammar point '~기는 [gineun]' is used to express contrast or exception in Korean. It is attached to the stem of a verb and implies that there is some contrasting or different element follows in the sentence. The nuance is similar to 'but' or 'although' in English. It is often used when agreeing with part of a statement, while pointing out some contrasting or different element.

examples.kr: 저는 여행하기는 좋아하는데, 비행기를 타는 것이 아직도 두렵습니다.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun yeohaenghagineun joahaneunde, bihaenggireul taneun geosi ajikdo duryeopseubnida.
examples.en: I like traveling, but I’m still scared of flying.

examples.kr: 그 건물은 크기는 큰데, 상태가 너무 안 좋아서 리모델링이 필요해 보여요.
examples.romaji: Geu geonmureun keugineun keunde, sangtaega neomu an joahaseo rimodellingi piryohae boyeoyo.
examples.en: That building is large, but it seems like it needs renovations because it’s in bad condition.

examples.kr: 그 친구는 친절기는 한데, 솔직히 말해서 너무 많이 물어봐서 조금 짜증나요.
examples.romaji: Geu chinguneun chinjeolhagineun hande, soljikhage malhaseyo neomu mani muleobwaseo jogeum jjajeungnayo.
examples.en: That friend is kind, but, to be honest, I’m a bit frustrated because he asks too many questions.

examples.kr: 이번 계절은 봄이기는 한데, 날씨가 아직도 춥고,  따뜻해지기를 기다리고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Ibeon gyejeoreun bomingineun hande, nalssiga ajikdo chupgo, ttatteuthaejigireul gidarigo isseoyo.
examples.en: This season is spring, but the weather is still cold, so I'm waiting for it to warm up.

title: ~기에는 [gieneun] (For doing)
short_explanation: Used to express the idea of 'for doing something' or 'in order to'.
long_explanation: '~기에는 [gieneun]' is a grammatical construction that is used to show the purpose or reason behind something, similar to the English phrase 'for doing something' or 'in order to'. This structure is usually used to explain why a subject is particularly suitable or unsuitable for a certain action. It often follows a verb stem and is then followed by a verb, noun, or adjective.

examples.kr: 이번 시험을 준비하기에는 시간이 충분하지 않다고 생각합니다.
examples.romaji: Ibeon siheomeul junbigieneun sigani chungbunhaji anhdago saengkaghamnida.
examples.en: I think that there is not enough time to prepare for this exam.

examples.kr: 운동하기에는 밖이 너무 추워요, 그래서 집에서 운동하려고 합니다.
examples.romaji: Undonghagieneun baggi neomu chuwoyo, geuraeseo jibeseo undongharyeogo hamnida.
examples.en: It is too cold outside to exercise, so I plan to work out at home.

examples.kr: 좋은 성적을 받기에는 진심으로 노력해야 합니다.
examples.romaji: Joheun seongjeogeul badgieneun jinsimeuro noryeokhaeya hamnida.
examples.en: You have to make a sincere effort to get a good grade.

examples.kr: 축구를 배우기에는 나이가 너무 많다고 생각하는 경우도 있어요.
examples.romaji: Chukgureul baeugieneun naiga neomu manhdago saengkakhaneun gyongudo isseoyo.
examples.en: There are times when you may think that you are too old to learn soccer.

title: ~기 전에 [gi jeone] (Before doing)
short_explanation: Used to express the action that happens before another action.
long_explanation: '~기 전에 [gi jeone]' is a Korean grammar structure used to refer to an action that is to take place before another action. In English, it is similar to the usage of 'before'. It is used to highlight a series of activities that occur in a specified order. It is usually used in sentences expressing the order of actions in time.

examples.kr: 운동을 하기 전에 충분히 스트레칭을 해야 해요, 그렇지 않으면 부상을 당할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Undongeul hagi jeone chungbunhi seuteurechingeul haeya haeyo, geureohji anheumyeon busangeul danghal su isseoyo.
examples.en: You have to stretch enough before exercising, otherwise, you might get injured.

examples.kr: 집을 나가기 전에 전기를 꺼야 해요, 그렇지 않으면 화재가 발생할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Jibeul nagagi jeone jeon-gireul kkeoya haeyo, geureohji anheumyeon hwajae-ga balsaenghal su isseoyo.
examples.en: You have to turn off the electricity before leaving home, otherwise, there might be a fire.

examples.kr: 수업이 시작하기 전에 숙제를 제출해야 해요, 그렇지 않으면 학점이 깎일 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Sueobi sijakagi jeone sukje-reul jechulhaeya haeyo, geureohji anheumyeon hakjeomi kkakkil su isseoyo.
examples.en: You need to submit your homework before the class starts, otherwise, your grades might be cut.

examples.kr: 먹기 전에 손을 꼭 씻어야 해요, 그렇지 않으면 병균에 감염될 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Meokgi jeone soneul kkok ssiseoya haeyo, geureohji anheumyeon byeonggyune gamyeondoel su isseoyo.
examples.en: You must wash your hands before eating, otherwise, you can be infected with germs.

title: ~나 보다 [na boda] (Seems like, guess)
short_explanation: Used to express an assumption or supposition in the form of 'seems like' or 'guess'.
long_explanation: The expression '~나 보다' is used in Korean when the speaker makes a guess or inference about a situation based on observations or information. It can be translated as 'seems like', 'looks like', 'I guess', 'It appears that'. It can be attached to both verbs and adjectives. Remember that your guess or supposition may not always be true when you use this expression.

examples.kr: 피곤한가 봐요, 학교에 와서 계속 잤어요.
examples.romaji: Pigonhanga boyo, hakgyoe wasseo gyesok jasseoyo.
examples.en: I guess he is tired, he kept sleeping after he came to school.

examples.kr: 이 풍경을 보면 행복하게 느껴지나 봐요, 그림을 그리며 눈물을 흘렸어요.
examples.romaji: I punggyeongeul bomyeon haengbokhage neukkyeojina boyo, geurimeul geurimyeo nunmureul heulleosseoyo.
examples.en: I guess I feel happy when I see this scenery, I cried while painting.

examples.kr: 비가 오나 봐요, 밖에 사람들이 우산을 들고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Biga ona boyo, bakke saramdeuri usaneul deulgo isseoyo.
examples.en: I guess it's raining, people outside are holding umbrellas.

examples.kr: 그녀가 감기에 걸린 것 같아요, 계속 헛기침을 하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoga gamgie geollin geo gatayo, gyesok heotgicheomeul hago isseoyo.
examples.en: I guess she caught a cold, she keeps coughing.

title: ~나다 [nada] (End up doing, come to do)
short_explanation: Expresses that an action happened unexpectedly or wasn’t originally intended.
long_explanation: '~나다 [nada]' is a verb ending used in the Korean language to express that something happened unintentionally or unexpectedly, despite the initial intentions of the subject. It gives a sense of surprise or disbelief and is often used when the subject didn't plan for the action to occur or when the outcome of the action wasn't originally expected. Typically, this structure is translated into English as 'end up doing something' or 'come to do something'

examples.kr: 그녀는 고민을 하다가 결국 친구의 조언을 따르는 것으로 결정나다.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun gomineul hadaga gyeolguk chinguui joseoneul ttaruneun geoseuro gyeoljeongnada.
examples.en: After much consideration, she ended up deciding to follow her friend’s advice.

examples.kr: 저는 간단히 쇼핑하러 갔다가 많은 돈을 쓰는 것으로 끝나다.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun gandanhi syopinghareo gatdaga manheun doneul sseuneun geoseuro ggeutnada.
examples.en: I went for a simple shopping but ended up spending a lot of money.

examples.kr: 어제 집에 일찍 돌아가려 했지만, 늦게까지 일하다가 돌아가는 것이 되다.
examples.romaji: Eoje jibe iljjik doragaryeo haetjiman, neutgekkaji ilhadaga doraganeun geosi doeda.
examples.en: I intended to go home early yesterday, but ended up working late.

examples.kr: 학교에 가려고 했는데, 결국 비가 너무 많이 내려서 집에 있게 되다.
examples.romaji: Hakgyoereul garyeogo haetneunde, gyeolguk biga neomu manhi naeryeoseo jibe isseuge doeda.
examples.en: I intended to go to school, but ended up staying at home because it rained too much.

title: ~나요? [nayo?] (Isn't it?)
short_explanation: Used to form tag questions or to express doubt; 'isn't it?', 'aren't you?' etc.
long_explanation: '~나요? [nayo?]' is a question ending in Korean, used often to form tag questions or to express doubt or uncertainty. It works similarly to 'right?', 'isn't it?', 'don't you?' etc. in English. It expresses a request for confirmation or agreement about the statement made before the '~나요' from the listener. The sentence final ending can be used in both formal and informal situations.

examples.kr: 오늘 날씨가 정말 좋지 않나요? 계속 비가 오고 있어서.
examples.romaji: Oneul nalssiga jeongmal johji annayo? Gyesok biga ogo isseoseo.
examples.en: The weather isn't really good today, isn't it? It's been raining continuously.

examples.kr: 당신은 저와 같이 저녁 식사를 할거야, 그렇지 않나요?
examples.romaji: Dangsineun jeowa gachi jeonyeok sikshareul halgeoya, geureochi annayo?
examples.en: You are going to have dinner with me, aren't you?

examples.kr: 저는 상당히 바빠 이 주말에는 휴식이 필요하지 않나요?
examples.romaji: Jeoneun sangdanghi bappa i jumaleneun hyusigi pilyohaji annayo?
examples.en: I'm quite busy, I need some rest this weekend, don't I?

examples.kr: 우리 모두 코로나 백신을 맞춰야 합니다, 그렇지 않나요?
examples.romaji: Uri modu korona baegsineul majchwoya hamnida, geureochi annayo?
examples.en: We all should get the Corona vaccine, shouldn't we?

title: ~는 대로 [neun daero] (As it is)
short_explanation: Used to express 'as is', 'as exactly as' or 'according to how'.
long_explanation: '~는 대로 [neun daero]' is a grammar point used in Korean to mean 'just as' or 'exactly as'. It implies that an action should be done in the same way as something else or exactly as it is said or instructed. It can also be used to describe something happening just as predicted or seen. This grammar point emphasizes on the accuracy and the unchanged state or process of something.
formation: Verb-stem + 는 대로 / Noun + 은/는 대로

examples.kr: 그림은 그림을 그리는 대로, 노래는 노래를 부르는 대로 학습해야 해요.
examples.romaji: Geurimeun geurimeul geurineun daero, noraeneun noraereul bureuneun daero haksseubhaeya haeyo.
examples.en: You should learn how to draw by drawing, and learn how to sing by singing.

examples.kr: 그녀의 예측대로, 비가 진짜 많이 왔어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoui yechaengdaero, biga jinjja manhi wasseoyo.
examples.en: Just as she predicted, it really rained a lot.

examples.kr: 요리는 레시피대로, 선생님의 지시대로 따라하세요.
examples.romaji: Yorineun reshipidaero, seonsaengnimui jisidaero ttarahaseyo.
examples.en: Follow the recipe for cooking, according to the teacher's instructions.

examples.kr: 우리는 지도대로 오늘 계획된 대로 여행해요.
examples.romaji: Urineun jidodaero oneul gyeplan doen daero yeohaenghaeyo.
examples.en: We travel as planned today, according to the map.

title: ~는 도중에 [neun dojunge] (While doing)
short_explanation: This grammar point is used to express the meaning of 'while doing something', 'in the midst of', or 'during'.
long_explanation: The '~는 도중에 [neun dojunge]' is used in Korean grammar to indicate an action or state that is ongoing or happening at the time of speaking. It signifies the middle of an action or a process, giving the idea of 'during' or 'while doing something' in English. It can be used with both action and descriptive verbs to convey the meaning of something happening during or in the midst of an action.

examples.kr: 나는 책을 읽는 도중에 잠이 들었어요, 그래서 책의 내용을 다 기억하지 못하겠어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun chaekeul ikneun dojunge jami deureosseoyo, geuraeseo chaekui naeyongeul da gieokhaji motagesseoyo.
examples.en: I fell asleep while reading the book, so I don't think I'll remember all the content of the book.

examples.kr: 그녀는 음악을 듣는 도중에 갑자기 춤을 추기 시작했어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun eumageul deuneun dojunge gabjagi chumeul chugi sijakhaesseoyo.
examples.en: She started dancing suddenly while listening to music.

examples.kr: 타이핑을 하는 도중에 컴퓨터가 갑자기 꺼져서 작업한 내용을 다시 시작해야 했어요.
examples.romaji: Taiping-eul haneun dojunge kompyuteoga gabjagi kkeojyeoseo jag-eophan naeyong-eul dasi sijaghayeo.
examples.en: The computer suddenly turned off while I was typing, so I had to start the work again.

examples.kr: 친구들과 캠핑을 하는 도중에 갑자기 비가 내려서 우리는 텐트 안으로 들어가야 했어요.
examples.romaji: Chingudeulgwa kaemping-eul haneun dojunge gabjagi biga naeryeoseo urineun tenteu an-euro deuleogaya haesseoyo.
examples.en: It suddenly began to rain while we were camping with friends, so we had to go inside the tent.

title: ~는 방향으로 [neun banghyangeuro] (Toward)
short_explanation: Used to indicate the direction something is heading or moving towards.
long_explanation: '~는 방향으로 [neun banghyangeuro]' is a Korean grammar point used to denote direction or orientation. It can be translated into English as 'towards' or 'in the direction of'. This grammar structure is often used with action verbs that imply movement, or with descriptive verbs that imply position or direction.

examples.kr: 나는 학교 있는 방향으로 가고 있어요, 그래야만 빠르게 도착할 수 있을 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Naneun hakgyo itneun banghyangeuro gago isseoyo, geuraeyaman ppareuge dochakhal su isseul geot gatayo.
examples.en: I am heading towards the direction of the school, I think this is the only way to arrive quickly.

examples.kr: 그는 집 있는 방향으로 달려갔어요, 그가 엄청 빨리 돌아가려고 했어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun jip itneun banghyangeuro dallyeogasseoyo, geuga eomcheong ppalli doragaryeogo haesseoyo.
examples.en: He ran toward the direction of the house, he seemed to be in a hurry to get back.

examples.kr: 그 여자는 나에게로 오는 방향으로 자리를 옮겼어요, 그래서 나는 기뻤어요.
examples.romaji: Geu yeojaneun naegero oneun banghyangeuro jarireul olmgyeosseoyo, geuraeseo naneun gippeosseoyo.
examples.en: The woman moved her seat towards the direction that I am, that made me happy.

examples.kr: 우리는 비가 오는 방향으로 계속 걸어가고 있어요, 그래서 우리는 모두 젖었어요.
examples.romaji: Urineun biga oneun banghyangeuro gyesok georeogago isseoyo, geuraeseo urineun modu jeojeosseoyo.
examples.en: We kept walking towards the direction it was raining, that's why we all got wet.

title: ~는 법이다 [neun beopida] (Usually, always)
short_explanation: This expression is used to describe a general rule or habit that always tends to happen.
long_explanation: The phrase '~는 법이다' [neun beopida] is a Korean grammar structure used to express that something usually or always happens in a certain way as if it is a rule or law. This pattern is commonly used to state general truths or habitual actions that are almost always the case. This phrase indicates a strong tendency or pattern of occurrence and is used to describe rules, habits, or principles that are relatively unchanging.

examples.kr: 우리 가족은 매일 밤 같이 저녁을 먹는 법이다.
examples.romaji: Uri gajogeun maeil bam gachi jeonyeogeul meogneun beopida.
examples.en: It's our family's rule to eat dinner together every night.

examples.kr: 그는 항상 일찍 일어나서 책을 읽는 법이다.
examples.romaji: Geuneun hangsang iljjik ileonaseo chaegeul ilgneun beopida.
examples.en: He always gets up early to read books.

examples.kr: 커피를 마신 후에는 항상 입을 헹구는 법이다.
examples.romaji: Keopireul masin hue-neun hangsang ibeul heungguneun beopida.
examples.en: It's always the case that I rinse my mouth after drinking coffee.

examples.kr: 나는 항상 집에서 공부하면서 음악을 듣는 법이다.
examples.romaji: Naneun hangsang jibeseo gongbuhwamyeonseo eumageul deudneun beopida.
examples.en: It is always my habit to listen to music while studying at home.

title: ~는데다 [neundedda] (Furthermore, and)
short_explanation: Used to add an additional information or emphasize the situation; 'furthermore', 'and'.
long_explanation: '~는데다 [neundedda]' is used to add more information to the previous statement or to emphasize a situation. This grammar point is used when you want to add more reasons, circumstances, or conditions that might strengthen your point. In English, it would resemble 'furthermore', 'and', or 'in addition to'.

examples.kr: 그 카페는 커피가 맛있는데다 분위기도 참 좋아요.
examples.romaji: Geu kapeuneun keopiga masitneundedda bunwigido cham joahyo.
examples.en: The café serves delicious coffee, and in addition, the atmosphere is also really great.

examples.kr: 이 호텔은 위치도 좋은데다 직원들의 서비스도 훌륭해요.
examples.romaji: I hoteleun wichido joheunneundedda jigweondeurui seobiseudo hullyunghaeyo.
examples.en: This hotel has a great location, and furthermore, the service of the staff is excellent.

examples.kr: 책을 읽는 것은 지식을 쌓는데다 스트레스 해소에도 도움이 돼요.
examples.romaji: Chaegeul ilgneun geoseun jisigeul ssahneundedda seuteureseu haesoeedo doumi dwaeyo.
examples.en: Reading books not only accumulates knowledge, but it also helps to relieve stress.

examples.kr: 그는 학점이 높은데다 학교 활동에도 적극적으로 참가하니 대학생활이 바쁠 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun hakjeomi nopneundedda hakgyo hwaldongeedo jeokgeukjeogeuro chamgahani daehaksaenghwali bakkul geot gatayo.
examples.en: He has high grades, and furthermore, he actively participates in school activities, so it seems his university life would be busy.

title: ~는데도 [neundedo] (Even though, but still)
short_explanation: Used to express contrasting or contradicting situations; 'even though', 'but still'.
long_explanation: ~는데도 [neundedo]' is a conjunctive particle that is used to describe a contradictory, contrasting events or conditions. It adds the sense of 'even though' or 'but still' in English, expressing the idea that despite a certain situation or fact, a certain outcome remains unaltered or an established assumption is defied. It often implies an element of surprise or emphasis.

examples.kr: 아기인데도 많이 잠을 자지 않아요. 하루 종일 놀기만 해요.
examples.romaji: Agineundedo mani jameul jaji anhayo. Haru jongil nolgiman haeyo.
examples.en: Even though he is a baby, he does not sleep much. He just plays all day long.

examples.kr: 많이 공부해서 시험을 잘 볼 거라 생각했는데도 시험점수가 낮게 나왔어요.
examples.romaji: Mani gongbuhayeo siheomeul jal bol geora saenggakhaetneundedo siheomjeomsuga najege nawatseoyo.
examples.en: Even though I studied a lot and thought I would do well on the test, my test score came out low.

examples.kr: 많이 먹는데도 그녀는 언제나 가벼워 보였어요.
examples.romaji: Mani meokneundedo geunyeoneun eonjena gabyeoweo boyeosseoyo.
examples.en: Even though she eats a lot, she always seemed lightweight.

examples.kr: 이런 일을 여러 번 경험했는데도 나는 계속 같은 실수를 반복하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Ireon ireul yeoreo beon gyeongheomhaetneundedo naneun gyesok gateun silsureul banbokhago isseoyo.
examples.en: Even though I have experienced such things several times, I keep repeating the same mistakes.

title: ~는지 [neunji] (Whether or not)
short_explanation: Used to express doubt or inquire about a certain fact; 'whether or not'.
long_explanation: '~는지 [neunji]' is a particle used in Korean to express doubt, inquire about a certain fact, or to indicate the speaker's lack of certainty about the veracity of the information. This particle is often used in indirect questions, or when the speaker is wondering about something. It can be translated as 'whether or not' in English.

examples.kr: 그는 내가 사랑하는지 알고 있을까요?
examples.romaji: Geuneun naega saranghaneunji algo isseulkka yo?
examples.en: I wonder if he knows that I love him?

examples.kr: 우리는 내일 회사에 갈 수 있는지 모르겠어요.
examples.romaji: Urineun naeil hoesae gal su issneunji moreugesseoyo.
examples.en: We don't know if we can go to the office tomorrow.

examples.kr: 그녀가 어디에 있는지 알아낼 수 있을까요?
examples.romaji: Geunyeoga eodie issneunji alanal su isseulkka yo?
examples.en: Can we find out where she is?

examples.kr: 그 영화가 재미있는지 아닌지 알아보기 위해 평가를 읽어보세요.
examples.romaji: Geu yeonghwaga jaemiissneunji aninji arabogi wihae pyeonggareul ilgeoboseyo.
examples.en: Read the reviews to find out whether or not that movie is interesting.

title: ~는지 모르겠다 [neunji moreugessda] (I'm not sure if)
short_explanation: Used to express uncertainty; 'I'm not sure if', 'I don't know whether'.
long_explanation: '~는지 모르겠다 [neunji moreugessda]' is a commonly used grammatical form that expresses uncertainty or the speaker's lack of knowledge on a certain topic. In English, it roughly translates to 'I'm not sure if' or 'I don't know whether'. This grammatical form is used when the speaker wants to convey a sense of doubt about the situation or someone's feelings or intentions.

examples.kr: 그가 어떻게 반응할지 모르겠어요, 그래서 불안하네요.
examples.romaji: Geuga eotteohge baneung halji moreugesseoyo, geureoseo buranhaeneyo.
examples.en: I'm not sure how he will react, so I'm nervous.

examples.kr: 비가 오는지 안 오는지 모르겠어요, 지금 날씨가 너무 흐려서요.
examples.romaji: Biga oneunji an oneunji moreugesseoyo, jigeum nalssiga neomu heuryeoseoyo.
examples.en: I'm not sure if it's raining or not because the weather is so cloudy.

examples.kr: 내일 시험을 잘 볼 수 있는지 모르겠어요, 여전히 많은 공부가 남았거든요.
examples.romaji: Naeil siheomeul jal bol su issneunji moreugesseoyo, yeojeonhi maneun gongbuga namatgeodeunyo.
examples.en: I'm not sure if I can do well in tomorrow's test, there is still a lot to study.

examples.kr: 회사에서 프로모션을 받을 수 있는지 모르겠어요, 경쟁이 무척激해서요.
examples.romaji: Hoesaeseo peulomosyeoneul badeul su issneunji moreugesseoyo, gyeongjaengi muceog gyeokhaeseoyo.
examples.en: I'm not sure if I can get a promotion at work, the competition is very fierce.

title: ~는지라 [neunjira] (Because, since)
short_explanation: Used to provide a reason or cause for something; 'because', 'since'.
long_explanation: '~는지라 [neunjira]' is a connective ending in Korean that provides a reason or justification for something in the main clause of the sentence. It's similar to 'because' or 'since' in English and is frequently used in formal and written Korean. It often implies that the provided reason is the sole and definite cause for the situation or action described in the main clause.

examples.kr: 그가 매우 똑똑한데다가 성실한지라, 누구든지 그를 존경해야 합니다.
examples.romaji: Geuga maeu tteoktteokhandaedaga seongsilhanjira, nugudeunji geureul jongyeonghaeya habnida.
examples.en: Because he is very smart and diligent, everyone should respect him.

examples.kr: 이 일이 너무 절실한지라, 내가 최선을 다해 해결해야 했습니다.
examples.romaji: I iri neomu jeolsilhanjira, naega choeseoneul dahae haegyeolhaeya haetseubnida.
examples.en: Because this matter was so urgent, I had to do my best to solve it.

examples.kr: 그녀가 너무 예쁜지라, 사람들이 자주 그녀를 보고 웃습니다.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoga neomu yeppeun jira, saramdeuli jaju geunyeoreul bogo utseubnida.
examples.en: Because she is so pretty, people often look at her and smile.

examples.kr: 라면이 너무 매운지라, 제가 물을 여러 잔 마셔야 했습니다.
examples.romaji: Rameni neomu maeun jira, jega mureul yeoreo jan masyeoya haetsseubnida.
examples.en: Because the ramen was so spicy, I had to drink several glasses of water.

title: ~다가 [daga] (While, and then)
short_explanation: Used to express 'in the middle of', 'when suddenly' or 'and then'.
long_explanation: '~다가 [daga]' is a grammar point in Korean that denotes the idea of being in the middle of an action when another action occurs or interrupts the initial action. It's equivalent to saying 'while' or 'when suddenly' in English. This can also be used to show two actions or states happening one after the other, which can be interpreted as 'and then' in English.

examples.kr: 제가 소풍 가는 길에 빨간 신호등을 기다리다가 휴대전화가 울렸어요.
examples.romaji: Jega sopung ganeun gire ppalgan sinhodeungeul gidaridaga hyudaejeonhwaga ulryeosseoyo.
examples.en: While I was waiting for the red traffic light on my way to the picnic, my cell phone rang.

examples.kr: 장미가 음악을 듣다가 잠이 들어버렸어요.
examples.romaji: Jangmi-ga eumageul deuddaga jami deureobeoryeosseoyo.
examples.en: Jangmi was listening to music and then she fell asleep.

examples.kr: 나는 저녁을 먹다가 갑자기 배가 아팠어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun jeonyeogeul meokdaga gapjagi baega apasseoyo.
examples.en: I was eating dinner when suddenly my stomach hurt.

examples.kr: 그는 책을 읽다가 피곤해서 잠들었습니다.
examples.romaji: Geuneun chaekeul ilgdaga pigonhaeseo jamdeul-issseubnida.
examples.en: He was reading a book and then fell asleep because he was tired.

title: ~다가는 [daganeun] (If keep doing)
short_explanation: This construction is used to express a negative potential outcome if the current situation or action continues.
long_explanation: '~다가는 [daganeun]' is a grammatical construction in Korean that communicates the negative results or consequences that may happen if a specific action or state continues as it is. It is often translated as 'if keep doing' or 'if continue doing' in English. The point of this structure is to express concern or warn about the possible negative outcome.

examples.kr: 숙제를 계속 미루다가는 결국 시험을 실패할 거예요.
examples.romaji: Sukjereul gyesog mirudaeganeun gyeolguk siheomeul silpaehal geoyeyo.
examples.en: If you keep putting off your homework, you'll end up failing the exam in the end.

examples.kr: 항상 늦게 자다가는 건강에 문제가 생길 거예요.
examples.romaji: Hangsang neutge jadaganeun geongange munjega saenggil geoyeyo.
examples.en: If you always go to bed late, you'll have health problems.

examples.kr: 언제나 그렇게 게임만 하다가는 눈이 나빠질 거예요.
examples.romaji: Eonjena geureohge geimman hadaganeun nuni nappajil geoyeyo.
examples.en: If you always play games like that, your eyes will get bad.

examples.kr: 너무 고민만 하다가는 결정의 시간이 없어질 거예요.
examples.romaji: Neomu gominman hadaganeun gyeoljeongui sigani eopseojil geoyeyo.
examples.en: If you keep worrying too much, you'll run out of time to decide.

title: ~다가도 [dagado] (Even though was doing)
short_explanation: Used to express an unexpected event or action that occurs while another action is taking place.
long_explanation: The grammar point '~다가도 [dagado]' is used to describe an unexpected occurrence that happens whilst another action is in progress or has been in progress. It can be translated as 'even though was doing...'. This formation correlates to the interruption or unexpected result of the original action. It is formulating a contrast between two situations where the first part anticipates a different outcome than what is revealed in the second part.

examples.kr: 저는 열심히 공부하다가도 시험에 떨어졌어요, 분명 다음 번에는 합격하겠어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun yeolsimhi gongbuhadagado siheome tteoreojyeosseo, bunmyeong daeum beoneun hapgyeokhagesseoyo.
examples.en: Even though I studied hard, I failed the exam, but I'm sure I'll pass next time.

examples.kr: 카페에서 커피를 마시다가도 비가 갑자기 내리기 시작했어요, 우산을 가지고 있었지만 여전히 축축해졌어요.
examples.romaji: Kaepheeseo keopireul masihadagado biga gapjagi naerigi sijakhaesseoyo, usaneul gajigo isseossjiman yeojeonhi chukchukhaejuosseo.
examples.en: Even though I was drinking coffee in the cafe, it suddenly started to rain; I had an umbrella, but I still got a bit wet.

examples.kr: 요리를 만드는 동안 주의를 기울였다가도 그릇을 끓는 수에 넣어버렸어요, 고마워 덕분에 손을 잘랐어요.
examples.romaji: Yorireul mandeuneun dongan juuieul giulyeotdagado geureuteul kkeulhneun sue neohyeobeoryeosseo, gomaeo deokbunae soneul jjarasseoyo.
examples.en: Even though I was careful while cooking, I dropped the bowl into boiling water; thanks to that, I cut my hand.

examples.kr: 강의를 듣다가도 중요한 부분을 놓쳤어요, 저는 그 부분을 다시 보려고 노력했지만 찾을 수 없었어요.
examples.romaji: Gangireul deudnagado jungyohan bubuneul nohchyeosseo, jeoneun geu bubuneul dasi boryeogo noryeokhaetjiman chajul su eopseosseo.
examples.en: Even though I was listening to the lecture, I missed an important part; I tried to look at that part again, but I couldn't find it.

title: ~다는 것 [daneun geot] (The fact that)
short_explanation: Used to express 'the fact that' or 'the idea that' when referring to some specific information
long_explanation: '~다는 것 [daneun geot]' is a grammar construct used in Korean language to express the idea or the concept of something, or to highlight and clarify some information in a conversation. In English, it's equivalent to 'the fact that', 'the idea that' or 'it is said that'. It's typically used in situations where the speaker wants to convey his/her understanding or acknowledge someone else's understanding of a particular fact or piece of information.

examples.kr: 저는 그녀가 한국에서 온 다는 것을 전혀 몰랐어요, 그래서 그녀의 한국어 실력에 놀랐어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun geunyeoga hanguke sa on daneun geoseul jeonhyeo mollasseoyo, geuraeseo geunyeoui hangugeo sillyeoge nollasseoyo.
examples.en: I didn't know the fact that she came from Korea, so I was surprised at her Korean skills.

examples.kr: 나는 내가 이길 것이라는 것을 확실히 믿고 있어요, 그래서 모든 준비를 철저히 해서 오늘 경기를 치를 것입니다.
examples.romaji: Naneun naega igil georaneun geot-eul hwagsinhage midgo isseoyo, geuraeseo modeun junbi-reul cheoljeohi hae-seo oneul gyeonggi-reul chireul geos-ibnida.
examples.en: I believe firmly in the fact that I will win, so I am thoroughly preparing for today's game.

examples.kr: 당신이 그만두었다는 것을 들었을 때, 나는 정말로 허탈하게 느꼈습니다, 왜냐하면 당신이 이 프로젝트에 중요한 부분이었기 때문입니다.
examples.romaji: Dangsin-i geuman duryeossda'neun geol-eul deul-eoss-eul ttae, na-neun jeongmallo heotalhage neukkyeoss-seubnida, waenyahamyeon dangsin-i i peulojegteu-e jungyohan bu bun-ieoss-gi ttaemun-ibnida.
examples.en: When I heard the fact that you quit, I felt truly devastated because you were a crucial part of this project.

examples.kr: 나는 그녀가 나를 좋아한다는 것을 알게 되었을 때, 정말로 행복했습니다, 왜냐하면 나도 그녀를 좋아했기 때문입니다.
examples.romaji: Na-neun geunyoga nal-eul joh-ahanda'neun geot-eul alge dwe-eoss-eul ttae, jeongmallo haengbokhaess-seubnida, waenyahamyeon na-do geunyeo-reul joh-ahaess-gi ttaemun-ibnida.
examples.en: When I found out the fact that she likes me, I was really happy because I also liked her.

title: ~다며 [damyeo] (Saying that)
short_explanation: This grammar point is used to express an action or state that the speaker says, thinks or feels.
long_explanation: "~다며 [damyeo]" is used in Korean when the speaker is explaining something they have said, thought, or felt. It is often used to report direct speech or thoughts, and describes a subjective view or personal interpretation. '~다며' often accompanies verbs of thinking, feeling, or saying, and does not have any tense itself. Tense is expressed through the sentence it is used in.

examples.kr: 모두가 하늘이 정말로 파랗다며 말했을 때, 저는 그냥 당연하다고 생각했어요.
examples.romaji: Moduga haneuli jeongmallo parahdamyeo malhaesseul ttae, jeoneun geunyang dangyeonhadago saenggakhaesseoyo.
examples.en: When everyone was saying that the sky was really blue, I just thought it was obvious.

examples.kr: 그녀는 자신이 더 이상 참을 수 없다며 그만두기로 결정했어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun jasini deo isang chameul su eopsdamyeo geumandugiro gyeoljeonghaesseoyo.
examples.en: She decided to quit saying that she could not stand it anymore.

examples.kr: 제 친구는 밤을 새워 공부한다며 이야기 했지만, 나는 그것이 거짓말이라고 생각했어요.
examples.romaji: Je chinguneun bameul saewo gongbuhandamyeo iyagi haetjiman, naneun geugeosi geojitmarirago saenggakhaesseoyo.
examples.en: My friend said that he studies all night, but I thought it was a lie.

examples.kr: 엄마는 올해는 반드시 다이어트를 해야 한다며 스스로에게 약속했어요.
examples.romaji: Eommaneun olhaeneun bandeusi daieoteureul haeya handamyeo seuseuroege yaksokhaesseoyo.
examples.en: My mother promised herself that she must diet this year saying that.

title: ~대로 [daero] (According to, as)
short_explanation: Used to indicate actions performed according to a certain method or manner.
long_explanation: '~대로 [daero]' is a grammar point used in Korean to express that something is done according to a specific method, order, or manner. It can also mean 'as it is'. This pattern shows that an action is guided by a previously mentioned condition or direction. It is commonly used to demonstrate following instructions or a predetermined path.

examples.kr: 선생님이 가르쳐 준 대로 문제를 풀어 보았지만, 아직도 이해가 안 돼요.
examples.romaji: Seonsaengnimi gareuchyeo jun daero munjeleul pureo boassjiman, ajikdo ihaega an dwaeyo.
examples.en: I tried to solve the problem according to the way the teacher taught me, but I still don't understand.

examples.kr: 언니가 추천해준 대로 책을 읽어봤습니다, 깊은 뜻을 품고 있는 재밌는 책이었습니다.
examples.romaji: Eonniga chucheonhaejun daero chaegireul ilgeobwassseubnida, gipeun ddeumeul pumgo issneun jaemissneun chaegieossseubnida.
examples.en: I tried reading the book as my older sister recommended, it was a fun book with a deep meaning.

examples.kr: 우리가 계획한 대로 여행을 계속 하면서 여러 랜드마크를 봤어요.
examples.romaji: Uriga gyehoekhan daero yeohaengeul gyesok hamyeonseo yeoreo raendeumakeureul bwasseoyo.
examples.en: We continued our journey as planned and saw various landmarks.

examples.kr: 사진 속에 보이는 경치대로 현실에서 보니까 너무 아름답고 기분이 좋아졌어요.
examples.romaji: Sajin sogye boineun gyeongchidaero hyeonsireso bonikkaneomu areumdapgo gibuni johajyeosseoyo.
examples.en: Seeing the scenery just as it appears in the photograph in reality was very beautiful and made me feel good.

title: ~대로 하다 [daero hada] (Do as instructed/said)
short_explanation: Used to express the meaning of 'according to' or 'as said/done'.
long_explanation: '~대로 하다 [daero hada]' is a Korean grammar point used to indicate that a certain action is performed as instructed, as said or as it was previously done. It consists of the noun or verb preceding the '~대로' to specify the action or the state that is being followed. It is often used in sentences to express compliance with a given rule, instruction, or to describe following a specific pattern.

examples.kr: 엄마는 아침에 일어나서 학교 가기 전에 꼭 아침 식사를 하라고 했어요, 그래서 저는 엄마가 말씀하신대로 하고 학교에 갑니다.
examples.romaji: Eommaneun achime ileonaseo hakgyo gagi jeone ggog achim siksa leul halago haesseoyo, geulaeseo jeoneun eomma-ga malssuemhasindaelo hago hakgyo-e gabnida.
examples.en: My mom told me to make sure to have breakfast before going to school in the morning, so I do as my mom said and go to school.

examples.kr: 요리책의 레시피대로 음식을 만들면 항상 맛있게 만들 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Yolichaeg-ui lesipidaelo eumsig-eul mandeulmyeon hangsang mas-issge mandeul su iss-eoyo.
examples.en: If you make food according to the recipe in the cookbook, you can always make it delicious.

examples.kr: 선생님이 강조하신대로 공부하면 시험에서 좋은 점수를 받을 수 있을 거예요.
examples.romaji: Seonsaengnim-i gangjohasindaelo gongbuhmyeon siheom-eseo joheun jeom-su leul bad-eul su iss-eul geo-eyo.
examples.en: If you study as advised by the teacher, you will be able to get good scores in the exams.

examples.kr: 부모님이 말씀하신대로 매일 운동하고, 영양가 있는 음식을 먹으니까, 건강이 좋아졌어요.
examples.romaji: Bumonim-i malssuemhasindaelo maeil undonghago, yeongyang-ga issneun eumsig-eul meog-nikka, geongang-i joh-ajyeoss-eoyo.
examples.en: Following my parents' advice, I exercise every day and eat nutritious food, which has improved my health.

title: ~대로이면 [daeroimyeon] (If it's as ... said)
short_explanation: Used to imply condition; 'If it's as ... said'.
long_explanation: '~대로이면 [daeroimyeon]' is a conditional phrase in Korean. It is used to imply that if conditions were as originally stated or as anticipated, a specific course of events or action might occur. The expressed condition is usually based on hearsay or an assumption made by the speaker, not on the speaker's direct observation or knowledge.

examples.kr: 치킨집 사장님이 말한대로이면, 여기서 가장 인기 있는 메뉴는 양념 치킨이에요.
examples.romaji: Chikinjip sajangnimi malhandaeroimyeon, yeogiseo gajang ingi issneun menyuneun yangnyeom chikinieyo.
examples.en: If we're to believe what the chicken shop owner said, their most popular menu item is the sweet chili chicken.

examples.kr: 너의 계획대로이면, 오늘 밤에 영화를 볼 수 있을거야.
examples.romaji: Neoui gyehoekdaeroimyeon, oneul bame yeonghwareul bol su isseulgeoya.
examples.en: If it's according to your plan, we'll be able to go see a movie tonight.

examples.kr: 민수가 말한대로이면, 이 시험은 아주 어렵다고 해요.
examples.romaji: Minsuga malhandaeroimyeon, i siheomeun aju eoryeopdago haeyo.
examples.en: If it's as Minsu said, this test is supposed to be very hard.

examples.kr: 흥민이 모든 것을 솔직하게 말한대로이면, 그는 그런 실수를 다시는 하지 않을 것입니다.
examples.romaji: Heungmini modeun geoseul soljikhage malhandaeroimyeon, geuneun geureon silsureul dasineun haji anheul geosibnida.
examples.en: If everything is as Heungmin honestly said, he will never make such a mistake again.

title: ~도록 [dorok] (So that)
short_explanation: Used to express 'so that' or 'in order to'.
long_explanation: '~도록 [dorok]' is a grammatical form that is commonly used in Korean to express an intended purpose or a result, similarly to 'so that' or 'in order to' in English. Additionally, it can be used to indicate cause and effect or to give instructions. So, it's often seen in sentences that are designed to tell someone to do something in order to achieve a certain result.
formation: [Verb stem + 도록] or [Noun + 이/가 + Adjective/Adjective verb + 도록]

examples.kr: 밤을 생활하는 동물들이 보이도록 야간 사파리에 가기로 했어요.
examples.romaji: Bameul saenghwaldohaneun dongmuldeuri boidorok yagan saparie gagi-ro haesseoyo.
examples.en: We decided to go to a nighttime safari so that we could see nocturnal animals.

examples.kr: 우리 모두가 이해할 수 있도록 강의를 천천히 해주세요.
examples.romaji: Uri moduga ihaehal su itdorok gang-ui-reul cheoncheonhi haejuseyo.
examples.en: Please lecture slowly so that all of us can understand.

examples.kr: 낙엽이 빠르게 정리되도록 주기적으로 땅을 쓸어 주었어요.
examples.romaji: Nagyeobi ppaleuge jeonglidoedorok jugijeogeuro ttangeul sseureo jueosseoyo.
examples.en: I swept the ground periodically so that the fallen leaves would be cleaned up quickly.

examples.kr: 비바람이 불어오지 않도록 창문을 꽉 닫아두었어요.
examples.romaji: Bibarami bure-oji antorok changmuneul kkwak dat-adueoisseoyo.
examples.en: I shut the windows tightly so that the rainstorm wouldn't blow in.

title: ~도록 하다 [dorok hada] (Make/ensure that)
short_explanation: Used to express 'making someone do something' or 'ensuring that something happens'.
long_explanation: The phrase '~도록 하다 [dorok hada]' is frequently used in the Korean language to imply that someone is commanded or requested to do something or an attempt to make a certain situation occur. This pattern can be translated to 'make someone do something' or 'ensure that something happens' in English. It is very adaptable and can be used with action verbs, descriptive verbs, and nouns.

examples.kr: 저는 언제나 학생들이 성실하게 수업을 듣도록 해요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun eonjena haksaengdeuli seongsilhage sueobeul deutdorok haeyo.
examples.en: I always make sure that the students listen to the class sincerely.

examples.kr: 회사에서는 직원들이 일찍 퇴근하도록 하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Hoesaeseoneun jigweondeuli iljjik toegeunhadorok hago isseoyo.
examples.en: The company is ensuring that employees leave work early.

examples.kr: 그녀는 아이들이 안전하게 집에 도착하도록 했어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun aideuli anjeonhage jibe dochakhadorok haesseoyo.
examples.en: She made sure that the children arrived home safely.

examples.kr: 엄마는 우리가 매일 채소를 먹도록 했어요.
examples.romaji: Eommaneun uriga maeil chaesoreul meokdorok haesseoyo.
examples.en: Mum made us eat vegetables every day.

title: ~도록이면 [dorogimyeon] (If possible)
short_explanation: Used to express a wish or desire for a certain condition or situation to be met if possible.
long_explanation: '~도록이면 [dorogimyeon]' is a grammar pattern used in Korean to express the speaker's preference or hope for a certain situation to occur, if possible. It's similar to the English phrase 'if possible'. It denotes a wish or desire that is conditional or dependent on certain circumstances and is generally used in statements expressing preferences, hopes, or desires.

examples.kr: 도록이면 건강한 음식을 먹으려고 노력하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Dorogimyeon geonganghan eumsigeul meogeuryeogo noryeokhago isseoyo.
examples.en: I'm trying to eat healthy food as much as possible.

examples.kr: 도록이면 빨리 답장을 부탁드려요.
examples.romaji: Dorogimyeon ppalliy dapjangeul butakdeuryeoyo.
examples.en: Please reply back as soon as possible.

examples.kr: 도록이면 매일 운동을 해야 건강을 유지할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Dorogimyeon maeil undongeul haeya geongangeul yujihal su isseoyo.
examples.en: You need to exercise daily if possible to maintain your health.

examples.kr: 도록이면 숙제를 미루지 않고 바로 해야 해요.
examples.romaji: Dorogimyeon sukjeeul miruji anhgo baro haeya haeyo.
examples.en: You should do homework immediately if possible.

title: ~든지 [deunji] (Whether ... or)
short_explanation: Used to express 'Whether ... or', presenting two or more possibilities to choose from.
long_explanation: '~든지 [deunji]' is a grammar point in Korean that is used when you want to present two or more possibilities or choices. It is akin to 'Whether... or' in English. The choices can be in the form of nouns, verbs or even phrases, so this grammar point is quite flexible. Note that the feeling conveyed is that any of the choices mentioned is okay or acceptable.
formation: Noun/Noun Phrase + 이든지/든지 or Verb + 던지/든지

examples.kr: 단체여행이든지 개인여행이든지, 어떤 형태의 여행도 좋아합니다.
examples.romaji: Danche-yeohaeng-ideunji gaein-yeohaeng-ideunji, eotteon hyeongtaeui yeohaeng-do joahamnida.
examples.en: Whether it's group travel or individual travel, I like any type of trip.

examples.kr: 이 문제를 해결하기 위해 우리는 많은 시간을 들였든지, 많은 돈을 썼든지, 그 모든 피로가 값어치가 있어요.
examples.romaji: I munjeleul haegyeolhagi wihae urineun manheun siganeul deulyeossgdeunji, manheun doneul sseossdeunji, geu modeun piroga gapseuchi iss-eoyo.
examples.en: Whether we spent a lot of time or a lot of money to solve this problem, all that fatigue is worthwhile.

examples.kr: 그가 만약 서울에 산다든지 부산에 산다든지, 그는 어디서든지 행복할 것입니다.
examples.romaji: Geuga manyak Seoul-e sandeunji Busan-e sandeunji, geuneun eodieseodeunji haengbokal geos-ibnida.
examples.en: Whether he lives in Seoul or Busan, he will be happy anywhere.

examples.kr: 이 회사에서 근무한다든지 다른 회사에서 근무한다든지, 어디서든지 나는 최선을 다하겠습니다.
examples.romaji: I hoisaeseo geunmuhanda-deunji dareun hoisaeseo geunmuhanda-deunji, eodieseodeunji naneun choeseoneul dahagess-seubnida.
examples.en: Whether I work at this company or another company, I will do my best anywhere.

title: ~든지 ~든지 [deunji deunji] (Either ... or)
short_explanation: Used to enumerate alternatives or choices; 'either ... or'.
long_explanation: '~든지 ~든지 [deunji deunji]' is a conjunctive expression used in Korean to convey choices or alternatives. It is similar to 'either ... or' in English. This grammar point is used when the speaker wishes to express that regardless of the options given, they don't mind about the result. It gives a sense of freedom of choice between multiple possibilities.

examples.kr: 이번 주말에는 영화를 보러 가든지, 아니면 집에서 쉬든지 할 계획이에요.
examples.romaji: Ibeon jumalen yeonghwa reul boreo gadeonji, animyeon jibeseo swideonji hal gyehoeg ieyo.
examples.en: This weekend, I plan to either go see a movie or rest at home.

examples.kr: 저녁 메뉴로 피자를 먹을 든지, 아니면 치킨을 먹을 든지 아직 결정하지 못했어요.
examples.romaji: Jeonyeok menuro pijareul meogeul deunji, animyeon chikineul meogeul deunji ajik gyeoljeonghaji mothaesseoyo.
examples.en: I haven't decided whether to eat pizza or chicken for dinner yet.

examples.kr: 지금 집에 가든지, 아니면 조금 더 머무를든지 마음대로 해도 괜찮아요.
examples.romaji: Jigeum jibe gadeonji, animyeon jogeum deo meomuldeonji maeumdaero haedo gwaenchanhayo.
examples.en: You can either go home now or stay a little longer as you please.

examples.kr: 그녀에게 전화하든지 아니면 메시지를 보내든지 반드시 연락을 취해야 해요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoege jeonhwahadeonji animyeon mesijireul bonaedonji bandeusi yeollageul chehaeya haeyo.
examples.en: You must make contact by either calling her or sending a message.

title: ~라도 [rado] (At least, even if)
short_explanation: Used to express the minimum action or condition; 'at least', 'even if'.
long_explanation: '~라도 [rado]' is a widely used ending in Korean to indicate the smallest or least action or condition that can or should be done. It depicts a sense of concession, similar to 'at least' or 'even if' in English. It is used to convey a minimum expectation or a condition that is less than ideal but is better than nothing.

examples.kr: 이 일을 할 수 없다면, 도움이라도 주세요.
examples.romaji: I ireul hal su eopdamyeon, doumirado juseyo.
examples.en: If you can't do this work, at least help.

examples.kr: 그는 수업에 참여하지 않았지만, 책을라도 읽었어야 했습니다.
examples.romaji: Geuneun sueobe chamyeohaji anhatjiman, chaeg eulrado ilgeosseoya haetsseumnida.
examples.en: He didn't participate in the class, but he should have at least read the book.

examples.kr: 시험에 떨어졌지만, 다시 시도라도 해보겠습니다.
examples.romaji: Siheome tteoreojyeotjiman, dasi sidorado haebogessseumnida.
examples.en: I failed the exam, but I will at least try again.

examples.kr: 영화를 보러 가고 싶지 않아도, 친구들이 영화를 좋아한다면 함께라도 가겠어요.
examples.romaji: Yeonghwareul boreo gago sipji anhado, chingudeuri yeonghwareul joahandamyeon hamgkerado gagessseoyo.
examples.en: Even if I don't want to go see a movie, I would at least go with them if my friends like the movie.

title: ~라든지 [radeunji] (Or something)
short_explanation: Used to indicate alternatives or options; 'or something', 'for example'
long_explanation: '~라든지 [radeunji]' is a conjunctive particle in Korean, used to suggest alternatives or possibilities, or to list examples. This particle is commonly used when the speaker is unsure, or when they want to offer some examples but do not wish to list everything. It's comparable to English expressions like 'or something', 'for example', 'such as', etc.

examples.kr: 커피라든지, 차라든지, 어떤 음료라도 마시겠어요?
examples.romaji: Keopiradeunji, charadeunji, eoddeon eumryorado masigesseoyo?
examples.en: Would you like to drink any beverage, like coffee or tea, or something?

examples.kr: 도서관에서 공부하라든지, 집에서 책을 읽으라든지, 저는 항상 많이 배우고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Doseogwaneseo gongbuharadeunji, jibeseo chaeg-eul ilg-euradeunji, jeoneun hangsang mani baeugo iss-eoyo.
examples.en: Whether studying at the library, reading books at home, or something else, I am always learning a lot.

examples.kr: 여행하라든지, 새로운 취미를 찾아보라든지, 당신이 즐거움을 찾기 위해 해 볼 수 있는 많은 일들이 있어요.
examples.romaji: Yeohaengharadeunji, saeroun chwimireul chajaboradeunji, dangsin-i jeulgeoum-eul chajgi wihae hae bol su issneun manh-eun ildeul-i iss-eoyo.
examples.en: There are many things you could try to find joy, like travelling or finding a new hobby, or something.

examples.kr: 사과라든지, 배라든지, 과일 중에서 어떤 것을 가장 좋아하십니까?
examples.romaji: Sagwaradeunji, baeradeunji, gwail jung-eueseo eoddeon geos-eul gajang joh-ahabnida?
examples.en: Among fruits, which one do you like most, such as apple, pear, or something?

title: ~라면 [ramyeon] (If it's the case that)
short_explanation: Used to express the hypothetical condition 'if it's the case that'.
long_explanation: '~라면 [ramyeon]' is a conditional suffix used in Korean to establish the hypothetical condition 'if it's the case that'. This structure is used when the speaker wants to make a hypothetical statement or question about a certain situation. Often used in hypothetical, conjectural or imaginary contexts, the subject or topic can be essentially anything, as long as it can be the basis for a 'if it is the case that' scenario.

examples.kr: 당신이 그 사실을 먼저 알았다면, 왜 저에게 말해주지 않았어요?
examples.romaji: Dangshini geu sasireul meonjeo alatdamyeon, wae jeoege malhaejueoji anhasseoyo?
examples.en: If you knew that fact first, why didn't you tell me?

examples.kr: 내일 비가 오라면, 우산을 챙겨야겠어요.
examples.romaji: Naeil biga oramyeon, usaneul chaenggyeoyagesseoyo.
examples.en: If it's going to rain tomorrow, I'll have to take an umbrella.

examples.kr: 내가 천재라면, 이 문제를 쉽게 해결할 수 있겠지요.
examples.romaji: Naega cheonjaeramyeon, i munjeleul swipge haegyeolhal su issgessjiyo.
examples.en: If I were a genius, I could solve this problem easily.

examples.kr: 영화를 보러 가고 싶다면, 저녁에 우리가 같이 가요.
examples.romaji: Yeonghwareul boreo gago sipdamyeon, jeonyeoge uriga gachi gayo.
examples.en: If you want to go see a movie, let's go together in the evening.

title: ~라면서 [ramyeonseo] (While saying that)
short_explanation: Used to express an action or state that contradict what one has said previously.
long_explanation: '~라면서 [ramyeonseo]' is a Korean grammar used to express an act or state that contradicts what has been stated by oneself or by someone else. It is used when the speaker's or someone else's action contradicts the previous statement. This pattern can also be used to denote that something was said and remain unchanged.

examples.kr: 그가 공부를 하겠다라면서 계속 게임을 하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Geuga gongbureul hagetsdaramyeonseo gyesok geimeul hago isseoyo.
examples.en: While he says he will study, he keeps playing games.

examples.kr: 그녀는 돈을 절약하겠다라면서 지금 쇼핑을 하러 가고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun doneul jeolyaghagetsdaramyeonseo jigeum syopingeul hareo gago isseoyo.
examples.en: While promising to save money, she is going shopping now.

examples.kr: 나는 다이어트를 해야 한다라면서 매일 달콤한 음식을 먹고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun daieoteureul haeya haramyeonseo maeil dalkomhan eumsigeul meokgo isseoyo.
examples.en: While I say I have to diet, I eat sweet food every day.

examples.kr: 우리 아버지는 흡연을 그만두겠다라면서 아직도 담배를 피우고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Uri abeojineun heubyoneul geumandugetsdaramyeonseo ajikdo dambaereul piugo isseoyo.
examples.en: Despite my father's promise to quit smoking, he is still smoking.

title: ~려고 [ryeogo] (In order to)
short_explanation: Used to show the intent or purpose of an action; 'in order to', 'to'.
long_explanation: '~려고 [ryeogo]' is used in Korean to express the intent or purpose of an action. It is often translated as 'in order to' or 'to' in English. It helps to specify the reason why the action in the main clause is being done, pointing to the intention or goal of the subject's action.

examples.kr: 한국어를 잘 하기 위해서 매일 한국어를 공부하려고 노력하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Hangug-eoleul jal hagi wihaeseo maeil hangug-eoleul gongbuhae ryeogo nolyeog hago isseoyo.
examples.en: I'm studying Korean every day in order to speak it well.

examples.kr: 다이어트를 하려고 운동하고, 칼로리를 줄이려고 많이 노력했어요.
examples.romaji: Daieoteuleul haryeo nun donghago, kallo lileul julligo mani noryeoghaesseoyo.
examples.en: I exercised a lot to diet and reduced my intake of calories in order to lose weight.

examples.kr: 이번 시험을 잘 보려고 많이 공부하고, 일찍 자려고 노력했습니다.
examples.romaji: Ibeon siheom-eul jal bo ryeogo mani gongbu hago, iljjik ja ryeogo noryeoghaessseubnida.
examples.en: I studied a lot to do well on this exam and tried to go to bed early.

examples.kr: 엄마가 행복하게 하려고 매일 방을 정리하고, 맛있는 음식을 만들어 드렸어요.
examples.romaji: Eommaga haengbokhage haryeo go maeil bang-eul jeongni hago, masissneun eumsig-eul mandeuleo deulyeosseoyo.
examples.en: To make my mother happy, I cleaned the room every day and made delicious food for her.

title: ~려고 하다 [ryeogo hada] (Try to)
short_explanation: '려고 하다' is used to express one's intention or the try to do something. It can be translated as 'try to' or 'plan to'.
long_explanation: This grammar point, ~려고 하다 [ryeogo hada], is used to express the intention or the effort to do something. It's a common structure when someone is planning or trying to do something. This phrase is often used in sentences where someone is intending to do something in the near future. It's equivalent to 'try to' or 'plan to' in English.

examples.kr: 저는 오늘 학교에 가려고 했는데, 비가 와서 갈 수 없었어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun oneul hakgyoe garyeogo haessneunde, biga waseo gal su eopseosseoyo.
examples.en: I intended to go to school today, but because it rained I couldn't go.

examples.kr: 삼촌은 내일 우리 집에 올려고 했지만 차가 고장나서 오지 못했어요.
examples.romaji: Samchoneun naeil uri jibe olryeogo haessjiman chaga gojangnaseo oji moshaesseoyo.
examples.en: My uncle tried to come to our house tomorrow, but he couldn't because his car broke down.

examples.kr: 나는 당신에게 전화려고 했어요, 그러나 배터리가 다 되어서 전화를 하지 못했어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun dangsinege jeonhwaryeogo haesseoyo, geureona baeteoriga da doeeoseo jeonhwareul haji moshaesseoyo.
examples.en: I tried to call you, but I couldn't because my battery was dead.

examples.kr: 친구들이 함께 영화를 보려고 했지만 표가 매진되어 보지 못했습니다.
examples.romaji: Chingudeuli hamkke yeongwareul boryeogo haessjiman pyoga maejindoeeo boji moshaessseubnida.
examples.en: My friends and I tried to watch a movie together, but we couldn't because the tickets were sold out.

title: ~려는데 [ryeonde] (I'm planning to, I want to)
short_explanation: Used to express a plan or intention.
long_explanation: '~려는데 [ryeonde]' is a grammar point in Korean that is used to express the speaker's planning or intention to do something. It is used when the speaker has a set plan or a certain inclination towards doing something in future. It infers that the person is going to take a certain action but it hasn't been executed yet. This form can also be used for rudimentary plans that may change depending on the situation.

examples.kr: 책을 사러 서점에 가려는데 비가 너무 많이 와서 아마 갈 수 없을 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Chaegeul sareo seojeme garyeonde biga neomu manhi wasseo ama gal su eopseul geos gatayo.
examples.en: I plan to go to the bookstore to buy a book, but it's raining so much that I probably can't go.

examples.kr: 디너를 준비하려는데 필요한 재료가 부족해서 장을 보러 가야 될 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Dineoreul junbi ryeonde pilyohan jaeryoga bujokhaeseo jangeul boreo gaya doel geos gatayo.
examples.en: I plan to prepare dinner, but I think I need to go grocery shopping because I lack the necessary ingredients.

examples.kr: 친구에게 선물을 주려는데 무슨 선물을 줄지 아직 결정하지 못했어요.
examples.romaji: Chinguege seonmureul juryeonde museun seonmureul julji ajik gyeoljeonghaji mothaesseoyo.
examples.en: I plan to give a gift to my friend, but I still haven't decided what gift to give.

examples.kr: 이번 주말에 영화를 보러 가려는데 모든 표가 예약되어서 보러 갈 수 없을 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Ibeon jumale yeonghwareul boreo garyeonde modeun pyoga yeyakdoeseo boreo gal su eopseul geos gatayo.
examples.en: I plan to go to a movie this weekend, but it seems like I cannot go because all the tickets are reserved.

title: ~마다 [mada] (Every)
short_explanation: Used to express 'every' or 'each' in Korean language.
long_explanation: '~마다 [mada]' is a postposition in Korean that is used to indicate 'every' or 'each'. This can refer to every instance of a recurring event, each item of a group or every part of a certain period. The time, space, distance, or frequency becomes more specific by this particle, giving a sense of every single instance within a defined scope.

examples.kr: 나는 주마다 도서관에 가서 책을 빌려와 읽어요, 그래서 새로운 지식을 계속 쌓아가고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun jumada doseogwane gaseo chaegreul billyeowa ilgeo, geuraeseo saeroun jisigeul gyesok ssahagago isseoyo.
examples.en: I go to the library and borrow books to read every week, so I am continually accumulating new knowledge.

examples.kr: 매일 아침마다 새로운 기분으로 하루를 시작하자, 그래야 좋은 일이 생길 것이야.
examples.romaji: Maeil achimmada saeroun gibuneuro harureul sijakhaja, geuraeya joheun iri saenggil geosiya.
examples.en: Let's start each day with a fresh feeling every morning, then good things will happen.

examples.kr: 저는 친구와 매달 말마다 영화를 보러 가요, 그래서 항상 새로운 영화를 볼 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun chinguwa maedal malmada yeonghwareul boreo gayo, geuraeseo hangsang saeroun yeonghwaleul bol su isseoyo.
examples.en: I go to see a movie with my friend at the end of each month, so I can always watch a new movie.

examples.kr: 우리는 여름마다 해변에 가서 즐거운 시간을 보낼 예정입니다, 그래서 여름이 기다려지는 죠.
examples.romaji: Urineun yeoreummada haebyeone gaseo jeulgeoun siganeul bonael yejeongimnida, geuraeseo yeoreumi gidaryeojineun jyo.
examples.en: We plan to go to the beach every summer to have a good time, so we look forward to summer.

title: ~만큼 [mankeum] (As much as)
short_explanation: This pattern is used to show the extent or degree of something or to compare two things.
long_explanation: '~만큼 [mankeum]' is a grammar point used to express 'as much as' or 'equivalent to' in English.
