It allows you to compare two things and denote that one thing is done or is to the extent as the other. This grammar point is often used to express comparison, equivalence or proportionality.

examples.kr: 당신이 좋아하면 그만큼 저도 좋아합니다, 감정은 항상 상호적인 것이니까요.
examples.romaji: Dangsini joahamyeon geumankeum jeodo joahamnida, gamjeongeun hangsang sanghojeokin geosinikka.
examples.en: As much as you like, I like it too, because emotions are always reciprocal.

examples.kr: 우리 아버지는 젊을 때만큼 빠르게 달리지는 못하지만 여전히 체력이 좋아요.
examples.romaji: Uri abeojineun jeolmeul ttaemankeum ppareuge dallijineun motajiman yeojeonhi cheryeogi joayo.
examples.en: My father can't run as fast as he did when he was young, but he still has good stamina.

examples.kr: 이 책은 읽을수록 좋아요, 책의 뒷 부분을 보면 앞 부분만큼 흥미로워요.
examples.romaji: I chaek-eun ilgeulsurok joayo, chaek-ui dwit bu-bun-eul bomyeon ap bu-bunmankeum heungmirowoyo.
examples.en: The more you read this book, the better it gets, the back of the book is as interesting as the front part.

examples.kr: 당신이 얼마나 노력하느냐에 따라 성공할 수 있는 가능성이 그만큼 높아집니다.
examples.romaji: Dangsini eolmana noryeokhaneunyae ddara seonggonghal su issneun ganeungseong-i geumankeum nopajimnida.
examples.en: The more effort you put in, the higher the chance of success.

title: ~면 [myeon] (If, when)
short_explanation: Used to express the conditional 'if' or to intimate a situation of 'when'.
long_explanation: '면 [myeon]' is suffix that you can attach to a verb to express the English equivalent of 'if' or 'when.' It is effectively used to describe a hypothetical situation or to propose a condition in the future. This pattern also implies that the situation in the main clause will automatically or naturally occur if/when the condition of the dependent clause is met.

examples.kr: 저는 밥을 먹으면 행복해지는 기분이에요. 마치 배고픔을 해결하는 것처럼요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun babeul meogeumyeon haengbokhaejineun gibunieyo. Machi baegopeumeul haegyeolhaneun geotcheoreomyeo.
examples.en: I feel happy when I eat. It's like solving hunger.

examples.kr: 수업이 끝나면 바로 집에 가려고 해요. 너무 피곤해서 공부할 의욕이 없어요.
examples.romaji: Sueobi kkeutnamyeon baro jibe garyeogo haeyo. Neomu pigonhaeseo gongbuhal uiyogi eopsseoyo.
examples.en: If the class ends, I intend to go home immediately. I'm too tired to have the passion to study.

examples.kr: 시험을 합격하면 친구들과 함께 파티를 열려고 생각하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Siheomeul hapgyeokhamyeon chingudeulgwa hamkke patireul yeollyeogo saenggakago isseoyo.
examples.en: If I pass the test, I'm thinking of throwing a party with my friends.

examples.kr: 저를 더 이상 짓누르면 결국에는 저는 앞으로 나아갈 용기를 잃을 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Jeoreul deo isang jisnurumyeon gyeolgugeneun jeoneun ap-eulo naagal yonggireul ilheul geos gatayo.
examples.en: If you keep pressing me down, I think I will eventually lose the courage to move forward.

title: ~면서 [myeonseo] (While)
short_explanation: This is a conjunction used to connect two actions happening at the same time.
long_explanation: The expression '~면서 [myeonseo]' is used in Korean grammar to indicate two actions or situations happening simultaneously. This can be directly translated to the English conjunctiona 'while' or ‘and'. This grammar point is used when the subject of both actions is the same, and both actions occur during the same time period. It is suitable to use when there is no sequence of occurrence between the connected verb clauses

examples.kr: 나는 음악을 들으면서 공부를 해요. 그러면 훨씬 더 집중이 잘 돼요.
examples.romaji: Naneun eumageul deuleumyeonseo gongbureul haeyo. Geureomyeon hwolssin deo jipjungi jal dwaeyo.
examples.en: I study while listening to music. It helps me to concentrate much better.

examples.kr: 우리 엄마는 요리를 하면서 노래도 불러요. 그 모습이 너무 사랑스러워요.
examples.romaji: Uri eommaneun yorireul hamyeonseo noraedo bulleoyo. Geu moseubi neomu sarangseureowoyo.
examples.en: My mom cooks and sings at the same time. It's a really lovely sight.

examples.kr: 저는 자전거를 타면서 책을 읽을 수는 없어요. 그렇게 하면 너무 위험해요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun jajeongeoreul tamyeonseo chaegeul ilgeul suneun eopseoyo. Geureohge hamyeon neomu wiheomhaeyo.
examples.en: I can't read a book while riding a bicycle. It's too dangerous that way.

examples.kr: 친구와 이야기하면서 커피를 마셔요. 그래서 카페를 자주 가요.
examples.romaji: Chinguwa iyagihamyeonseo keopireul masyeoyo. Geuraeseo cafereul jaju gayo.
examples.en: I drink coffee while chatting with friends. That's why I often go to cafes.

title: ~밖에 [bakke] (Nothing but, only)
short_explanation: Used to express 'nothing but' or 'only', indicating limited choices or possibilities.
long_explanation: '~밖에 [bakke]' is a postposition in Korean grammar indicating limitation or exclusivity. It is used to express that only the item or person referred to exists or is relevant. So, this pattern is usually used in a negative sentence to emphasize the scarcity or the sole option of something and is often used in sentences to express a limited number, quantity, or possibility.

examples.kr: 나는 한국어밖에 몰라서 다른 나라에서 생활하는 데 너무 어려워요.
examples.romaji: Naneun Hangugeobakke mollaseo dareun naraseo saenghwalhaneun dede neomu eoryeowoyo.
examples.en: It's too difficult for me to live in other countries because I know nothing but Korean.

examples.kr: 이 가게에서는 감자튀김밖에 팔지 않아서 선택할 만한 것이 별로 없어요.
examples.romaji: I gageeseoneun gamjatwigimbakke palji anhaseo seontaekhal manhan geosi byeollo eopseoyo.
examples.en: This shop only sells French fries, so there are not much to choose from.

examples.kr: 그녀는 카페에서 머핀밖에 사지 않아서 다른 메뉴를 모르겠어요.
examples.romaji: Gyeonuneun kapeeseo meopinbakke saji anhaseo dareun menyu-reul moreugesseoyo.
examples.en: She buys nothing but muffins at the cafe, so she doesn't know other menus.

examples.kr: 이번 주말은 우리 집에서 쉬는 거밖에 할 수 없어요, 모든 친구들이 바빠서 만날 수 없어요.
examples.romaji: Ibeon jumal-eun uri jib-eseo swineun geobakke hal su eopseoyo, modeun chingudeuli bappaseo mannal su eopseoyo.
examples.en: I can't do anything but rest at home this weekend, because all of my friends are too busy to meet.

title: ~보다 [boda] (More than)
short_explanation: Used to make comparative expressions equivalent to 'more than' in English.
long_explanation: '~보다 [boda]' is a particle in Korean that is used to make comparative statements. It translates to 'more than' in English. It is appended to a noun or a verb stem to indicate that something is superior, larger, better, more, etc than the other thing. In contrast to English where the thing you are comparing to comes after 'than', in Korean, it comes before '보다'.

examples.kr: 저는 커피보다 차를 더 좋아해요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun keopiboda chareul deo joahaeyo.
examples.en: I like tea more than coffee.

examples.kr: 이번 여름은 작년 여름보다 더 더웠어요.
examples.romaji: Ibeon yeoreumeun jaknyeon yeoreumboda deo deowosseoyo.
examples.en: This summer was hotter than last summer.

examples.kr: 내가 평소에 보다 더 많이 밥을 먹었어요.
examples.romaji: Naega pyeongsoe bodadeo manhi babeul meogeosseoyo.
examples.en: I ate more rice than I usually do.

examples.kr: 지금 시간은 밤 10시보다 더 늦어요.
examples.romaji: Jigeum siganeun bam 10siboda deo neujeoyo.
examples.en: The current time is later than 10 o'clock at night.

title: ~부터 [buteo] (From, starting from)
short_explanation: This is used to express the beginning point of an action, location, or time.
long_explanation: ~부터 [buteo] is a commonly used grammar point in Korean that generally indicates the starting point of an action, location, or time. It is equivalent to 'from' in English when used to illustrate the beginning moment, place, action, or status from which an event or situation commences. It's additionally used to list out items or points in no particular order.

examples.kr: 내일은 아침 일곱 시부터 수업이 시작되니까 늦지 않게 준비해야 해요.
examples.romaji: Naeireun achim ilgop shibuteo sueobi sijakdoenikka neutji anhge junbihaeya haeyo.
examples.en: The class starts from seven o'clock in the morning tomorrow, so we should prepare so as not to be late.

examples.kr: 여행 가방을 정리할 때는 옷부터 시작했어요, 그 다음에는 악세사리를 정리했어요.
examples.romaji: Yeohaeng gabangeul jeongrihal ttaeneun otbuteo sijakhaesseoyo, geu daeumeneun aksesarireul jeongrihaesseoyo.
examples.en: When I organized my travel bags, I started with the clothes, and then I organized the accessories.

examples.kr: 이 식당에서는 점심 열두 시부터 오후 세 시까지 점심 메뉴를 판매하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: I sikdangesoneun jeomsim yeoldu shibuteo ohu se shikkaji jeomsim menyureul panmaehago isseoyo.
examples.en: At this restaurant, they sell lunch menus from twelve noon to three in the afternoon.

examples.kr: 이번달부터 다음해 초까지 이 프로젝트를 완성해야 해요.
examples.romaji: Ibeondalbuteo daeumhae chokkaji i peurojekteureul wanseonghaeya haeyo.
examples.en: We need to complete this project from this month until the beginning of next year.

title: ~서는 [seoneun] (But in)
short_explanation: Used to indicate contrast or contradiction.
long_explanation: '~서는 [seoneun]' is a connecting form used in Korean to indicate a contrast or contradiction between two situations or actions. It is similar to 'but in' or 'but when' in English. It is often used when expressing disappointment, surprise, or a counterargument related to what was said or done.

examples.kr: 그 친구는 일본어도 잘하고 중국어도 잘해서는, 한국어는 전혀 못해요.
examples.romaji: Geu chinguneun ilboneodo jalhago junggugeodo jalhaseoneun, hangug-eoneun jeonhyeo mothae-yo.
examples.en: That friend can speak Japanese and Chinese well, but in Korean, he can't speak at all.

examples.kr: 난요리를 잘하긴 해서는, dessert를 만들줄은 모르겠어요.
examples.romaji: Nan yori-reul jalhagin haeseoneun, dessert-reul mandeuljuleun moreugesseoyo.
examples.en: I cook well, but in making desserts, I don't think I can do it.

examples.kr: 그는 시험을 잘 봤다고 했는데, 결과를 보니까 그는 망했어서는, 저는 놀랐어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun siheomeul jal bwassdago haessneunde, gyeolgwareul bonikka geuneun manghaesseoneun, jeoneun nollaesseoyo.
examples.en: He said he did well on the test, but in result, he failed and I was surprised.

examples.kr: 동생은 항상 방을 깨끗하게 관리한다 했는데, 실제로 보면 방은 너무 지저분해서는, 진짜로 실망했어요.
examples.romaji: Dongsaeng-eun hangsang bang-eul kkaegeuthage gwanlihanda haessneunde, siljero bomyeon bang-eun neomu jigeobeunhaseoneun, jinjjaro shilmanghaesseoyo.
examples.en: My younger sibling said they always keep their room clean, but in reality, the room is so messy that I was really disappointed.

title: ~아/어 보이다 [a/eo boida] (Looks/seems like)
short_explanation: Used to make a subjective judgement or prediction about someone or something based on their appearance or situation.
long_explanation: '~아/어 보이다 [a/eo boida]' is an expression used in Korean to make an observation about someone or something based on how things appear to be. This grammar point often adds a sense of subjectivity or assumption to a statement, similar to the English phrases 'looks like', 'seems like', or 'looks as though'.

examples.kr: 내일은 날씨가 좋아 보여요, 외출하면 좋을 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Naeireun nalssiga joa boyeoyo, oechulhamyeon joeul geot gatayo.
examples.en: It looks like the weather will be nice tomorrow, it might be good to go out.

examples.kr: 그 친구는 종종 외로워 보이더라고요, 도와주면 좋을 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Geu chinguneun jongjong oerowo boideragoyo, dowajumyeon joeul geot gatayo.
examples.en: That friend often seems lonely, I think it would be good to help him/her.

examples.kr: 진희씨는 요즘 정말 바빠 보이네요, 부지런하게 일하는 모습을 보면 장래가 기대됩니다.
examples.romaji: Jinhee-ssi-neun yojeum jeongmal bappa boineyo, bujireonhage ilhaneun moseubeul bomyeon jangraega gidaedoebnida.
examples.en: Jinhee seems really busy these days, seeing her working hard makes me look forward to her future.

examples.kr: 이렇게 많이 먹어도 배가 고파 보이는 건 어떻게 설명할 수 있을까요?
examples.romaji: Ireoke manhi meogeodo baega gopa boineun geon eotteoke seolmyeonghal su isseulkka?
examples.en: How can we explain that you seem hungry even though you eat so much?

title: ~아/어 버리다 [a/eo beorida] (Completely do, unfortunately do)
short_explanation: '~아/어 버리다' is used either to indicate the extent of an action (completely) or an action that is an unfortunate occurrence.
long_explanation: '~아/어 버리다' is a common grammar structure in Korean which is added to the stem of a verb to emphasize either complete realization of the action expressed by the verb, or the regretful, unfortunate effect of that action. While the usual translation is 'completely', depending on the context, it can also imply regret, sudden and complete realization of an action. It's often used in cases where the speaker feels sorry for the result of the action or they didn't want it to happen.

examples.kr: 처음 만나는 여자 친구를 기다리다가 너무 늦어서 저는 잠을 자버렸어요.
examples.romaji: Cheoeum mannaneun yeoja chingureul gidaridaga neomu neujeoseo jeoneun jameul jaboryeosseoyo.
examples.en: I fell asleep while waiting for my girlfriend who I was meeting for the first time because it got too late.

examples.kr: 과제가 너무 어려워서 나는 그냥 포기해 버렸어요.
examples.romaji: Gwaje ga neomu eoryeowoseo, naneun geunyang pogihae beoryeosseoyo.
examples.en: The assignment was so difficult, I ended up just giving up.

examples.kr: 가방을 버스에 두고 내려서 잊어버렸어요.
examples.romaji: Gabangeul beoseue dugo naeryeo seo ijeobeoryeosseoyo.
examples.en: I left my bag on the bus and got off and completely forgot about it.

examples.kr: 야구 경기에서 우리 팀이 너무 나빠서 점수를 전부 잃어버렸어요.
examples.romaji: Yagu gyeonggieseo uri timi neomu nappaseo jeomsureul jeonbu ilheobeoryeosseoyo.
examples.en: Our team was so bad in the baseball game, we ended up losing all our points.

title: ~아/어 두다 [a/eo duda] (Keep, leave)
short_explanation: Used to express the idea of leaving or keeping something in a certain state or condition.
long_explanation: '~아/어 두다 [a/eo duda]' is a Korean grammar pattern used to indicate the act of leaving something in a specific state or keeping it as it is for a certain period of time. It often implies an intentional act to maintain or preserve something for future use or reference. The form will change depending on the verb stem – if it ends with a vowel, '아 두다' is used; if the verb stem ends with a consonant, '어 두다' is typically used.

examples.kr: 사랑하는 사람을 위해 좋은 추억을 만들어 두는 것이 중요해요.
examples.romaji: Saranghaneun sarameul wihae joheun chueogeul mandeureo duneun geosi jungyoaeyo.
examples.en: It's important to create and keep good memories for the person you love.

examples.kr: 요리를 너무 많이 만들었어요, 나중에 먹기 위해 냉장고에 저장해 두었어요.
examples.romaji: Yorireul neomu manhi mandeureosseoyo, najunge meokgi wihae naengjanggoe jeojanghae dueosseoyo.
examples.en: I made too much food, so I left it in the refrigerator for later.

examples.kr: 공부하다가 모르는 단어를 찾으면 노트에 적어 두는 것이 좋아요.
examples.romaji: Gongbuhadaga moreuneun daneoreul chajeumyeon noteue jeogeoduneun geosi joayo.
examples.en: When studying, if you come across a word you don't know, it's good to write it down and keep it.

examples.kr: 나는 나의 꿈을 이루기 위해 항상 노력을 아끼지 않고 노력해 두었어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun nayi kkumeul irugi wihae hangsang noryeogeul akkiji anhgo noryeokhae dueosseoyo.
examples.en: I always made an effort and kept striving for my dream without holding back on any efforts.

title: ~아/어 가다 [a/eo gada] (Go on doing)
short_explanation: This grammar point is used to express the continuous action of something.
long_explanation: '~아/어 가다 [a/eo gada]' is a Korean grammar form that is used to express the continuity or duration of an action. It gives the implication that the action keeps ongoing without a specific end, much like 'go on doing something' in English. This form indicates that the action is done steadily or continuously, perhaps even despite difficulties.

examples.kr: 그는 매일 아침 운동을 해 가면서 건강을 유지하려고 노력합니다.
examples.romaji: Geuneun maeil achim undongeul hae gamyeonseo geongangeul yujihaeryeo noryeokhamnida.
examples.en: He goes on exercising every morning to maintain his health.

examples.kr: 그녀는 학교에 다니면서 일을 해 가고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun hakgyoe danimyeonseo ileul hae gago isseoyo.
examples.en: She goes on working while attending school.

examples.kr: 우리는 큰 어려움에도 불구하고 프로젝트를 계속 해 가고 있습니다.
examples.romaji: Urineun keun eoryeoumedo bulguhago peurojekteureul gyesok hae gago itsseumnida.
examples.en: Despite great difficulties, we go on with the project.

examples.kr: 친구들이 포기함에도 불구하고, 저는 연습을 계속 해 가고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Chingudeuli pogihamedo bulguhago, jeoneun yeonseubeul gyesok hae gago isseoyo.
examples.en: Despite my friends giving up, I go on practicing.

title: ~아/어 오다 [a/eo oda] (Come to do)
short_explanation: Used to express the process of doing something over time or gradual change.
long_explanation: '~아/어 오다 [a/eo oda]' is a verb ending used in Korean to express an action that has been in progress or developing up to the present moment. The ending carries a sense of gradual change along a continuous timeline. It can give the meaning of accumulation of a certain action until the present moment. In English, it might be roughly equivalent to expressions like 'have been doing', 'have become' or 'come to do' depending on the context.

examples.kr: 그는 한 달 동안 매일 한국어를 공부하여 오다 보니 이제 한국어를 유창하게 할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun han dal dongan maeil hangug-eoreul gongbuhae oda boni ije hangug-eoreul yuchanghage hal su iss-eoyo.
examples.en: He has been studying Korean every day for a month, so now he can speak Korean fluently.

examples.kr: 우리는 매일 같이 운동하다가 어느새 강해져 오다 보니 마라톤도 완주할 수 있게 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Urineun maeil gachi undonghadaga eoneusae ganghaejyeo oda boni marathon-do wanjuhal su itge doeeosseoyo.
examples.en: We have gradually become stronger by exercising together every day, and now we can even finish a marathon.

examples.kr: 미나는 그림을 그려오다 보니 점점 잘 그리게 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Mina-neun geurimeul geuryeo oda boni jeomjeom jal geurige doeeosseoyo.
examples.en: Mina has come to draw well by drawing pictures continually.

examples.kr: 해가 저무어 오다 보니 곧 어둠이 밀려들어 왔어요.
examples.romaji: Haega jeomueo oda boni got eodumi millyeodeureowasseoyo.
examples.en: As the sun set, darkness soon came rolling in.

title: ~아/어야 하다 [a/eoya hada] (Have to, must)
short_explanation: Used to express obligation or necessity.
long_explanation: The '~아/어야 하다 [a/eoya hada]' endings refer to the necessity to do something or the feeling of obligation in a situation. This can also be used to express 'have to' or 'must' in English. It is also used in sentences to express compulsion imposed by situations or conditions. The verb stem is used with '아야 하다' for verbs that end in vowels and '어야 하다' for verbs that end in consonants.

examples.kr: 내일 시험이 있으니까 오늘 밤에 공부하아야 해요.
examples.romaji: Naeil siheomi isseunikka oneul bame gongbuhaoaya haeyo.
examples.en: I must study tonight because I have an exam tomorrow.

examples.kr: 회사에 늦지 않기 위해 7시에 집을 나가아야 해요.
examples.romaji: Hoesae neujji anhgi wihae chil shie jibeul nagaaya haeyo.
examples.en: I must leave home at 7 to not be late for work.

examples.kr: 야외 활동을 할 때는 태양으로부터 피부를 보호하아야 해요.
examples.romaji: Yawoe hwaldongeul hal ttaeneun taeyangeurobuteo pibureul bohohaoaya haeyo.
examples.en: You must protect your skin from the sun when doing outdoor activities.

examples.kr: 좋은 점수를 받기 위해 더 열심히 공부하아야 해요.
examples.romaji: Joeun jeomsureul badgi wihae deo yeolsimhi gongbuhaoaya haeyo.
examples.en: I must study harder to get a good score.

title: ~아/어야지 [a/eoyaji] (I'm going to)
short_explanation: Expresses speaker's strong intention or resolution to do something in the future.
long_explanation: The '~아/어야지 [a/eoyaji]' grammatical form is used to express a speaker's determination or strong intention towards something that will or should happen in the future. It can be used when announcing a decision or making a strong resolution. It is often used with first person subjects, referring to the speaker or the speaker's group.

examples.kr: 진짜 공부를 더 열심히 해야지, 이번에는 정말로 성적을 높이기 위해 노력할 것이다.
examples.romaji: Jinjja gongbureul deo yeolsimhi haeyaji, ibeoneun jeongmallo seongjeogeul nopigi wihae noryeokhal geotida.
examples.en: I really should study harder, this time I am really going to work hard to raise my grades.

examples.kr: 내일 아침에 일어나서 운동을 해야지, 건강을 위해 더 신경 써야겠어.
examples.romaji: Naeil achime ireonaseo undongeul haeyaji, geongangeul wihae deo singyeong sseoyagesseo.
examples.en: I am going to wake up tomorrow morning and work out, I need to pay more attention to my health.

examples.kr: 이제는 진짜로 흡연을 그만두어야지, 내 건강이 너무 걱정돼서 결심했다.
examples.romaji: Ijeneun jinjjaro heupyeoneul geumandueoyaji, nae geongangi neomu geokjeongdwaeseo gyeolsimhaetda.
examples.en: Now I really have to quit smoking, I've made up my mind because I'm too worried about my health.

examples.kr: 엄마에게 전화를 해야지, 꽤 오랜 시간이 지났으니 연락을 좀 더 자주해야겠어.
examples.romaji: Eommaege jeonhwareul haeyaji, kkwae orae sigani jinasseuni yeonrageul jom deo jajuhaeyagesseo.
examples.en: I should call my mom, it's been quite some time so I need to keep in touch more frequently.

title: ~아/어도 [a/eodo] (Even if)
short_explanation: Used to express 'even if' or 'although'.
long_explanation: '~아/어도 [a/eodo]' is a conjunction used in Korean to express the meaning of 'even if' or 'although', which is often used in sentences to indicate a conditional or hypothetical situation. This grammar point is somewhat equivalent to 'even if' in English and is used to express a condition which will not affect the outcome of the situation despite being fulfilled, in other words, the action in the second clause will still be true regardless of whether the condition in the first clause is fulfilled or not.

examples.kr: 여기에 있는 음식은 아무리 비싸도 맛있어서 자주 먹어요.
examples.romaji: Yeogie issneun eumsikeun amuri bissado masisseoseo jaju meogeoyo.
examples.en: No matter how expensive the food here is, it's delicious so I eat it often.

examples.kr: 아무리 빨리 달려도 학교에 늦는 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Amuri ppalli dallyeodo hakgyoe neutneun geot gatayo.
examples.en: Even if I run fast, it seems I'm late for school.

examples.kr: 내가 얼마나 노력해도 그 프로젝트를 완성할 수 없을 것 같아.
examples.romaji: Naega eolmana noryeokhaedo geu peurojekteureul wanseonghal su eopseul geot gata.
examples.en: No matter how hard I try, I don't think I can complete that project.

examples.kr: 운동을 아무리 해도 제 몸에 만족하지 못하겠어요.
examples.romaji: Undongeul amuri haedo je mome manjokhaji mothagesseoyo.
examples.en: No matter how much I exercise, I can't be satisfied with my body.

title: ~아/어서 [a/eoseo] (Because, so)
short_explanation: Used to express reason or cause, 'because', 'so'.
long_explanation: '~아/어서 [a/eoseo]' is a conjunctive ending in Korean language that is used to show the reason or cause of something. It can be translated as 'because' or 'so' in English. It adds explanation or reason to the main clause and is commonly used in everyday speech and writing.

examples.kr: 머리가 아파서 학교에 갈 수 없었습니다.
examples.romaji: Meoriga apaseo hakgyoe gal su eopseosseumnida.
examples.en: I couldn't go to school because I had a headache.

examples.kr: 오늘 날씨가 좋아서 산책하러 갔습니다.
examples.romaji: Oneul nalssiga johaseo sanchaekhaneureo gatsseumnida.
examples.en: I went for a walk because the weather was good today.

examples.kr: 이 영화가 재미있어서 두 번 봤어요.
examples.romaji: i yeonghwaga jaemiisseoseo du beon bwasseoyo.
examples.en: I watched this movie twice because it was interesting.

examples.kr: 그녀는 책을 잃어서 슬퍼합니다.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun chaegul irheoseo seulpeohamnida.
examples.en: She is sad because she lost her book.

title: ~았/었던 [ass/eossdeon] (Was)
short_explanation: Used to express past state or condition; 'was'.
long_explanation: '~았/었던 [ass/eossdeon]' is a past tense modifier used in Korean to discuss something that existed or occurred in the past. It is similar to the English past tense 'was' or 'were'. This grammar form is usually used to modify a noun, indicating that the noun was in a particular state or did something in the past. The choice of 았 or 었 in the structure depends on the verb's final vowel sound.

examples.kr: 저는 학교에서 천재였던 학생이었어요, 국어, 수학, 과학, 사회에서 모두 최고의 성적을 받았어요.
examples.romaji: jeoneun haggyoeseo cheonjaeyeossdeon hagsaeng-yeosseoyo, gugeo, suhag, gwahag, sahoeeseo modu choegoui seongjeogeul bad-ass-eoyo.
examples.en: I was a genius student at school, receiving the highest grades in Korean, math, science, and social studies.

examples.kr: 내가 어릴 때 좋아했던 가수는 신화였어요, 그들의 음악은 항상 제 기억에 남아요.
examples.romaji: naega eoril ttae johahaessdeon gasuneun sinawayeosseoyo, geudeul-ui eumag-eun hangsang je gieog-e nam-a yo.
examples.en: The singer I liked when I was young was Shinhwa, their music always remains in my memory.

examples.kr: 우리 아버지가 어렸을 때에는 가난했던 사람이었어요, 하지만 지금은 잘 살고 있어요.
examples.romaji: uri abeojiga eoryeoss-eul ttaeeneun gananhaessdeon saramieosseoyo, hajiman jigeum-eun jal salgo iss-eoyo.
examples.en: My father was a poor person when he was young, but now he is living well.

examples.kr: 그녀는 학교 시절에는 너무 조용했던 사람이었는데, 지금은 엄청 활발해진 거 같아요.
examples.romaji: geunyeoneun hakgyo sijeol-eneun neomu joyonghaessdeon saramieossneunde, jigeum-eun eomcheong hwalbalhaejin geo gat-a yo.
examples.en: She was a very quiet person during her school days, but now she seems to have become very active.

title: ~았/었어야 했다 [ass/eosseoya haessda] (Should have done)
short_explanation: Used to express regret for not doing something that should have been done in the past.
long_explanation: '~았/었어야 했다 [ass/eosseoya haessda]' is a Korean grammar pattern used to express feelings of regret or to state that something should have been done in the past but was not. It means 'should have done' in English. This formation can make students understand the speaker's sense of regret for something they neglected to do.

examples.kr: 저는 어제 그 일을 해야 했는데 시간이 없어서 안 했어요. 많이 후회하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun eoje geu ileul haeya haessneunde sigani eopseoseo an haeyo. mani huhoehago isseoyo.
examples.en: I should have done that work yesterday, but I didn't because I didn't have time. I regret it a lot.

examples.kr: 오늘 아침에는 운동을 해야 했지만 나는 너무 게으르게 느껴져서 안 했어요.
examples.romaji: Oneul achimeneun undongeul haeya haessjiman naneun neomu geueuruge neukkyeojyeoseo an haesseoyo.
examples.en: I should have exercised this morning, but I felt too lazy so I didn't.

examples.kr: 당신은 그런 상황에서 따뜻하게 대해야 했는데 차가운 태도를 보였어요.
examples.romaji: Dangsineun geureon sanghwangeseo ddaddeushage daehaeya haessneunde chagaun taedoreul boyeosseoyo.
examples.en: You should have reacted warmly in such a situation, but you showed a cold attitude.

examples.kr: 저는 그날 잔뱅을 어떻게든 피해야 했는데 못 했어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun geunal janbaengeul eotteokedeun pihaeya haessneunde mot haesseoyo.
examples.en: I should have somehow avoided the fight that day, but I couldn't.

title: ~았/었으면 [ass/eosseumyeon] (I wish it were)
short_explanation: '~았/었으면' is used to express a wish or desire for a situation to be different from what it currently is.
long_explanation: '~았/었으면 [ass/eosseumyeon]' is a grammar point that is commonly used in Korean to express hypothetical or unreal situations. It is often translated into English as 'I wish it were' or 'if only'. It is used to express regret, unfulfilled wishes, or desires for a situation to be different from its current state. Note that this form is used in the past tense verb form which indicates a desire for something that has not been fulfilled.

examples.kr: 저는 어릴 때부터 음악가가 되고 싶었어요. 진짜 음악가가 되었으면 좋겠어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun eoril ttaebuteo eumakgaga doego sip-eoss-eoyo. Jinjja eumakgaga doeeoss-eumyeon johgess-eoyo.
examples.en: Since I was young, I wanted to become a musician. I wish I really became a musician.

examples.kr: 날씨가 좋았으면 좋겠어요. 그럼 우리가 함께 산책하러 갈 수 있을 텐데요.
examples.romaji: Nalssiga joh-ass-eumyeon johgess-eoyo. Geuleom uliga hamkke san-chaekhaleo gal su iss-eul tendeyo.
examples.en: I wish the weather was good. Then, we could go for a walk together.

examples.kr: 마지막으로 그와 만났을 때 좋은 이야기를 들려줬으면 좋겠어요.
examples.romaji: Majimag-eulo geuwa mannass-eul ttae joheun iyagileul deullyeojwoss-eumyeon johgess-eoyo.
examples.en: I wish I told him a good story when I met him last time.

examples.kr: 약속을 지켰으면 좋겠어요. 그럼 다른 사람들이 저를 더 신뢰할 수 있었을 거예요.
examples.romaji: Yagsog-eul jikyeoss-eumyeon johgess-eoyo. Geuleom daleun salamdeul-i jeoleul deo sinloehal su iss-eoss-eul geoyeyo.
examples.en: I wish I had kept my promise. Then other people could have trusted me more.

title: ~았/었을 텐데 [ass/eosseul tende] (I assume it must have been)
short_explanation: Used to express assumption or expectation based on past events.
long_explanation: '~았/었을 텐데 [ass/eosseul tende]' is a Korean grammar point used to express the speaker's speculation or presumption about a past situation. It indicates that the speaker believes something must have been a certain way, even though they are not completely certain. It's a combination of the past tense conjugation '~았/었' and '을 텐데' which expresses assumption or expectation.

examples.kr: 너무 바빴을 텐데 그 일을 다 하지 못했을 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Neomu bappass-eul tende geu il-eul da haji moshaess-eul geos gat-ayo.
examples.en: I assume you didn't manage to do all the work as it must have been too busy.

examples.kr: 당신이 그렇게 많이 공부했을 텐데 문제를 풀수 있었나요?
examples.romaji: Dangsini geuleohge mani gongbuyeoss-eul tende munjereul pulsueossnayo?
examples.en: Considering you studied that much, I assume you were able to solve the problems?

examples.kr: 그녀가 너무 행복했을 텐데 왜 눈물을 흘렸을까요?
examples.romaji: Geunyeoga neomu haengboghass-eul tende wae nunmureul heullyeoss-eulkka yo?
examples.en: She must have been so happy, so I wonder why she shed tears?

examples.kr: 날씨가 화창했을 텐데 여행이 재미있었을 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Nalssi-ga hwachanghaess-eul tende yeohaeng-i jaemiisseoss-eul geos gat-a yo.
examples.en: I assume the trip must have been enjoyable, considering the weather was so nice.

title: ~았/었다가 [ass/eossdaga] (Was and then)
short_explanation: This grammar point is used to express something that happened in the past, then changed or was followed by another occurrence.
long_explanation: The '~았/었다가 [ass/eossdaga]' grammar structure is used in Korean to denote a change in state, behavior, or situation, signifying that something was one way and then changed. It is typically used with eventive verbs, which describe dynamic events or activities that have an endpoint, and generally follows the sequential events that occurred in the past.

examples.kr: 저는 학교에 갔다가 도서관에서 공부를 하러 갔어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun hakgyoe gassdaga doseogwaneseo gongbureul hareo gasseoyo.
examples.en: I went to school, and then I went to the library to study.

examples.kr: 그는 일을 했다가 집으로 돌아갔어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun ireul haessdaga jibeuro doragasseoyo.
examples.en: He worked, and then he went home.

examples.kr: 나는 친구를 만났다가 영화를 보러 갔어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun chingureul mannassdaga yeonghwareul boreo gasseoyo.
examples.en: I met a friend, and then I went to see a movie.

examples.kr: 우리는 점심을 먹었다가 공원에서 산책을 했어요.
examples.romaji: Urineun jeomsimeul meogeossdaga gongwoneseo sancharerul haesseoyo.
examples.en: We ate lunch, and then we took a walk in the park.

title: ~았/었다면 [ass/eossdamyeon] (If it had been)
short_explanation: This is used to express hypothetical situations in the past, meaning 'if it had been'.
long_explanation: The grammar point ~았/었다면 is used to imagine a different outcome for a past situation. The '다면' added after a verb or adjective in past tense form creates a hypothetical or unreal condition in the past. This form is used to express regret, or to consider what could have happened if another condition would have been met in the past.

examples.kr: 그때 그의 조언을 들었다면 지금 현재 상황이 다르지 않았을까요?
examples.romaji: Geuttae geuui joyeoneul deureossdamyeon jigeum hyeonjae sanghwangi dareuji anhasseulkkayo?
examples.en: If I had listened to his advice at that time, wouldn't the current situation be different?

examples.kr: 자기의 실수를 인정했다면 큰 난관에 봉착하지 않았을 텐데.
examples.romaji: Jagiui silsureul injeonghaessdamyeon keun nangwane bongchagji anhasseul tende.
examples.en: If he had acknowledged his mistake, he wouldn't have ended up in a big predicament.

examples.kr: 어제 비가 왔다면 축구 경기가 취소되었을까요?
examples.romaji: Eoje biga watdamyeon chukgu gyeonggiga chwisodoeeosseulkka yo?
examples.en: If it had rained yesterday, would the soccer match have been cancelled?

examples.kr: 더 빨리 도착했다면 그녀를 만날 수 있었을텐데.
examples.romaji: Deo ppalli dochakhaessdamyeon geunyeoreul mannal su isseosseultende.
examples.en: If I had arrived earlier, I could've met her.

title: ~으면 좋겠다 [eumyeon joketda] (I hope, it would be good if)
short_explanation: This expression is used to express a wish or hope for a certain situation or result.
long_explanation: '~으면 좋겠다 [eumyeon joketda]' is a Korean grammar point used to express a hope or desire for a certain event or situation. It translates roughly as 'I hope' or 'It would be good if' in English. This is often used in situations where the speaker is hoping for a positive outcome or result.

examples.kr: 날씨가 좋으면 좋겠다, 그래야 꽃놀이가 더 즐거울 것 같아.
examples.romaji: Nalssiga joh-eumyeon johketda, geuraeya kkotnoliga deo jeulgeoul geos gata.
examples.en: I hope the weather is good, then the flower viewing will be more enjoyable.

examples.kr: 시험을 잘 보면 좋겠다, 그럼 학기가 끝나면 여행을 갈 수 있을 것 같아.
examples.romaji: Siheomeul jal bom-eumyeon johketda, geuleom hak-giga kkeutnamyeon yeohaeng-eul gal su iss-eul geos gata.
examples.en: I hope I do well on the exam, then I think I can go on vacation when the semester ends.

examples.kr: 아픈 친구가 빨리 나으면 좋겠다, 그럼 함께 놀러 갈 수 있을 것이야.
examples.romaji: Apeun chinguga ppalli na-eumyeon johketda, geuleom hamkke nol-eo gal su iss-eul geos-eya.
examples.en: I hope my sick friend gets better soon, then we can go out together.

examples.kr: 코로나가 끝나면 좋겠다, 그럼 다시 일상생활로 돌아갈 수 있을 것 같아.
examples.romaji: Kolonaga kkeutna-eumyeon joketda, geuleom dasi ilsangsaenghwallo dolagal su isseul geos gata.
examples.en: I hope Corona ends, then I think we can return to normal life.

title: ~으면서도 [eumyeonseodo] (While, but still)
short_explanation: Used to express contradiction; 'while', 'but still'.
long_explanation: '~으면서도 [eumyeonseodo]' is a conjunction used in Korean to show two contrasting situations or conditions in the same sentence. It is used to express that while a certain situation holds true, there is another situation that contradicts or contrasts with it. It can be translated into English as 'while', 'but still', 'even though', or 'despite'.

examples.kr: 그는 건강에 좋지 않으면서도 매일 패스트푸드를 먹어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun geongange joji anheumyeonseodo maeil paeseuteupudeureul meogeyo.
examples.en: He eats fast food every day, while knowing it's bad for his health.

examples.kr: 너무 바쁘면서도 항상 친구들과 시간을 만들어내요.
examples.romaji: Neomu bappeumyeonseodo hangsang chingudeulgwa siganeul mandeureonaeyo.
examples.en: She's really busy, but still, she always makes time for her friends.

examples.kr: 아파트 값이 비싸면서도 계속 증가하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Apateu gagi bissamyeonseodo gyesok jeunggahago isseoyo.
examples.en: Apartment prices are increasing, even though they're already expensive.

examples.kr: 인터넷이 느리면서도 많은 정보를 얻을 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Inteonesi neurimyeonseodo manheun jeongboreul eodeul su isseoyo.
examples.en: Internet is slow, but still, you can get a lot of information.

title: ~을/ㄹ 거예요 [eul/l geoyeyo] (Going to, will)
short_explanation: This grammar point is used to express future intention - 'going to' or 'will'.
long_explanation: The Korean grammar point '~을/ㄹ 거예요 [eul/l geoyeyo]' is used to indicate something that the speaker has the intention of doing or something that will happen in the future. It's similar to use of 'going to' or 'will' in English. It's attached to the stem of a verb or adjective. If the stem ends in a vowel, we use 'ㄹ 거예요', and if it ends in a consonant, we use '을 거예요'.

examples.kr: 저는 이번 주말에 쇼핑을 갈 거예요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun ibeon jumale syopingeul gal geoyeyo.
examples.en: I am going to go shopping this weekend.

examples.kr: 내일 비가 올 거예요.
examples.romaji: Naeil biga ol geoyeyo.
examples.en: It will rain tomorrow.

examples.kr: 엄마는 저녁으로 김치찌개를 만들 거예요.
examples.romaji: Eommaneun jeonyeogeuro gimchijjigaereul mandeul geoyeyo.
examples.en: Mom will make kimchi stew for dinner.

examples.kr: 우리의 팀은 다음 대회에서 반드시 이길 거예요.
examples.romaji: Uriui timeun daeum daehoeso bandeusi igil geoyeyo.
examples.en: Our team will definitely win in the next competition.

title: ~을/ㄹ게요 [eul/l geyo] (I will)
short_explanation: Used to express future intention; 'I will'.
long_explanation: '~을/ㄹ게요 [eul/l geyo]' is a verb ending in Korean that is used to state the speaker’s intention to do something in the near future. It's a way to promise or assure someone that you will do something, or to state what you have decided to do. The form '을게요' is used after verbs ending in a vowel and 'ㄹ게요' is used after verbs ending in a consonant.
formation: Verb stem + ~을게요 (if the verb stem ends with a vowel) or Verb stem + ~ㄹ게요 (if the verb stem ends with a consonant).

examples.kr: 저는 내일 학교에 가서 친구를 만날게요. 오랜만에 보는 친구라 정말 기대되요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun naeil hakgyoe gaseo chingureul mannalgeyo. Oranmane boneun chingura jeongmal gidaedoeyo.
examples.en: I will go to school tomorrow and meet my friend. I'm really looking forward to seeing my friend who I haven't seen in a long time.

examples.kr: 매일 밤 10시에 자러 갈게요. 건강을 위해 더 일찍 자는 것이 필요한 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Maeil bam 10sie jareo galgeyo. Geongangeul wihae deo iljjik janeun geosi pilyohan geot gatayo.
examples.en: I will go to sleep at 10 pm every night. I think I need to go to bed earlier for my health.

examples.kr: 저는 주말에 운동을 할게요. 운동을 하면 몸이 건강해져서 좋아요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun juemal-e undong-eul halgeyo. Undong-eul hamyeon mom-i geonganghaejyeoseo joayo.
examples.en: I will exercise on the weekend. It's good to exercise because it makes the body healthier.

examples.kr: 내일 밥을 사러 갈게요. 집에 먹을 것이 별로 없어요.
examples.romaji: Naeil bab-eul sareo galgeyo. Jib-e meog-eul geos-i byeollo eobs-eoyo.
examples.en: I will go to buy some food tomorrow. There's not much to eat at home.

title: ~을/ㄹ게요 [eul/l geyo] (In order to)
short_explanation: '~을/ㄹ게요 [eul/l geyo]' is used to express future intentions in an informal manner.
long_explanation: In Korean, this grammar point '~을/ㄹ게요 [eul/l geyo]' is used when the speaker wants to inform the listener of his/her future plan or intention. This grammar point can be perceived as informal and somewhat friendly. Therefore, it can be frequently observed in informal conversations among friends or family members.

examples.kr: 음악에 푹 빠져서, 피아노 배울게요.
examples.romaji: Eumak-e pook ppajyeoseo, piano baeulgeyo.
examples.en: I'll learn the piano because I'm very into music.

examples.kr: 시간이 좀 걸릴 것 같아요, 하지만 새로운 언어 공부할게요.
examples.romaji: Sigan-i jom geollil geos gat-ayo, hajiman saeroun eoneo gongbuhalgeyo.
examples.en: It might take time, but I will study a new language.

examples.kr: 맛있는 음식을 만드는 방법을 배우고 싶어서 요리 클래스를 들을게요.
examples.romaji: Masissneun eumsik-eul mandeuneun bangbeob-eul baeugo sip-eoseo yoli keulaseu-leul deulgeyo.
examples.en: I'm going to take a cooking class to learn how to make delicious food.

examples.kr: 다음 주 중에 시간을 내서 친구들과 함께 영화를 볼게요.
examples.romaji: Da-eum ju jung-e sigan-eul naeseo chingudeul-gwa hamkke yeonghwa-reul bolgeyo.
examples.en: I'll make time next week to watch a movie with my friends.

title: ~을/ㄹ까요? [eul/l kkayo?] (Shall we?)
short_explanation: Used to suggest or propose an action to do together or ask for the listener's suggestion.
long_explanation: '~을/ㄹ까요? [eul/l kkayo?]' is a Korean sentence ending used to suggest or propose activities that the speaker would like to do with the listener. It can also be used to ask for the listener's opinion on a particular matter. This form is mostly used in informal polite situations and is translated as 'Shall we?' or 'Should we?' in English.
formation: 1st Verb Stems ending in vowel: Verb stem + 를까요? | 2nd Verb Stems ending in consonant: Verb stem + 을까요?

examples.kr: 함께 저녁을 먹을까요? 맛있는 음식을 할 수 있는 식당을 아는데.
examples.romaji: Hamkke jeonyeogeur meogeulkka yo? Mas itneun eum sik eu rul ha l su iss neun sik dang eul a neun de.
examples.en: Shall we eat dinner together? I know a restaurant where we can have delicious food.

examples.kr: 영화를 볼까요? 오늘은 좋은 영화가 상영 중입니다.
examples.romaji: Yeonghwa reul bolkka yo? Oneul eun joheun yeonghwa ga sang yeong jung i ssseub nida.
examples.en: Shall we watch a movie? Today, a good movie is playing.

examples.kr: 주말에 여행을 갈까요? 분위기 변화가 필요해 보이는데.
examples.romaji: Jumal e yeohaeng eul galkka yo? Bunwig i byonhwa ga pilyo hae bo i neun de.
examples.en: Shall we go on a trip on the weekend? It seems like we need a change of atmosphere.

examples.kr: 우리 산책을 할까요? 날씨가 너무 좋아 보여서.
examples.romaji: Uri san chaek eul halkka yo? Nalssi ga neu mu joa boyeo seo.
examples.en: Shall we go for a walk? The weather looks so good.

title: ~을/ㄹ 때 [eul/l ttae] (When)
short_explanation: Used to denote the point in time 'when' something takes place.
long_explanation: '~을/ㄹ 때 [eul/l ttae]' is a grammar structure used to indicate the time when an action occurs. It can be translated to 'when' in English. This grammar point is used to connect two events that happen at the same time or to indicate the condition when the action occurs. Depending on the verb stem it is attached to, it can be written as '을 때' after a consonant ending or 'ㄹ 때' after vowel ending.
formation:
Verb stem + 을 때 (if verb stem ends in a consonant)
 OR
 Verb stem + ㄹ 때 (if verb stem ends in a vowel)
 + Sentence

examples.kr: 책을 읽을 때는 조용한 곳에서 읽는 것이 좋아요.
examples.romaji: Chaeg-eul ilgeul ttaeneun joyonghan gos-eseo ilgneun geosi joayo.
examples.en: I prefer to read in a quiet place when I read a book.

examples.kr: 친구를 만날 때 항상 많이 웃어요.
examples.romaji: Chingureul mannal ttae hangsang mani useoyo.
examples.en: I always laugh a lot when I meet a friend.

examples.kr: 시험 볼 때 늘 긴장해요.
examples.romaji: Siheom bol ttae neul ginjanghaeyo.
examples.en: I always get nervous when I take a test.

examples.kr: 비가 올 때는 우산을 가져가야 해요.
examples.romaji: Biga ol ttaeneun usaneul gajyeogaya haeyo.
examples.en: You need to take an umbrella when it's raining.

title: ~을/ㄹ 듯하다 [eul/l deushada] (Seems like)
short_explanation: Used to express that something seems like or feels like something; 'it seems like' or 'it feels like'.
long_explanation: '~을/ㄹ 듯하다 [eul/l deushada]' is a construction used in Korean to express the idea that something has the appearance or gives the feeling of something else. This form is used when the speaker wants to express a conjecture or assumption based on his or her observation or feeling. The action verb, descriptive verb or noun that comes before 듯하다 carries the meaning, and 듯하다 itself expresses the seemingness or likeness.
formation: Action verb / Descriptive verb / Noun + ~을/ㄹ 듯하다

examples.kr: 그는 마치 변한 것처럼 보여서, 옛날의 그대로인 것을 듯하다.
examples.romaji: Geuneun machi byeonhan geotcheoreom boyeoseo, yeonnalui geudaeroin geoseul deushada.
examples.en: He seems to be just like he was in the old days, as if he hasn't changed.

examples.kr: 오늘이 마치 겨울인 것처럼 춥다, 가을인 것을 듯하다.
examples.romaji: Oneuri machi gyeoulin geotcheoreom chupda, gaeurin geoseul deushada.
examples.en: It's cold today as if it's winter, it feels like it's autumn.

examples.kr: 그의 눈빛은 마치 무슨 생각에 잠긴 것처럼 보여요, 깊게 생각하고 있는 것을 듯하다.
examples.romaji: Geuui nunbicheun machi museun saenggage jamgin geotcheoreom boyeoyo, gipge saenggakago issneun geoseul deushada.
examples.en: His look seems as if he's absorbed in some thought, it feels like he's thinking deeply.

examples.kr: 그녀는 마치 웃을 것처럼 웃지 않았어요, 무슨 일이 있는 것을 듯했어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun machi useul geotcheoreom utji anhasseoyo, museun iri issneun geoseul deushaesseoyo.
examples.en: She didn't smile as if she was about to, it seemed like something was going on.

title: ~을/ㄹ 만하다 [eul/l manhada] (Worth doing)
short_explanation: Used to express that something is worth doing or experiencing.
long_explanation: '~을/ㄹ 만하다' is a grammar point used in Korean to express the judgment that something is worth the effort, time, or price. It signifies that an action, event, or situation is considered valuable or justified enough for the effort or cost involved in carrying it out. It translates into 'worth doing' or 'worth it' in English.

examples.kr: 이 케이크는 비싸지만 맛있어서 사 먹을 만해요.
examples.romaji: I keikeuneun bissajiman masisseoseo sa meok-eul manhaeyo.
examples.en: This cake is expensive but it's delicious, so it's worth buying and eating.

examples.kr: 이 영화는 시간을 많이 걸리지만 정말 재미있어서 보러 갈 만해요.
examples.romaji: I yeonghwaneun siganeul mani geollimjiman jeongmal jaemiisseoseo boreo gal manhaeyo.
examples.en: This movie takes a lot of time, but it's really fun, so it's worth going to see.

examples.kr: 그 밴드의 콘서트 티켓은 많이 비싸지만 그들의 사운드를 듣기 위해 구매할 만해요.
examples.romaji: Geu baendeuui konsa-teu tikeseun mani bissajiman geudeul-ui saundeu-reul deudgi wihae gumaehal manhaeyo.
examples.en: Those band's concert tickets are very expensive, but it's worth buying to hear their sound.

examples.kr: 이 게임은 설치하는데 시간이 오래 걸려도 제게는 플레이할 만해요.
examples.romaji: I geim-eun seolchihaneunde sigan-i orae geollyeodo jegen-eun peulleihal manhaeyo.
examples.en: This game takes a long time to install, but for me, it's worth playing.

title: ~을/ㄹ 수록 [eul/l surok] (The more)
short_explanation: Used for expressing 'the more...the more' comparative form in Korean.
long_explanation: The grammar point '~을/ㄹ 수록 [eul/l surok]' is used to indicate that as the action or state in the first clause increases or changes, so does the action or state in the second clause. It is primarily used with verbs, and it is similar to 'the more... the more' in English. In essence, it shows a proportional or parallel increase or change between two events or conditions.

examples.kr: 한국어를 많이 공부할수록 한국어 문화를 더 잘 이해할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Hangug-eoleul mani gongbuhal surog hangug-eo munhwareul deo jal ihaehal su iss-eoyo.
examples.en: The more you study Korean, the better you understand Korean culture.

examples.kr: 여기에 오래 있을수록, 이 도시가 점점 더 좋아져요.
examples.romaji: Yeogie orae isseulsurok, i dosiga jeomjeom deo joajyeoyo.
examples.en: The more I stay here, the more I like this city.

examples.kr: 걷기를 매일 할수록 건강이 점점 좋아져요.
examples.romaji: Geotgireul maeil halsurok geongangi jeomjeom joajyeoyo.
examples.en: The more I walk every day, the healthier I get.

examples.kr: 커피를 많이 마실수록 잠이 덜 올 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Keopireul mani masilsurok jami deol ol geot gatayo.
examples.en: The more coffee I drink, the less likely I am to fall asleep.

title: ~을/ㄹ 줄 알다 [eul/l jul alda] (Know how to)
short_explanation: This grammar point is used to indicate that someone knows how to do something or knows that something is the case.
long_explanation: '~을/ㄹ 줄 알다 [eul/l jul alda]' is used when the speaker wants to indicate that someone, often themselves, knows how to do a certain action, or is aware that something is the case. It can be translated as 'know how to' or 'know that' in English. It implies an understanding of how to perform a skill or an awareness of a certain fact or situation.
formation: Verb in Dictionary Form + 을/ㄹ 줄 알다

examples.kr: 제가 한글을 읽을 줄 알아요, 그래서 한국 드라마를 자막 없이 볼 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Jega hangeureul ilgeul jul arayo, geuraeseo hanguk deurameul jamak eopsi bol su isseoyo.
examples.en: I know how to read Hangul, so I can watch Korean dramas without subtitles.

examples.kr: 아빠가 요리를 잘할 줄 알았어요, 하지만 어제 저녁 만들 때 문제가 많이 생겼어요.
examples.romaji: Appaga yorireul jall jul arasseoyo, hajiman eoje jeonyeok mandeul ttae munjega mani saenggyeosseoyo.
examples.en: I thought Dad knew how to cook well, but there were many problems when he made dinner last night.

examples.kr: 저는 그녀가 한국인이라는 것을 줄 알았어요, 그래서 그녀에게 한국어로 말했어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun geunyeoga hangukiniran geoseul jul arasseoyo, geuraeseo geunyeoege hangugeo-ro malhaesseoyo.
examples.en: I knew that she was Korean, so I spoke to her in Korean.

examples.kr: 우리 강아지는 명령을 따를 줄 알아요, 그래서 잘 훈련된 강아지라고 생각해요.
examples.romaji: Uri gangajineun myeonglyeongeul ttarul jul arayo, geuraeseo jal hullyuendoen gangajirago saenggakhaeyo.
examples.en: Our puppy knows how to follow commands, so I think it's well trained.

title: ~을/ㄹ지 [eul/lji] (Whether or not)
short_explanation: Used to express uncertainty or doubt; 'whether or not'.
long_explanation: '~을/ㄹ지 [eul/lji]' is a grammar point used in Korean to express doubt, uncertainty or question about an event or outcome, akin to 'whether or not' in English. It is frequently used in indirect questions and conditional sentences to indicate the unsure nature. It is attached after the verb stem and shows the speaker is not sure about the possibility of the situation.

examples.kr: 우리 아빠가 저녁에 홈으로 돌아올지 모르겠어요.
examples.romaji: Uri abba-ga jeonyeoke homeuro dolaolji molla.
examples.en: I don't know whether our dad will return home tonight.

examples.kr: 그녀가 내일 파티에 올지 안 올지 나는 정말 궁금해.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoga naeil patie olji an olji naneun jeongmal gunggeumhae.
examples.en: I'm really curious whether or not she will come to the party tomorrow.

examples.kr: 날이 따뜻해질지 아직 확실하지 않아.
examples.romaji: Nari ttatteokaejilji ajik hwaksilha-ji anha.
examples.en: I'm not sure yet whether the weather will get warmer.

examples.kr: 당신이 제안을 받아들일지 안 받아들일지 나는 알 수 없어.
examples.romaji: Dangsin-i jegong-eul badadeurilji an badadeurilji naneun al su eobseo.
examples.en: I don't know whether or not you will accept the proposal.

title: ~을/ㄹ지도 모르다 [eul/ljido moreuda] (Might)
short_explanation: This is used to express uncertainty or possibility.
long_explanation: '~을/ㄹ지도 모르다 [eul/ljido moreuda]', or simply 'might' in English, is a grammar pattern that is used to represent the speaker's uncertainty or to express the possibility of a future event or condition. The pattern can be translated into English as 'might' or 'might not' depending on context. The verb should match the subject in formality and respect in its form.

examples.kr: 내일 비가 올지도 모르니까 우산을 가져가세요.
examples.romaji: Naeil biga oljido moreunikka usaneul gajyeogaseyo.
examples.en: It might rain tomorrow, so take an umbrella.

examples.kr: 그는 다음 회의에 참석할지도 모릅니다.
examples.romaji: Geuneun daeum hoeuie chamseokhaljido moreumnida.
examples.en: He might attend the next meeting.

examples.kr: 저는 아마 내년에 한국으로 이사할지도 모르겠어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun ama naenyeone hangugeuro isahaljido moreugesseoyo.
examples.en: I might move to Korea next year.

examples.kr: 그녀가 그 소식을 알고 있을지도 모르죠.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoga geu sosigeul algo isseuljido moreujyo.
examples.en: She might know that news.

title: ~을/ㄹ지라도 [eul/ljirado] (Even if)
short_explanation: Used to say 'even if'; 'no matter how/if'; nonetheless.
long_explanation: '~을/ㄹ지라도 [eul/ljirado]' is a conditional form used in Korean to express the meaning of 'even if', 'no matter how' or 'nonetheless'. This grammar point is used when the speaker wants to say that 'it wouldn't matter' even if the situation or condition were to occur. It usually indicates that the expected result won't change despite the given condition.

examples.kr: 문제가 어렵지라도 포기하지 않고 계속 풀어볼게요.
examples.romaji: Munjega eoryeobjirado pogihaji anhgo gyesok pulleobolgeyo.
examples.en: Even if the problem is difficult, I won't give up and I'll keep trying to solve it.

examples.kr: 비가 오지라도 갈 생각이에요, 제가 중요한 미팅이 있어요.
examples.romaji: Biga ojirado gal saenggakieyo, jegA jungyohan mitingi isseoyo.
examples.en: Even if it's raining, I'm planning to go, as I have an important meeting.

examples.kr: 너무 빠르지라도 절대 쫓아가지 않아요, 안전이 우선이에요.
examples.romaji: Neomu ppareujirado jeoldae jochagaji anhayo, anjeoni useonieyo.
examples.en: Even if it's too fast, I will never chase, safety first.

examples.kr: 비용이 많이 들지라도 좋은 품질의 제품을 만들고 싶어요.
examples.romaji: Biyongi manhi deuljirado joheun pumjilui jepumeul mandeulgo sippeoyo
examples.en: Even if it costs a lot, I want to make a product of good quality.

title: ~을/ㄹ지 몰라 [eul/lji molla] (Maybe)
short_explanation: Used to express uncertainty or doubt; 'maybe', 'might', 'I don't know if'
long_explanation: '~을/ㄹ지 몰라 [eul/lji molla]' is an uncertain form in Korean grammar used to indicate doubts, uncertainties, or suppositions. It can be translated as 'maybe', 'might', or 'I don’t know if' in English. This form is typically used when the speaker is unsure of something or wants to convey a speculative premise.

examples.kr: 그녀가 내일 학교에 올지 몰라, 요즘 아프다니까.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoga naeil haggyoe olji molla, yojeum apeudanikka.
examples.en: Maybe she will come to school tomorrow, she said she's been sick lately.

examples.kr: 이 물건을 사려고 했는데, 아직 돈이 충분할지 몰라요.
examples.romaji: I mulgeoneul saryeogo haetneunde, ajik doni chungbunhalji mollayo.
examples.en: I was planning to buy this item, but I don't know if I have enough money.

examples.kr: 내일 비가 올지 몰라서 우산을 준비해야겠어요.
examples.romaji: Naeil biga olji mollaseo usaneul junbihaeyagesseoyo.
examples.en: I should prepare an umbrella because it might rain tomorrow.

examples.kr: 어떤 옷을 입을지 몰라서 세 가지를 준비했어요.
examples.romaji: Eoddeon oseul ibeulji mollaseo se gajireul junbihaesseoyo.
examples.en: I prepared three different clothes because I'm not sure which one to wear.

title: ~을래요 [eullaeyo] (Want to)
short_explanation: Used to express the speaker 'wants' to do something or 'would like' to do something.
long_explanation: '~을래요 [eullaeyo]' is a verb ending in Korean that is used to express an intention, suggestion, or a polite proposal from the speaker's point of view. It denotes that the speaker 'wants to' do or 'would like' to do. It can also express a plan or a proposal to do something in the future. Note that the verb must be attached directly to a verb stem.

examples.kr: 저는 오늘 집에서 영화를 볼래요, 외부로 나가기가 너무 추워요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun oneul jibeseo yeonghwareul bollae, oebeuro nagagiga neomu chuwoyo.
examples.en: I want to watch a movie at home today, it's too cold to go out.

examples.kr: 우리 이번 주말에 캠핑장에 가서 텐트를 칠래요, 어떻게 생각해요?
examples.romaji: Uri ibeon jumal-e keampingjang-e gaseo tent-eul chillae, eotteoke saengkaekhae?
examples.en: How about we go to the campground this weekend and pitch a tent?

examples.kr: 나는 저녁을 하나 먹을래요, 아직 배가 고파서 더 먹지 않을래요.
examples.romaji: Naneun jeonyeogeul hana meogeullae, ajik baega gopaeseo deo meokji anheullae.
examples.en: I want to eat just one meal in the evening, I don't want to eat more because I'm still hungry.

examples.kr: 나는 이번 주말에 팔리를 보러 갈래요, 한국의 문화를 좋아해서 결심했어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun ibeon jumal-e pallileul boreo gallae, hangug-ui munhwareul joahaseo gyeolsimhaess-eoyo.
examples.en: I've decided to go see a play this weekend because I like Korean culture.

title: ~을리가 없다 [eulliga eopda] (It's unlikely that)
short_explanation: This expression is used to indicate that a certain situation is unlikely or impossible to happen.
long_explanation: '~을리가 없다 [eulliga eopda]' is a speculative expression used in Korean to indicate that something is improbable or implausible based on the speaker's reasoning or judgment. It is used to express uncertainty or disbelief about the possibility of a certain situation or event occurring. The '~을리가 없다 [eulliga eopda]' form is often used to contrast reality with a hypothetical situation or an assumption.

examples.kr: 이것이 사실일리가 없어요, 그가 그런 일을 저지를 사람이 아니에요.
examples.romaji: Igeosi sasilliga eobs-eoyo, geuga geuleon il-eul jeojileul salam-i ani-eyo.
examples.en: It's unlikely that this is true, he's not the one to do such a thing.

examples.kr: 그녀가 날 잊어버릴리가 없어요, 우리 너무 오래 같이 지냈거든요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoga nal ij-eobeurilliga eobs-eoyo, uli neomu olae gati jinaessgeodeunyo.
examples.en: It's unlikely that she would forget me, we've been together for a long time.

examples.kr: 저는 이 계약서를 사인할리가 없어요, 제가 아직 조건들을 모두 이해하지 못했어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun i gyeagseoreul sainhalliga eobseoyo, jega ajik jogeondeul-eul modu ihaehaji moshaesseoyo.
examples.en: It's unlikely that I will sign this contract, I still do not fully understand the terms.

examples.kr: 그가 오늘 올 리가 없어요, 그거 알고 있어요 그가 아픈 걸.
examples.romaji: Geuga oneul ol riga eopseoyo, geugeo algo isseoyo geuga apeun geol.
examples.en: It's unlikely that he will come today, I know he's sick.

title: ~을수록 [eulsurok] (The more)
short_explanation: Used to express 'the more...the more', or an increasing degree or intensity in a certain state or action.
long_explanation: The grammar point '~을수록 [eulsurok]' is used in Korean to indicate an increasing degree or intensity in a certain state or action. It expresses the idea that as one thing or condition intensifies, another thing or condition also intensifies proportionately. It is equivalent to the phrase 'the more...the more' in English, showing a proportional link between two events or situations.

examples.kr: 한국어를 공부할수록, 한국 문화에 대해 더 많이 이해할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Hangugeoreul gongbuhal suruk, hanguk munhwae daehae deo mani ihaehal su isseoyo.
examples.en: The more I study Korean, the more I can understand about Korean culture.

examples.kr: 이 노래를 많이 들을수록, 더 좋아지는 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: I noraereul mani deuleulsurok, deo joajineun geot gatayo.
examples.en: The more I listen to this song, the more I seem to like it.

examples.kr: 날이 점점 더워질수록, 아이스크림이 더 많이 팔려요.
examples.romaji: Nari jeomjeom deoweojilsurok, aiseukeurimi deo manhi pallyeoyo.
examples.en: The hotter the day gets, the more ice cream is sold.

examples.kr: 사람들이 친환경 제품을 사용할수록, 환경보호에 더 많은 기여를 할 수 있습니다.
examples.romaji: Saramdeuri chimhwangyeong jepumeul sayonghalsurok, hwangyeong bohoe deo manheun giyeoreul hal su itsseumnida.
examples.en: The more people use eco-friendly products, the more they can contribute to environmental protection.

title: ~을지언정 [euljieonjeong] (Even though)
short_explanation: This phrase is used to indicate 'even though' or 'despite'.
long_explanation: '~을지언정 [euljieonjeong]' is a conjunction utilized in Korean language that conveys the meaning of 'even though', 'even if', or 'despite'. It is used when presenting a contrasting situation or fact that exists despite the previous statement or condition. While typically used in formal or written language, it is still useful to understand and practice for broader comprehension and for use in the TOPIK test.

examples.kr: 그것이 그에게 굉장히 중요한 일일지언정, 그는 결코 그것에 손을 대지 않았다.
examples.romaji: Geugeosi geuege goengjanghi jungyohan iriljieonjeong, geuneun gyeolko geugeos-e son-eul daeji anh-assda.
examples.en: Even though that was very important to him, he never laid a hand on it.

examples.kr: 그가 부자일지언정, 평소에 아주 절약하는 습관이 있다.
examples.romaji: Geuga bujailjieonjeong, pyeongso-e aju jeolyaghamyeon seubgwan-i issda.
examples.en: Even though he is rich, he has a habit of being very thrifty on regular days.

examples.kr: 영희가 이길지언정, 철수는 최선을 다했다.
examples.romaji: Yeong-heega igiljieonjeong, Cheolsuneun choeseoneul dahaessda.
examples.en: Even though Young-hee won, Cheolsu did his best.

examples.kr: 그 공원이 아름다울지언정, 저녁에는 위험이 많으니 조심하세요.
examples.romaji: Geu gong-woni aleumdauljieonjeong, jeonyeogeneun wihemi manh-euni joshimhaseyo.
examples.en: Despite that park being beautiful, it is dangerous in the evening, so be careful.

title: ~이나 [ina] (Or, whether)
short_explanation: Used to indicate choice, alternative, or uncertainty; 'or', 'whether'.
long_explanation: '~이나 [ina]' is a conjunction used in Korean to indicate alternatives, choices or uncertainties. Functioning similarly to 'or' in English, it allows for offering or mentioning different options or possibilities, even if uncertain. '~이나 [ina]' is typically used post-verb or post-adjective, especially in questions, to represent the concept of 'whether' or 'if'.

examples.kr: 집에 있을까요, 아니면 바깥에 나갔을까요?
examples.romaji: Jib-e iss-eulkka yo, animyeon baggat-e nagass-eulkka yo?
examples.en: Are they at home, or did they go out?

examples.kr: 사과이나 오렌지, 그 중 하나만 골라주세요.
examples.romaji: Sagwa ina orenji, geu jung hanaman gollajuseyo.
examples.en: Please choose either an apple or an orange.

examples.kr: 오늘 비가 올까요, 아니면 눈이 올까요?
examples.romaji: Oneul biga olkkayo, animyeon nun-i olkkayo?
examples.en: Will it rain today, or will it snow?

examples.kr: 이번 주말에 쉬러 갈까요, 아니면 일을 계속 할까요?
examples.romaji: Ibeon jumal-e swi leo galkkayo, animyeon il-eul gyesok halkkayo?
examples.en: Should we rest this weekend, or should we continue to work?

title: ~이든 [ideun] (Either or)
short_explanation: Used to present two or more choices; 'either', 'or'.
long_explanation: '~이든 [ideun]' is a connecting ending used in Korean to present two or more alternatives or choices. It is analogous to 'either', 'or' in English. It's commonly used when the speaker doesn't care about which choice is chosen and all the options presented are equally acceptable.

examples.kr: 피자든 파스타든 무엇을 먹어도 좋아요, 둘 다 맛있으니까요.
examples.romaji: Pijadeun pasteudeun mueoseul meogeodo joayo, dul da masisseunikka yo.
examples.en: Either pizza or pasta, anything is good to eat because they both are delicious.

examples.kr: 운동이든 요가든 모든 활동이 건강에 좋아요.
examples.romaji: Undongideun yogadeun modeun hwaldongi geongange joayo.
examples.en: Either exercise or yoga, all activities are good for health.

examples.kr: 친구들하고 영화보기이든, 책을 읽는 것이든 저는 행복해요.
examples.romaji: Chingudeulhago yeonghwabogideun, chaeg eul ilgneun geosideun jeoneun haengboakhaeyo.
examples.en: Either watching movies with friends, or reading a book, I am happy.

examples.kr: 떡볶이이든, 부대찌개든 저는 둘다 좋아하는 음식입니다.
examples.romaji: Tteokbokkiideun, budaejjigaedeun jeoneun duldaneun joahaneun eumsigibnida.
examples.en: Either tteokbokki or budae jjigae, both are foods that I like.

title: ~이라도 [irado] (At least, even if)
short_explanation: Used to express 'at least', 'even if'; refers to a minimum or lesser expectation.
long_explanation: The '~이라도 [irado]' grammar point is used in Korean to express a minimum expectation or lesser alternative when the preferred or better option isn't available. It conjures a sense of conceding to less desirable options or scenarios, akin to 'at least' or 'even if' in English. This grammar point if often used in situations where the speaker is trying to propose or suggest a less ideal option when faced with significant challenges or obstacles.

examples.kr: 이 작은 선물이라도 받아주세요. 저는 더 좋은 선물을 줄 수 없어요.
examples.romaji: I jageun seonmurirado badajuseyo. Jeoneun deo joheun seonmureul jul su eobseoyo.
examples.en: Please accept this small gift at least. I can't give a better gift.

examples.kr: 미안하다고 말이라도 해 줬으면 좋겠어요.
examples.romaji: Mianhadago marirado hae jwosseumyeon johgesseoyo.
examples.en: I wish you would at least say you're sorry.

examples.kr: 비록 그녀가 나를 싫어한다 해도, 친구로서라도 계속 만나고 싶어요.
examples.romaji: Birok geunyeoga nareul sirheohanda haedo, chinguroseorado gyesok mannago sippeoyo.
examples.en: Even if she dislikes me, I want to keep seeing her, at least as friends.

examples.kr: 신발은 원하는 색깔이 없으니까, 흰 색이라도 사겠어요.
examples.romaji: Sinbareun wonhaneun saekkkari eobseunikka, huin saekirado sa gesseoyo.
examples.en: I will buy the white ones at least, since the shoes don't come in the color I want.

title: ~이라는 것 [iraneun geot] (The thing called)
short_explanation: This phrase is used to make reference to, or to define something previously mentioned
long_explanation: '~이라는 것 [iraneun geot]' is a Korean sentence structure use to make reference to a certain thing or idea, or to define something that was previously mentioned. It is generally used in explanatory situations, giving the speaker the means to elaborate on a concept, provide a definition or highlight certain attributes or characteristics.

examples.kr: 사랑이라는 것이 어떤 것인지, 많은 사람들이 꼭 알고 싶어 하는 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Sarangiraneun geosi eotteon geotinji, maneun saramdeuli ggog algo sip-eo haneun geot gat-ayo.
examples.en: It seems like many people really want to know what this thing called love is.

examples.kr: 성공이라는 것은 많은 노력과 헌신 없이는 이루어질 수 없는 것입니다.
examples.romaji: Seonggongiraneun geoseun maneun noryeokgwa heonsin eobsineun irueojil su eobsneun geosibnida.
examples.en: Success, the thing called, cannot be achieved without a lot of effort and dedication.

examples.kr: 행복이라는 것은 개인마다 다른 의미를 갖고 있기 때문에 정의하기가 어렵습니다.
examples.romaji: Haengbogiraneun geoseun gaenmada dareun uimireul gajgo issgie ttaemune jeonguihagiga eoryeopseumnida.
examples.en: It's difficult to define happiness as it holds different meanings for each individual.

examples.kr: 배려라는 것은 자신의 행동이 다른 사람에게 어떤 영향을 미치는지 고려하는 것입니다.
examples.romaji: Baerylaneun geoseun jasinui haengdong-i daleun salam-ege eotteon yeonghyang-eul michineunji golyeohaneun geosibnida.
examples.en: Consideration, the thing we refer to as, is considering how one's actions might affect others.

title: ~이라면 [iramyeon] (If it's the case that)
short_explanation: Used to imagine a certain situation; 'if it's the case that'.
long_explanation: '~이라면 [iramyeon]' is a conjugation used in Korean to pose a hypothetical scenario or situation. It is akin to 'if it's the case that' in English. It can be used to speculate about the consequences or outcomes of a specific condition or situation, often expressing uncertainty before conjecturing about something.

examples.kr: 여기가 정말로 유명한 관광 명소라면, 왜 이렇게 사람이 없나요?
examples.romaji: Yeogiga jeongmallo yumyeonghan gwangwangmyeongso-iramyeon, wae ireohge sarami eomnayo?
examples.en: If this is really a famous tourist spot, why are there so few people?

examples.kr: 정말로 그런 일이 있다면, 어떻게 대처해야 할지 고민해봐야겠어요.
examples.romaji: Jeongmallo geureon iri itdamyeon, eotteohge daecheohaeya halji gominhae bwayagesseoyo.
examples.en: If such a thing really happens, I will have to think about how to deal with it.

examples.kr: 학교를 그만두고 싶다면, 미래를 어떻게 설계할지 생각해봐야 할 거에요.
examples.romaji: Hakgyoreul geumandugo sipdamyeon, miraereul eotteohge seolgyehalji saenggakhae bwayahal geo eyeo.
examples.en: If you want to quit school, you should think about how to plan your future.

examples.kr: 니가 내 친구라면, 왜 나를 배신하고 다른 친구들에게 나쁜 이야기를 퍼뜨렸나요?
examples.romaji: Niga nae chingura myeon, wae nareul baesinhago dareun chingudeulege nappeun iyagireul peodeut leossnayo?
examples.en: If you are my friend, why did you betray me and spread bad stories to other friends?

title: ~이래 [irae] (Like this, in this manner)
short_explanation: Used to express 'like this' or 'in this manner'. It can be used to refer to a present status or situation and also to refer directly to what the speaker is doing.
long_explanation: '~이래 [irae]' is used in Korean to talk about a certain status, condition, or behaviour of someone or something. This grammar point is usually used with a noun before it to describe 'in this way' or 'like this'. It gives emphasis to the specific way or manner in how something is done or exists. It can be used to refer to the current status or situation, and also to the speaker's own condition or action. It usually comes before the verb in a sentence.

examples.kr: 날씨가 이래서는 놀러갈 수가 없어요.
examples.romaji: Nalssiga iraeseoneun nolleogal suga eobseoyo.
examples.en: We can't go out to play when the weather is like this.

examples.kr: 내가 이래 봐서는 유명해질 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Naega irae bwaseoneun yumyeonghaejil geot gatayo.
examples.en: If I keep it up like this, I think I'll become famous.

examples.kr: 이 집이 이래서는 팔 수가 없어.
examples.romaji: I jibi iraeseoneun pal suga eobseo.
examples.en: We can't sell the house when it's like this.

examples.kr: 자네가 이래서는 운동선수로 출중한 성과를 이룰 수 있을 것 같군.
examples.romaji: Janaega iraeseoneun undongseonsuro chuljung han seonggwareul irul su isseul geot gatgun.
examples.en: If you keep it up like this, you can achieve outstanding results as an athlete.

title: ~이랑 [irang] (And, with)
short_explanation: Used to connect two nouns, expressing 'and' or 'with'.
long_explanation: '~이랑 [irang]' is a commonly used connector in Korean language, serving a similar function to 'and' or 'with' in English. It is used to join two nouns together, showing a connection or a relationship between the two. It can be used in all types of sentences, irrespective of the politeness level or sentence type.

examples.kr: 저는 친구이랑 같이 영화를 보러 갈 계획이에요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun chinguirang gachi yeonghwaleul boreo gal gyehoegieyo.
examples.en: I plan to go see a movie with my friend.

examples.kr: 우리는 피자이랑 치킨을 주문했어요.
examples.romaji: Urineun pijairang chicken-eul jumunhaesseoyo.
examples.en: We ordered pizza and chicken.

examples.kr: 저는 언니이랑 쇼핑몰에서 옷을 샀어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun eonniirang syopingmol-eseo oseul sasseoyo.
examples.en: I bought clothes at the shopping mall with my sister.

examples.kr: 나는 고양이이랑 개를 키우고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun goyangiirang gaereul giugo isseoyo.
examples.en: I am raising a cat and a dog.

title: ~이러하다 [ireohada] (Like this)
short_explanation: Used to describe the state or condition of a subject as 'like this', representative of the situation.
long_explanation: '~이러하다 [ireohada]' is used primarily as a descriptive verb in Korean to express a thing, person or situation as 'being like this'. There is an emphasis on the current state or condition of the subject or scenario. This form can be used to illustrate an example or condition and can often be seen in statements about someone's state, behaviors, or habits.

examples.kr: 친구가 너무 지각해서 저는 이러하게 기다리게 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Chinguga neomu jigakhaeseo jeoneun ireohage gidarige doe-eosseoyo.
examples.en: Because my friend was so late, I ended up waiting like this.

examples.kr: 세상이 이러하게 변해버리다니, 믿을 수 없어요.
examples.romaji: Sesangi ireohage byeonhaebeoridani, mideul su eopseoyo.
examples.en: I can't believe the world has changed like this.

examples.kr: 그녀가 나를 이러하게 만들어버렸어요. 그녀 없이 울게 만들었어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoga nareul ireohage mandeureobeoryeosseoyo. Geunyeo eobsi ulge mandeureosseoyo.
examples.en: She made me like this. She made me cry without her.

examples.kr: 그가 이러하게 거짓말을 하다니, 정말 기가 막혔어요.
examples.romaji: Geuga ireohage geojismareul hadani, jeongmal giga makhyeosseoyo.
examples.en: I was really shocked that he could lie like this.

title: ~이런/그런/저런 [ireon/geureon/jeoreon] (This kind of/That kind of/That kind over there)
short_explanation: Used to describe the type or category of something; 'this kind of', 'that kind of', 'that kind over there'.
long_explanation: ~이런/그런/저런 [ireon/geureon/jeoreon] are demonstrative adjectives used in Korean to classify or describe things according to their type or category. '이런' is akin to 'this kind of' in English, '그런' to 'that kind of', and '저런' to 'that kind of over there'. These adjectives are used to refer to, clarify, or distinguish certain types of things or situations based on their proximity to the speaker or listener.

examples.kr: 이런 상황에서는 어떻게 대처해야 할 지 모르겠어요.
examples.romaji: Ireon sanghwang-eseoneun eotteohge daecheohaeya halji moreugesseoyo.
examples.en: I don't know how to deal with this kind of situation.

examples.kr: 그런 분위기를 좋아하지 않아요.
examples.romaji: Geureon bunwigireul johahaji anhayo.
examples.en: I don't like that kind of atmosphere.

examples.kr: 저런 옷을 입으면 어떻게 생각할까요?
examples.romaji: Jeoreon ot-eul ib-eumyeon eotteohge saeng-gaghalggayo?
examples.en: What would you think if I wore that kind of clothes over there?

examples.kr: 이런 생각을 하지 말아야겠어요.
examples.romaji: Ireon saeng-gag-eul haji mal-ayahgesseoyo.
examples.en: I should not think this way.

title: ~이므로 [imuro] (Because, since)
short_explanation: Used to express a reason or cause; 'because', 'since'.
long_explanation: '~이므로 [imuro]' is a conjunction used in Korean to indicate a reason or cause, which corresponds to 'because' or 'since' in English. It typically precedes the conclusion or result caused by the preceding clause. ~이므로 [imuro] is more formal and is typically used in written Korean such as in official documents, academic writing, or news reports.

examples.kr: 내일은 월요일이므로, 오늘 밤에 일찍 잠에 들어야 합니다.
examples.romaji: Naeireun wol-yo-ilimuro, oneul bam-e iljjik jam-e deul-eoya habnida.
examples.en: Because tomorrow is Monday, we have to go to bed early tonight.

examples.kr: 그는 학점이 낮아 교수에게 외자 장학금을 받을 수 없었기 때문에 금전적인 문제가 있었어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun hakjeomi naj-a gyosu-egi oja janghakgeum-eul bad-eul su eobs-eoss-gi ttaemune geumjeonjeog-in munje-ga iss-eoss-eoyo.
examples.en: He had financial difficulties because he had low grades and thus could not receive foreign scholarships from his professor.

examples.kr: 우리는 시간이 없기 때문에, 저녁 식사를 축소해야 합니다.
examples.romaji: Ulineun sigani eobs-gi ttaemune, jeonyeog siksa-leul chugsohaeya habnida.
examples.en: Because we are short of time, we have to cut down on dinner.

examples.kr: 그 직원은 업무능력이 매우 불량이므로, 우리는 그에게 경고를 발했습니다.
examples.romaji: Geu jigwon-eun eobmu neunglyeog-i maeu bullyang-imuro, ulineun geu-ege gyeonggo-leul balhaessseubnida.
examples.en: We issued a warning to the employee because his job performance was very poor.

title: ~이야 [iya] (Is, informal declaration)
short_explanation: '~이야' is used as an informal, casual way to state or declare something.
long_explanation: '~이야' is a verb modifier in Korean utilized to assert, declare or express a fact, situation or feeling in an informal or casual context. It attaches to the stem of a verb or adjective and can be used either in positive or negative sentences. It is very commonly used in daily conservation among close friends or people of similar age. It is not advisable to use it with elders or superiors as it may sound rude or disrespectful.

examples.kr: 나는 배가 고프다고 생각했더니 아니었어, 김밥을 사 왔어, 이제 배가 고프지 않아.
examples.romaji: Naneun baega gopeudago saenggakhaetdeoni anieosseo, gimbabeul sa wass-eo, ije baega gopeuji anha.
examples.en: I thought I was hungry, but I wasn't, I bought gimbap, now I'm not hungry.

examples.kr: 오늘 날씨가 참 좋아, 하늘이 맑고 파란 하늘이 보여
examples.romaji: Oneul nalssiga cham joa, haneuli malggo paran haneuli boyeo
examples.en: The weather is really nice today, you can see the clear, blue sky

examples.kr: 여기가 내 집이야, 조금 작지만 아늑하고 편안해
examples.romaji: Yeogiga nae jib-iya, jogeum jagjiman aneugago pyeonanhae
examples.en: This is my house, it's small but cozy and comfortable

examples.kr: 너가 진짜로 좋아하는 거야, 말해 줘서 고마워
examples.romaji: Neoga jinjjaru joahaneun geoya, malhae jweoseo gomawo
examples.en: You're really grateful for telling me what you like

title: ~이지만 [ijiman] (But, although)
short_explanation: Used to convey a contrast or contradiction; 'but', 'although'.
long_explanation: '~이지만 [ijiman]' is a phrase used in Korean to indicate a contrast or contradiction between two statements or facts. It is similar to 'but' or 'although' in English. Despite the situation or condition presented in the first clause, the information in the second clause transpires or is still valid. In casual contexts, '-지만 [jiman]' can also be used on its own.

examples.kr: 평소에 드라마를 잘 안 보는 편이지만 이 드라마는 흥미로워서 꼭 봐야겠어요.
examples.romaji: Pyeongsoe deurameureul jal an boneun pyeonijiman i deurameuneun heungmirowoseo ggok bwayagesseoyo.
examples.en: I usually don't watch dramas, but this drama is so interesting that I must watch it.

examples.kr: 오늘 날씨가 좋지만 바쁘서 나가지 못할 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Oneul nalssiga joijiman bappeoseo nagaji mothael geo gatayo.
examples.en: The weather is good today, but I think I won't be able to go out because I'm busy.

examples.kr: 당신은 젊지만 이미 많은 경험을 가지고 있네요.
examples.romaji: Dangsineun jeolmjiman imi maneun gyeongheomeul gajigo itneyo.
examples.en: You are young, but you already have a lot of experience.

examples.kr: 제가 팀장이지만 모든 결정을 혼자서 하지는 않아요.
examples.romaji: Jega timjangijiman modeun gyeoljeongeul honjaseo hajineun anhayo.
examples.en: I am the team leader, but I don't make all the decisions by myself.

title: ~이후 [ihu] (After, since)
short_explanation: Used to express the meaning of 'after' or 'since'.
long_explanation: '~이후 [ihu]' is a postposition used in Korean to indicate the time after a specific point or event. It corresponds to 'after' or 'since' in English. It is commonly used in Korean language to convey the meaning of 'since then' or 'after that time'. It is often used to refer to a future time period or an occurrence after a certain event or situation.

examples.kr: 중학교 졸업 이후로 처음으로 친구들과 모였어요.
examples.romaji: Jung hakgyo jol eob ihuro cheoeum euro chingu deul gwa moyeosseoyo.
examples.en: This is the first time I've gathered with my friends since graduating from middle school.

examples.kr: 그녀가 도시에 이사 간 이후로 그녀를 본 적이 없어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeo ga dosi e isa gan ihuro geunyeo reul bon jeogi eobseoyo.
examples.en: I haven't seen her since she moved to the city.

examples.kr: 아침 식사 이후로 아무것도 먹지 않았어요.
examples.romaji: Achim siksa ihuro amugeosdo meokji anhasseoyo.
examples.en: I haven't eaten anything since breakfast.

examples.kr: 회의 이후로 사무실에서 일을 계속하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Hoeui ihuro samusireseo ireul gyesokhago isseoyo.
examples.en: I've been continuing my work in the office since the meeting.

title: ~인즉 [injeuk] (In other words, that is to say)
short_explanation: Used to rephrase or further explain a preceding statement; 'in other words', 'that is to say'.
long_explanation: '~인즉 [injeuk]' is a connective ending in Korean used to rephrase or further explain a preceding statement or idea. It is used when the speaker feels a need to provide more clarity or details to the listener, similar to 'In other words' or 'That is to say' in English. This phrase allows the speaker to elaborate their thoughts in a different way to ensure understanding.

examples.kr: 이 작업이 정말 어려워요, 인즉, 전문가가 아니면 제대로 해낼 수 없습니다.
examples.romaji: I jak-eob-i jeongmal eol-eowoyo, injeug, jeonmunga-ga animyeon jedaelo hael su eobs-seubnida.
examples.en: This task is really hard, in other words, if you're not an expert, you can't do it properly.

examples.kr: 그녀는 내일 결혼합니다, 인즉, 그녀는 더 이상 독신이 아니다.
examples.romaji: Geunyeo-neun naeil gyeolhonhabnida, injeug, geunyeo-neun deo isang dongsin-i anida.
examples.en: She is getting married tomorrow, that is to say, she is no longer single.

examples.kr: 박물관 직원은 저를 입장하게 허락하지 않았습니다. 인즉, 저는 규정을 위반했습니다.
examples.romaji: Bakmulgwan jik-won-eun jeoleul ibjanghage heolak haji anhassseubnida. injeug, jeoneun gyujeong-eul wibanhaessseubnida.
examples.en: The museum staff did not allow me to enter, in other words, I violated the rules.

examples.kr: 우리는 연구에 참여하였습니다, 인즉, 우리는 어떤 학문적인 기여를 했습니다.
examples.romaji: Ulineun yeongu-e cham-yeohayeossseubnida, injeug, ulineun eotteon hakmunjeogin giyeoleul hayeossseubnida.
examples.en: We participated in the research, in other words, we have made some academic contribution.

title: ~자 [ja] (Let's)
short_explanation: Used to propose doing something; 'Let's'.
long_explanation: '~자 [ja]' is an ending particle in Korean used to make a suggestion or a proposal about doing an action together. It loosely corresponds to 'Let's' in English. This form is often used in informal or casual contexts and is generally used among friends, colleagues or family members. The subject is often omitted when using this form and the verb before ~자 is always in its dictionary or base form.

examples.kr: 날씨가 너무 좋으니까, 우리 산에 등산하러 가자.
examples.romaji: Nalssiga neomu jo-eunikka, uri sane deungsanhareo gaja.
examples.en: The weather is so good, let's go mountain climbing.

examples.kr: 오늘이 일요일이므로, 교회에 가서 기도하자.
examples.romaji: Oneuli ilyo-irimyeo, gyohoee gaseo gidohaja.
examples.en: Since today is Sunday, let's go to church and pray.

examples.kr: 밥은 다먹었으니, 이제 커피 한 잔 마시러 카페에 가자.
examples.romaji: Babeun dameogeoss-euni, ije keopi han jan masileo kapee gaja.
examples.en: Now that we're done eating, let's go to the cafe and have a cup of coffee.

examples.kr: 길고 지루한 하루였으니, 이제 보드게임 하나 플레이하며 편히 쉬자.
examples.romaji: Gilgo jiruhan haru-yeoss-euni, ije bodeugeim hana peulleihameo pyeonhi shija.
examples.en: It's been a long and boring day, let's relax by playing a board game now.

title: ~자마자 [jamaja] (As soon as)
short_explanation: Used to express the immediate occurrence of a second event or action after the first one.
long_explanation: The '~자마자 [jamaja]' grammar point is used to emphasize that an action or event occurred immediately after the previous action or event. It translates to 'as soon as' in English. It typically implies a close temporal relationship between two actions, with the action marked by '~자마자' happening right after the other one.

examples.kr: 저는 집에 돌아오자마자 식사를 준비했어요, 왜냐하면 너무 배고파서 바로 음식을 먹고 싶었기 때문이에요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun jibe doraojamaja siksa를 junbihaesseoyo, waenyahamyeon neomu baegopaseo baro eumsigeul meokgo sipheossgi ttaemunieyo.
