examples.en: As soon as I returned home, I prepared a meal, because I was so hungry and wanted to eat right away.

examples.kr: 엄마가 전화를 끊자마자 잠을 청하러 갔어요, 어제는 너무 늦게 잠들었기 때문에 기분이 피곤했어요.
examples.romaji: Eommaga jeonhwareul kkeunhjamaja jameul cheonghareo gasseoyo, eojeoneun neomu neutge jamdeureossgi ttaemune gibuni pigonhaesseoyo.
examples.en: As soon as mom hung up the phone, I went to sleep, because I was tired as I went to bed too late yesterday.

examples.kr: 그는 일어나자마자 커피를 마셔요, 그는 아침에 커피 없이 일을 시작할 수 없다고 말해요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun ireonajamaja keopireul masyeoyo, geuneun achime keopi eobsi ireul sijakhal su eobsdagohaeyo.
examples.en: As soon as he wakes up, he drinks coffee, saying he cannot start work without coffee in the morning.

examples.kr: 비가 오자마자 우산을 들고 도서관에 갔어요, 왜냐하면 수업 자료를 찾기로 결정했기 때문이에요.
examples.romaji: Biga ojamaja usaneul deulgo doseogwane gasseoyo, waenyahamyeon sueop jaryoreul chajgiro gyeoljeonghaetggi ttaemunieyo.
examples.en: As soon as it started raining, I went to the library with an umbrella, because I decided to look for class materials.

title: ~전에/전까지 [jeone/jeonkkaji] (Before/by the time of)
short_explanation: Used to indicate an action or state that will/was completed or occurring before a specific time.
long_explanation: '~전에 [jeone]' and '전까지 [jeonkkaji]' are both used in Korean to denote the completion of some action or state before a specified time or event. '~전에 [jeone]' is used when the action or state is not ongoing beyond the mentioned time, while '전까지 [jeonkkaji]' is used when the action or state continues up to the specified time.

examples.kr: 저는 학교에 가기 전에 아침을 먹어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun hakgyoe gagi jeone achimeul meogeo.
examples.en: I eat breakfast before going to school.

examples.kr: 그녀는 출근하기 전까지 연락할게요. 아마 연락 올 때까지 기다리세요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun chulgukhagi jeonkkaji yeollakhalkkeyo. Ama yeollak ol ttaekkaji gidariseyo.
examples.en: She will contact you before going to work. Please wait until she contacts you.

examples.kr: 기차가 도착하기 전에 짐을 싸야해요.
examples.romaji: Gichaga dochakhagi jeone jimeul ssayahae.
examples.en: We have to pack our luggage before the train arrives.

examples.kr: 우리가 집에 돌아오기 전까지 조심하세요.
examples.romaji: Uriga jibe dorao gikkkaji joshimhaseyo.
examples.en: Take care until we return home.

title: ~정도 [jeongdo] (About, Approximately)
short_explanation: Used to express approximation or manner; 'about', 'approximately'.
long_explanation: '~정도 [jeongdo]' is a particle used in Korean to indicate an approximate quantity, amount, degree, level, or extent of something. It conveys a sense of approximation akin to 'about' or 'approximately' in English. It is often used in conversations when you are not sure about the exact quantity or amount and want to give an estimated or rough idea.

examples.kr: 이 문제를 해결하는 데는 한 시간쯤 정도 걸릴 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: I munjeleul haegyolhaneun dedeun han siganjjeum jeongdo geollil geot gatayo.
examples.en: It is expected to take about an hour or so to solve this problem.

examples.kr: 진짜로 영화를 봤다면 네 시간 정도가 걸렸을 것이에요.
examples.romaji: Jinjjalo yeonghwaleul bwatdamyeon ne sigan jeongdoge geollyeosseul geosieyo.
examples.en: If you really watched the movie, it would have taken about four hours.

examples.kr: 이 과제를 완료하려면 한 달 정도의 시간이 필요합니다.
examples.romaji: I gwajeleul wanlyohamyeon han dal jeongdoeui sigani pilyohabnida.
examples.en: Completing this assignment requires about a month's time.

examples.kr: 그의 성과를 평가하려면 최소한 10가지 이상의 요소를 고려해야 하고, 이것은 대략 한 시간 정도의 시간을 요구합니다.
examples.romaji: Geuui seonggwareul pyeonggahamyeon choesohwan 10gaji isangui yosoreul goleohaeya hago, igeoseun daerak han sigan jeongdoeui siganeul yoguhabnida.
examples.en: To evaluate his performance requires considering at least 10 or more factors, and this requires approximately an hour of time.

title: ~제 [je] (Although, even if)
short_explanation: Used to express 'although', 'even if'. It signifies that despite the preceding situation or condition, the outcome differs than expected.
long_explanation: '~제 [je]' is a conjunction that is used in Korean to express opposition or contrasting concepts, similar to 'although', 'even if', 'even though' in English. It is used when the actual result or situation contradicts the expected result that follows certain situations, conditions, or assumptions. Its function is similar to '-지만' but it's used in more formal or polite mood.

examples.kr: 그녀가 아프제 일을 계속했어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoga apeuje ireul gyesokhayesseoyo.
examples.en: Although she was sick, she continued to work.

examples.kr: 동생이 어리제 그에게 맡길 수 있는 일이 많아요.
examples.romaji: Dongsaengi eorije geuege matgil su issneun iri manhayo.
examples.en: Even though my younger sibling is young, there are many tasks I can entrust to him.

examples.kr: 비가 내리제 나는 외출했어요.
examples.romaji: Biga naerije naneun weochulhayesseoyo.
examples.en: Even though it was raining, I went out.

examples.kr: 시험 문제가 어렵제 제가 좋아하는 공부였기 때문에 재미있게 풀었어요.
examples.romaji: Siheom munjega eoryeopje jega joahaneun gongbuyeossgi ttaemune jaemiissge pulleosseoyo.
examples.en: Even though the test questions were difficult, since it was a subject I liked, I enjoyed solving it.

title: ~조차 [jocha] (Even)
short_explanation: This grammar point expresses the meaning 'even' or 'to the extent that'.
long_explanation: '~조차 [jocha]' is used in Korean to emphasizes a situation or circumstance where something is considered to the degree or extent that it even includes the thing being stated. It reinforces the degree of something and is used to show the maximum limit or strong emphasis, conveying a sense of surprise and unexpectedness.

examples.kr: 그는 돈조차 너무 좋아해서 친구들에게 돈을 빌려주지 않아요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun donjocha neomu joahaseo chingudeurege doneul billyeojugi anhayo.
examples.en: He likes money so much that he doesn't even lend money to his friends.

examples.kr: 저는 이번 주말에는 집에서 나가는 것조차 귀찮아요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun ibeon jumaleneun jibeseo naganeun geotjocha gwicheonhayo.
examples.en: This weekend, I even find going out of the house annoying.

examples.kr: 이번 시험은 너무 어려워서 문제를 읽는 것조차 어려웠어요.
examples.romaji: Ibeon siheomeun neomu eoryeowoseo munjeleul ilgneun geotjocha eoryeowosseoyo.
examples.en: This exam was so hard that even reading the problems was difficult.

examples.kr: 가게에 사람이 너무 많아서 메뉴를 선택하는 것조차 힘들었어요.
examples.romaji: Gagee sarami neomu manaseo menyureul seontaekhaneun geotjocha himdeureosseoyo.
examples.en: There were so many people in the store that even choosing the menu was difficult.

title: ~존재하다 [jonjaehada] (To exist)
short_explanation: '존재하다' is used to express the existence of something or someone.
long_explanation: '존재하다 [jonjaehada]' is a Korean verb that indicates the existence or presence of someone or something. This verb could be used in various instances, such as expressing whether a thing or a person is currently present or exists, or even for abstract concepts like expressing the existence of hope, ideas, problems, etc. When conjugated into its present form, it becomes '존재해요.'

examples.kr: 영화 속에 존재하는 그런 판타지 세계가 현실에서도 존재하길 바래요.
examples.romaji: Yeonghwa soge jonjaehaneun geureon pantaji segaega hyeonsil-eseodo jonjaehagil baraeyo.
examples.en: I hope that such a fantasy world existing in the movie also exists in reality.

examples.kr: 사랑이 과연 영원히 존재하는 건지 모르겠어요.
examples.romaji: Sarangi gwayeon yeongwonhi jonjaehaneun geonji moreugesseoyo.
examples.en: I am not sure if love really exists forever.

examples.kr: 이 세상에 완벽한 사람이 존재하는지 의심스러워요.
examples.romaji: I sesange wanbyeokhan sarami jonjaehaneunji uisimseurewoyo.
examples.en: I doubt that a perfect person exists in this world.

examples.kr: 이 방에는 저 말고 다른 사람들이 존재하지 않아요.
examples.romaji: I bangeun jeo malgo dareun saramdeuli jonjaehaji anhayo.
examples.en: Except for me, no other people exist in this room.

title: ~줄 알다 [jul alda] (Thought that)
short_explanation: '~줄 알다' is used to express the speaker's incorrect assumption or expectation about something.
long_explanation: '~줄 알다' is a Korean grammar pattern used when the speaker had a certain assumption or expectation about a situation, but the actual outcome was different, i.e., the speaker was mistaken or the expectation did not come true. It expresses a sense of surprise or disappointment about the mismatch between expectation and reality. It can be translated as 'I thought that...' in English.

examples.kr: 날씨가 좋을 줄 알았는데, 갑자기 비가 와서 실망했어요.
examples.romaji: Nalssiga joheul jul alatneunde, gapjagi biga waseo shilmanghaesseoyo.
examples.en: I thought the weather would be nice, but it suddenly started raining and I was disappointed.

examples.kr: 그 사람이 나를 좋아할 줄 알았는데, 아니었어요.
examples.romaji: Geu sarami nareul joahal jul alatneunde, anieosseoyo.
examples.en: I thought that person liked me, but that was not the case.

examples.kr: 시험 문제가 어려울 줄 알았는데, 생각보다 쉬웠어요.
examples.romaji: Siheom munjega eoryeoul jul alatneunde, saenggakboda swiweosseoyo.
examples.en: I thought the test questions would be difficult, but they were easier than I thought.

examples.kr: 진행이 늦을 줄 알았는데, 빨리 끝났어요.
examples.romaji: Jinhaengi neujeul jul alatneunde, ppalli kkeutnasseoyo.
examples.en: I thought the proceedings would be slow, but they ended quickly.

title: ~즉시 [jeukshi] (Immediately, at once)
short_explanation: Used to express 'immediately' or 'as soon as'.
long_explanation: '~즉시 [jeukshi]' is a compound noun in Korean, which is used to express the meaning of doing something immediately or right away after a certain situation or event. It means 'as soon as' or 'the moment when' and generally follows a noun or verb. It stresses the immediacy of the action that follows after a preceding event.

examples.kr: 그녀가 방에 들어오자마자 저는 그녀에게 선물을 주려고 했지만, 그녀가 들어올 즉시 얘기하고 싶어했던 것을 깜빡했어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoga bange deuleoojamaja jeoneun geunyeoege seonmureul juryeogo haessjiman, geunyeoga deureool jeukshi yaegihago sipheossdeon geoseul kkamppaghaessdeoyo.
examples.en: As soon as she came into the room, I wanted to give her a gift, but the moment she came in, I forgot what I wanted to say.

examples.kr: 메시지를 받자마자 즉시 반응해야 합니다, 아니면 그 사람은 기다리게 됩니다.
examples.romaji: Mesijireul batjamaja jeukshi baneunghaeya habnida, animyeon geu sarameun gidarige doebnida.
examples.en: You should respond immediately as soon as you receive a message, otherwise that person will be left waiting.

examples.kr: 그날 밤, 그녀가 보고서를 완료하면 즉시 체크하였다.
examples.romaji: Geunal bam, geunyeoga bogoseoreul wanryohamyeon jeukshi chekeuhaessda.
examples.en: That night, he checked as soon as she finished her report.

examples.kr: 회의가 끝나자마자 즉시 사진을 찍으러 갔어요.
examples.romaji: Hoeuiga kkeutnajamaja jeukshi sajineul jjigeureo gasseoyo.
examples.en: I went to take a picture immediately as soon as the meeting was over.

title: ~지 않다 [ji anta] (Negative form)
short_explanation: Negates the action implied by the verb in the sentence; equivalent to 'not' in English.
long_explanation: The grammar point '~지 않다 [ji anta]' is the standard and polite way to convert a verb into its negative form in Korean. It negates the verb, which means it changes the meaning of the verb into 'not doing' the action. The negative verb form is made by attaching '지 않다' at the end of the verb stem. This is mostly used in polite or formal speech, but can also be used in casual conversations.

examples.kr: 나는 오늘 학교에 가지 않았어요, 왜냐하면 비가 너무 많이 와서 출근이 불가능했어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun oneul hakgyoe gaji anhasseoyo, waenyahamyeon biga neomu mani wasseo chulgeuni bulganeunghaesseoyo.
examples.en: I did not go to school today, because it rained so much that it was impossible to go out.

examples.kr: 저는 일반적으로 고기를 먹지 않아요, 왜냐하면 나는 채식주의자이기 때문입니다.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun ilbanjeogeuro gogireul meokji anhayo, waenyahamyeon naneun chaesikjuuijaigi ttaemunibnida.
examples.en: I generally do not eat meat, because I am a vegetarian.

examples.kr: 민지는 그 영화를 보지 않았어요, 왜냐하면 그녀는 그것이 너무 무서워하기 때문입니다.
examples.romaji: Minjineun geu yeonghwareul boji anhasseoyo, waenyahamyeon geunyeoneun geugeosi neomu museowohagi ttaemunibnida.
examples.en: Minji did not watch that movie, because she finds it too scary.

examples.kr: 그들은 내 생일 파티에 오지 않았어요, 왜냐하면 그들은 바빴기 때문입니다.
examples.romaji: Geudeureun nae saengil patie oji anhasseoyo, waenyahamyeon geudeureun bappatgi ttaemunibnida.
examples.en: They did not come to my birthday party because they were busy.

title: ~지 않아도 되다 [ji anado dweda] (Do not have to)
short_explanation: Used to imply that something does not have to be done.
long_explanation: '~지 않아도 되다 [ji anado dweda]' is a Korean grammar point used when you want to say that you 'do not have to' do something, or something 'doesn't have to be' a certain way. The emphasis here is on the optional nature of some action or state, communicating there is no obligation, necessity, or requirement for it.

examples.kr: 너무 걱정하지 않아도 돼, 모든 것이 잘 될 거야.
examples.romaji: Neomu geokjeonghaji anado dwae, modeun geosi jal doel geoya.
examples.en: You don't have to worry too much, everything will be ok.

examples.kr: 지금 당장 먹지 않아도 돼, 나중에 먹어도 괜찮아.
examples.romaji: Jigeum dangjang meokji anado dwae, najunge meogeodo gwaenchanha.
examples.en: You don't have to eat right now, you can eat later.

examples.kr: 다른 사람들이 하는 것을 따라하지 않아도 돼, 너 자신을 믿어.
examples.romaji: Dareun saramdeuli haneun geoseul ttarahaji anado dwae, neo jasineul mideo.
examples.en: You don't have to follow what others are doing, believe in yourself.

examples.kr: 어디로 가지 않아도 돼, 집에서 편하게 쉬어.
examples.romaji: Eodiro gaji anado dwae, jibeseo pyeonhage swieo.
examples.en: You don't have to go anywhere, just rest comfortably at home.

title: ~지 않을까 [ji anheulkka] (Perhaps)
short_explanation: Used to express a conjecture, a guess or a supposition; 'perhaps', 'maybe'
long_explanation: '지 않을까 [ji anheulkka]' is a common ending form in Korean language used to express educated guesses or predictions. Somewhat similar to 'perhaps', 'I wonder if...', 'maybe', or 'probably' in English, the speaker uses it when they can't be sure about something, but it's their best guess based on the information they have.

examples.kr: 오늘 밤에 비가 오지 않을까 싶어요, 하늘이 완전히 회색이니까.
examples.romaji: Oneul bame biga oji anheulkka sip-eoyo, haneuli wanjeonhi hoesaeginikka.
examples.en: I think it might rain tonight, since the sky is completely gray.

examples.kr: 그녀가 내 생각을 하지 않을까 궁금해요, 오랜만에 만났으니까.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoga nae saeng-gag-eul haji anheulkka gung-geumhaeyo, olaenman-e mannat-eunikka.
examples.en: I wonder if she is thinking about me because we met after a very long time.

examples.kr: 내일 시험이 취소되지 않을까 기대해요, 어제는 너무 늦게 공부했으니까.
examples.romaji: Naeil siheom-i chwisodoedji anh-eulkka gidaehaeyo, eojeneun neomu neujge gongbuhaess-eunikka.
examples.en: I wonder if tomorrow's exam might get canceled, because I stayed up late studying yesterday.

examples.kr: 지금 집에 가면 아빠가 저녁을 만들어 놓지 않을까 생각해요, 오늘은 제 생일이니까.
examples.romaji: Jigeum jib-e gamyeon appaga jeonyeog-eul mandeul-eo nohji anh-eulkka saeng-gaghaeyo, oneul-eun je saeng-il-inikka.
examples.en: I wonder if my dad has made dinner if I go home now because it's my birthday today.

title: ~지만 [jimyeon] (But, however)
short_explanation: Used to express contrast or contradiction; 'but', 'however'.
long_explanation: '~지만 [jimyeon]' is a conjunction used in Korean to express contrast or contradiction. It is akin to 'but' or 'however' in English. It connects two clauses where the second clause presents a contradiction or an unexpected result compared to the first clause. The first clause expresses a situation or condition, and the second clause expresses something contradictory.

examples.kr: 오늘의 날씨는 흐리지만, 기분은 매우 좋아요.
examples.romaji: Oneul-ui nalssineun heulijiman, gibuneun maeu joayo.
examples.en: Even though today's weather is cloudy, I feel very good.

examples.kr: 그 영화는 재미없었지만, 그 배우의 연기는 훌륭했어요.
examples.romaji: Geu yeonghwaneun jaemiopseotjiman, geu baeuui yeongineun hulryunghaesseoyo.
examples.en: Although the movie was not interesting, the actor's performance was great.

examples.kr: 고기를 좋아하지만, 가끔 비건 음식을 먹습니다.
examples.romaji: Gogireul johahajiman, gaggeum bigeon eumsigeul meogseumnida.
examples.en: I like meat, but sometimes I eat vegan food.

examples.kr: 아들은 친절하지만, 때때로 소심해집니다.
examples.romaji: Adeureun chinjeolhajiman, ttaettaero sosimhaejibnida.
examples.en: My son is kind, but sometimes he becomes timid.

title: ~지요 [jiyo] (~right?, isn't it?)
short_explanation: Used to echo or affirm the argument; '~right?', 'isn't it?'.
long_explanation: The ending '~지요 [jiyo]' is used in Korean to echo or affirm the statement preceding it. This is similar to English phrases like 'right?' or 'isn't it?'. The speaker uses this end phrase to seek agreement or affirmation from the person they're speaking to, expecting the listener to agree with their statement or share their point of view. It is usually used in declarative or interrogative sentences, and can be used in both formal and informal language contexts.

examples.kr: 오늘 날씨가 정말 좋지요, 태양이 환하게 빛나고, 바람도 시원하니까요.
examples.romaji: Oneul nalssiga jeongmal jotjiyo, taeyangi hwanhage bitnago, baramdo siwonhnikkayo.
examples.en: The weather today is really nice, right? The sun is shining brightly, and the wind is refreshing.

examples.kr: 새로 오픈한 그 카페의 커피가 맛있지요, 한번 가 볼 만하다고 생각해요.
examples.romaji: Saero openhan geu kapeui keopiga matitjiyo, hanbeon ga bol mandahago saenggakhaeyo.
examples.en: The coffee at the newly opened café is delicious, right? I think it's worth a visit.

examples.kr: 강아지가 정말 귀엽지요, 매일 보고 싶어져요.
examples.romaji: Gangajiga jeongmal gwiyeopjiyo, maeil bogo sipheojyeoyo.
examples.en: The puppy is really cute, right? I want to see it every day.

examples.kr: 우리 아이가 키가 크지요, 아빠를 닮아서 그런 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Uri aiga kiga keutjiyo, appareul dalma-seo geureon geot gatayo.
examples.en: Our child is really tall, right? I think it is because he looks like his father.

title: ~진 않다 [jin anta] (Not really)
short_explanation: This pattern is used when something is not exactly or  not demonstrably true.
long_explanation: The ~진 않다 [jin anta] form is used when describing a condition or situation that is not fully or exactly as described by the adjective or verb preceding it. It is the equivalent of the English expressions 'not really', 'not quite', 'not necessarily', or 'not exactly'. The level of denial in this form is weaker than in the standard negative form and often used when the speaker doesn't want to fully agree or disagree.

examples.kr: 그 곳은 많이 더워지진 않지만, 여름에는 항상 습해요.
examples.romaji: Geu goseun mani deowojijin antjiman, yeoreumeun hangsang seubhaeyo.
examples.en: It doesn't get very hot there, but it is always humid in summer.

examples.kr: 나는 그녀를 좋아하진 않아도 그녀의 사고 방식을 존경해요.
examples.romaji: Naneun geunyeoreul johahajin anado geunyeoui sago bangsigeul jongyeonghaeyo.
examples.en: I don't particularly like her, but I respect her way of thinking.

examples.kr: 요즘 너무 바빠서 체육관에 자주 가진 않아도, 집에서 운동은 해요.
examples.romaji: Yojeum neomu bappaseo cheyukgane jaju gajin anado, jibeseo undongeun haeyo.
examples.en: I am too busy these days to go to the gym regularly, but I do exercise at home.

examples.kr: 이 식당은 레스토랑으로 꼭 기억되진 않지만, 음식은 맛있어요.
examples.romaji: I sikdangeun reseutorangeuro ggok gieokdoejin antjiman, eumsigeun masisseoyo.
examples.en: This restaurant may not be particularly memorable, but the food is delicious.

title: ~처럼 [cheoreom] (Like, as if)
short_explanation: Used to express similarities or comparisons to something; 'like', 'as if'.
long_explanation: '~처럼 [cheoreom]' is a postposition used in Korean to indicate that something is similar to or acts in the same manner as the mentioned subject or object. It conveys a sense of comparison or simile, akin to 'like' or 'as if' in English. It is used to make comparisons between two things or to describe that someone or something acts or is in a condition that is similar to another.

examples.kr: 그녀는 나비처럼 춤을 춰요, 그녀의 리듬감과 움직임은 정말 아름다워요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun nabicheoreom chumeul chwoyo, geunyeoui rideumgamgwa umjigimeun jeongmal areumdawoyo.
examples.en: She dances like a butterfly, her sense of rhythm and movements are really beautiful.

examples.kr: 아버지는 항상 든든한 나무처럼 가족을 지켜줘요.
examples.romaji: Abeojineun hangsang deundeunhan namucheoreom gajogeul jikyeojwoyo.
examples.en: My father always protects the family like a sturdy tree.

examples.kr: 그는 배가 고파서 사자처럼 고기를 먹었어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun baega gopaseo sajacheoreom gogireul meogeosseoyo.
examples.en: He was so hungry, he ate the meat like a lion.

examples.kr: 진실을 들킨 그가 마치 쥐를 잡은 고양이처럼 미소를 지었어.
examples.romaji: Jinsireul deulkin geuga machi jwireul jabeun goyangicheoreom misoreul jieosseo.
examples.en: Having found out the truth, he smiled like a cat that got the mouse.

title: ~쳐서 [chyeoseo] (So)
short_explanation: Used to connect two clauses and show that the second clause is the result of the first; 'so', 'therefore'.
long_explanation: The suffix '~쳐서 [chyeoseo]' is used in Korean language to express cause and effect. It is used to connect two clauses in a sentence where the second clause is the result or effect of what is described in the first clause. This postfix can often be translated into 'so' or 'therefore' in English, conveying a sense of consequence or reason.

examples.kr: 저는 배가 너무 고파서 밥을 두 그릇이나 먹었어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun baega neomu gopaseo babeul du geureusina meogeosseoyo.
examples.en: I was so hungry that I ate two bowls of rice.

examples.kr: 친구가 너무 늦게 와서 영화가 이미 시작했어요.
examples.romaji: Chinguga neomu neutge wasseo yeonghwaga imi sijakhaesseoyo.
examples.en: Because my friend came too late, the movie had already started.

examples.kr: 수업이 너무 어려워서 공부를 많이 했어요.
examples.romaji: Sueobi neomu eoryeowoseo gongbureul mani haesseoyo.
examples.en: The class was so difficult that I studied a lot.

examples.kr: 날씨가 너무 추워서 집에만 있었어요.
examples.romaji: Nalssiga neomu chuweoseo jibeoman isseosseoyo.
examples.en: The weather was so cold that I just stayed at home.

title: ~카이다 [kaida] (Seems like)
short_explanation: Expresses the speaker's guess or inference about a situation based on a certain basis or evidence.
long_explanation: '~카이다 [kaida]' is a suffix used in Korean to infer and express a speaker's guess about a situation. The speaker should have certain evidence or grounds on which they are making the inference, even if the situation may not be directly observable. This grammar point is somewhat similar to 'seems like' or 'appears like' in English. It's used to describe someone’s indirect and uncertain comments about a specific action or state.

examples.kr: 나는 오늘 아침부터 배가 아프다. 아마 매운 음식을 먹어서 아픈 것 카이다.
examples.romaji: Naneun oneul achimbuteo baega apeuda. Ama maeun eumsigeul meogeoseo apeun geot kaida.
examples.en: I've had a stomachache since this morning. It seems like it's because I ate spicy food.

examples.kr: 그녀가 갑자기 분위기가 달라진 것 카이다. 무슨 일이 있었는지 아는 사람이 없다.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoga gapjagi bunwigiga dallajin geot kaida. Museun iri isseossneunji aneun sarami eopda.
examples.en: She seems to have suddenly changed her mood. No one knows what happened.

examples.kr: 어제 비가 왔는데 오늘은 반짝반짝한 것 카이다.
examples.romaji: Eoje biga watneunde oneureun banjjak banjjakhan geot kaida.
examples.en: It rained yesterday, but today, it seems to be sparkling.

examples.kr: 밖에 사람들이 없는 것 카이다. 모두 어디로 갔는지 모르겠다.
examples.romaji: Bagge saramdeuli eomneun geot kaida. Modu eodiro gassneunji moreugessda.
examples.en: It seems like there's no one outside. I don't know where everyone has gone.

title: ~커녕 [keonyeong] (Let alone, far from)
short_explanation: Used to express an idea contrary to expectation; 'let alone', 'far from'.
long_explanation: '~커녕 [keonyeong]' is a connector used in Korean to indicate that a certain expectation is not only not met, but the reality is far from, or contrary to, that expectation. It is often translated to 'let alone' or 'far from' in English. This grammar pattern is used in situations where one thing is not done, let alone something else that is even more unlikely or difficult.

examples.kr: 지영이는 한국어를 통해 간단한 대화를 나누는 것 커녕, '안녕하세요' 정도밖에 하지 못 해요.
examples.romaji: Jiyeongineun hangugeo reul tonghae gandanhan daehwareul nanuneun geot keonyeong, 'annyeonghaseyo' jeongdo bakke haji mot haeyo.
examples.en: Far from having a simple conversation in Korean, Jiyoung can barely say 'hello'.

examples.kr: 나는 주말에 책을 읽을 시간이 있다 커녕, 집안일에 치여서 어려워요.
examples.romaji: Naneun jumare chaekeul ilgeul sigani itda keonyeong, jibanire chiyeoseo eoryeowoyo.
examples.en: Far from having time to read a book on the weekend, I'm overwhelmed by housework.

examples.kr: 성진이는 시험 공부를 마치고 잔다 커녕, 게임을 하다가 밤새우기도 해요.
examples.romaji: Seongjineun siheom gongbureul machigo janda keonyeong, geimeul hadaga bamsaeugido haeyo.
examples.en: Far from going to sleep after studying for the exam, Seongjin often stays up all night playing games.

examples.kr: 그녀는 살을 빼려는 것 커녕, 매일 밤마다 간식을 먹어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun sareul bbaeryeoneun geot keonyeong, maeil bam mada gansigeul meogeoyo.
examples.en: Far from trying to lose weight, she eats snacks every night.

title: ~케 되다 [ke dweda] (Become)
short_explanation: Meaning 'to become' or 'end up', it is used to express the result of a change or transformation.
long_explanation: '~케 되다 [ke dweda]' is a Korean verb construction that's used to reflect the end result of a change or transformation, typically elicited by some factor or reason. The change could differ, from things about personal disposition, situations, or physical alteration. It’s quite comparative to saying 'to become', 'to get', 'to turn out to be' or 'end up' in English. The involved noun indicates the resultant state of change.

examples.kr: 어제 친구들과 멀리서 축구를 했는데, 너무 피곤하게 되어서 지금은 잠만 잘 수 있겠어요.
examples.romaji: Eoje chingudeulgwa meolliseo chuggureul haenneunde, neomu pigonhage dweeoseo jigeumeun jamman jal su issgeossseubnida.
examples.en: I played football from far away with my friends yesterday and I became so tired that now I think I can only sleep.

examples.kr: 그는 열심히 공부해서 성공적으로 비즈니스맨이 되었습니다.
examples.romaji: Geuneun yeolsimhi gongbuhago seonggongjeogne ro bijeuniseumani dweossseubnida.
examples.en: He studied hard and successfully became a businessman.

examples.kr: 그 책을 읽고 나서 고뇌하게 되었어요. 그것은 너무 어려웠습니다.
examples.romaji: Geu chaegeul ikgo naseo gonoihage dweeosseoyo. Geugeoseun neomu eoryeosseumnida.
examples.en: After reading that book, I became troubled. It was too difficult.

examples.kr: 긴 시간 동안 춥게 있었기에 우리가 건강에 나쁜 컨디션에 있게 되었어요.
examples.romaji: Gin sigan dongan chubge isseossgi-e usiga gi un gaenga-e nappeun keondisyeone issge dweeosseoyo.
examples.en: We became in a bad health condition because we were too long in the cold.

title: ~케 하다 [ke hada] (Make)
short_explanation: Used to express 'making or causing someone or something to be in a certain state'.
long_explanation: '~케 하다' is a grammar point in Korean that is used to mean 'make or cause something or someone to be in a certain state'. It is usually used with a descriptive verb stem and conjugates with '하다' to express causality. It's similar to 'make' or 'cause to be' in English.

examples.kr: 그녀는 저를 행복하게 해서 저는 그녀 때문에 항상 웃을 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun jeoreul haengbokhage haeseo jeoneun geunyeo ttaemune hangsang useul su isseoyo.
examples.en: She makes me happy, so I can always smile because of her.

examples.kr: 이 감자 스프를 맛있게 하려면, 감자를 잘 삶아서, 크림과 잘 섞어야 해.
examples.romaji: I gamja seupeureul masitke haryeomyeon, gamjareul jal tamhaeseo, keurimgwa jal seokkeoya hae.
examples.en: To make this potato soup delicious, you have to boil the potatoes well and mix them well with cream.

examples.kr: 엄마가 저를 준비하게 했기 때문에, 시험에 통과할 수 있었어요.
examples.romaji: Eommaga jeoreul junbi hage haetgi ttaemune, siheome tonggwahal su isseosseoyo.
examples.en: Because my mom made me prepare, I was able to pass the exam.

examples.kr: 교수님이 저를 집중하게 했기 때문에, 저는 모든 정보를 기억할 수 있었습니다.
examples.romaji: Gyosunimi jeoreul jipjunghage haetgi ttaemune, jeoneun modeun jeongboreul gieokhal su isseotsseumnida.
examples.en: Because the professor made me focus, I was able to remember all the information.

title: ~케하다 [kehada] (To make so that)
short_explanation: Used to indicate the action of making or letting someone or something be in a certain way.
long_explanation: '~케하다 [kehada]' is a grammar pattern used to express the action of making or letting someone or something happen or be in a certain way. It essentially means 'to make' or 'to let'. This pattern is often used when one actively influences or causes a certain state or action from someone else or another thing. The noun or verb before ~케하다 determines the particular state or action being caused or influenced.

examples.kr: 여자친구가 커피를 좋아하니까, 매일 아침 커피를 마시게 했어요.
examples.romaji: Yeojachinguga keopireul joahnikka, maeil achim keopireul masike haesseoyo.
examples.en: Because my girlfriend likes coffee, I made her drink coffee every morning.

examples.kr: 부모님이 학벌이 중요하다고 생각해서, 아이들을 혼자 공부하게 만들었어요.
examples.romaji: Bumonim-i hakbeol-i jung-yohadago saenggakhaeseo, aideul-eul honja gongbuhage mandeuleosseoyo.
examples.en: Because the parents think that education is important, they made their children study alone.

examples.kr: 친구가 해외여행을 하고 싶어서, 저는 그를 도와 비행기표를 예약하게 했습니다.
examples.romaji: Chingu-ga haeoeyeohaeng-eul hago sip-eoseo, jeoneun geul-eul dowahwa bihaenggitpyo-leul yeyaghage haessseubnida.
examples.en: Because my friend wanted to travel abroad, I helped him and made him reserve an airline ticket.

examples.kr: 제 체중이 증가해서, 이제부터 매일 운동을 하게 됐어요.
examples.romaji: Je chejung-i jeung-gahaseo, ijebuteo maeil undong-eul hage dwaesseoyo.
examples.en: Because my weight increased, from now on, I'm made to exercise every day.

title: ~키가 크다/작다 [kiga keuda/jakda] (To be tall/short)
short_explanation: Expressions used to describe height of an individual, literally translating to 'big in size' and 'small in size'.
long_explanation: '키가 크다 [kiga keuda]' and '키가 작다 [kiga jakda]' are simple phrases used in the Korean language to denote the height of a person. '키가 크다 [kiga keuda]' translates to 'big in size', often used to refer to someone tall. On the other hand, '키가 작다 [kiga jakda]' gets translated as 'small in size', used to indicate someone who is short. They directly refer to physical characteristics, specifically height in this context.

examples.kr: 우리 학교에서 제일 키가 큰 사람은 우리 반의 철수야.
examples.romaji: Uri hakgyoeseo jeil kiga keun saramun uri banui cheolsuya.
examples.en: The tallest person in our school is Cheolsu from our class.

examples.kr: 그녀는 키가 크기로 유명해요, 모델처럼 보여요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun kiga keugiro yumyeonghaeyo, modelcheoreom boyeoyo.
examples.en: She is famous for being tall, she looks like a model.

examples.kr: 나는 키가 작아서 아직도 어린이 좌석을 이용할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun kiga jakaseo ajikdo eorini jwaseogeul iyonghal su isseoyo.
examples.en: I am short, so I can still use the children's seat.

examples.kr: 그는 키가 작아도 그의 인간성은 큰 것 같아요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun kiga jakado geuui inganseongeun keun geot gatayo.
examples.en: Even though he is short, his humanity seems to be big.

title: ~키로 [kiro] (By means of, with)
short_explanation: Used to express the method, means, or instrumentality by which an action is performed.
long_explanation: '~키로 [kiro]' is a Korean grammar point that illustrates the tool, means, or through a certain method by which an action is carried out or achieved. It provides the additional information about how an action is conducted. This grammatical construct is similar to the English phrases 'by means of' or 'with'. Also, it can be used to show the tool, mechanism, or method that is predetermined or planned for action.

examples.kr: 저는 매일 아침 한 변 피아노를 치기로 해서 음악 실력을 향상시킵니다.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun maeil achim han beon pianoreul chikiro haeseo eumak silryeogeul hyangsangsikipnida.
examples.en: I play the piano once every morning as a mean to improve my musical skills.

examples.kr: 우리는 이 사건을 해결하기 위해 대화하기로 결정했습니다.
examples.romaji: Urineun i sageoneul haegyeolgihwi daehwagikiro gyeoljeonghaetsseumnida.
examples.en: We decided to resolve this issue by means of conversation.

examples.kr: 그녀는 매주 월요일 글을 쓰기로 시작해서 글쓰기 실력을 키웠습니다.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun maeju woryoil geuleul sseugikiro sijakhaeseo geulsseugi silryeogeul kiwotsseumnida.
examples.en: She began to write every Monday, thereby improving her writing skills.

examples.kr: 난 작년부터 매일 운동하기로 했고, 건강이 크게 개선되었습니다.
examples.romaji: Nan jaknyeonbuteo maeil undonghagikiro haetgo, geongangi keuge gaeseondwoetsseumnida.
examples.en: I decided to exercise daily from last year and my health has greatly improved.

title: ~타다 [tada] (To take, ride)
short_explanation: Used to express the action of taking or riding a form of transportation.
long_explanation: '~타다 [tada]' is a verb suffix in Korean that denotes the action of taking or riding a form of transportation such as a bus, a train, a taxi, a bicycle and so on. It is often used with the noun that indicates the mode of transportation. It can also be used to express the action of riding or using mechanical or electronic devices.
formation: Noun indicating transport or mechanical device + ~타다

examples.kr: 저는 일주일에 비행기를 두 번 타다보니까 비행기에 익숙해진 것 같아요. 아무래도 직장이 이렇게 멀긴 해서 비행기를 종종 타야 합니다.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun iljuile bihaenggireul du beon tadabonikkaji bihaenggie igsukhajin geot gatayo. Amuraedo jikjangi ireohge meolgin haeseo bihaenggireul jongjong taya hamnida.
examples.en: As I take the airplane twice a week, I think I have become familiar with airplanes. Because my job is so far away, I often have to take planes.

examples.kr: 아무래도 자전거를 타다보면 체력도 좋아지고, 건강에도 좋으니까 자전거를 자주 타보세요. 그리고 자전거를 타는 것이 운동으로도 좋습니다.
examples.romaji: Amuraedo jajeongeoreul tadabomyeon cheryeokdo joajigo, geongaedo joheunikka jajeongeoreul jaju taboseyo. Geurigo jajeongeoreul taneun geosi undongeurodo joheumnida.
examples.en: As you ride a bicycle, your stamina will improve, and it's good for your health, so try to ride a bicycle often. Also, riding a bicycle is excellent exercise.

examples.kr: 택시를 이렇게 자주 타다 보면 돈이 많이 드는 것 같아요. 그러니까 가능하면 지하철을 타거나 도보로 가시는 것이 좋을 것 같습니다.
examples.romaji: Taeksireul ireohge jaju tadabomyeon doni manhi deuneun geot gatayo. Geureonikka ganeunghamyeon jihacheoreul tageona doboreo gasineun geosi joheul geot gatseumnida.
examples.en: If you take a taxi this often, it seems like it costs a lot of money. So if possible, I think it would be better to take the subway or walk.

examples.kr: 이렇게 늦은 밤에 버스에 혼자 타다 보면 아무래도 좀 불안하겠죠? 그러니 이런 늦은 시간에는 가능하면 택시를 타는 것이 더 좋아요.
examples.romaji: Ireohge neutun bame beoseue honja tadabomyeon amuraedo jom buranhagessjyo? Geureoni ireon neutun sigueneun ganeunghamyeon taeksireul taneun geosi deo joayo.
examples.en: It probably feels a bit uneasy to be alone on a bus this late at night, doesn't it? So at this late hour, if possible, it's better to take a taxi.

title: ~테니까 [tenikka] (Because)
short_explanation: This is used to explain the reason or cause of an action or a state.
long_explanation: The grammar form ~테니까 [tenikka] is used to express 'because' in Korean. It is a complex form used to clarify the reason for a certain situation, behavior or outcome. There is usually no new information in the clause before ~테니까; the new or important information is in the clause after it. The ~테니까 pattern emphasizes the connection between cause and effect more than simple ~서 pattern.

examples.kr: 밖이 추우니까 옷을 더 입고 가세요.
examples.romaji: Bakk-i chuuni-kka ot-eul deo ib-go ga-se-yo.
examples.en: Because it's cold outside, wear more clothes.

examples.kr: 너무 늦게 잤으니까 아침에 일어나기 힘들었어요.
examples.romaji: Neomu neutge jass-euni-kka achim-e il-eona-gi himdeul-eoss-eo-yo.
examples.en: Because I slept too late, it was hard to get up in the morning.

examples.kr: 서울에서 살고 있으니까 가끔 한강에 산책하러 가요.
examples.romaji: Seoul-eseo salgo iss-euni-kka gakkeum Hangang-e sanchaekhaleo ga-yo.
examples.en: Because I live in Seoul, I occasionally go for walks by the Han River.

examples.kr: 한국어 공부가 즐거우니까 매일 열심히 공부하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Hangugeo gongbu-ga jeulgeou-ni-kka maeil yeolsimhi gongbuha-go iss-eo-yo.
examples.en: Because studying Korean is enjoyable, I study hard every day.

title: ~토록 [torok] (So that, to the extent that)
short_explanation: Used to express 'to the extent that' or 'so that'.
long_explanation: '~토록 [torok]' is a postposition used in the Korean language to express a certain condition or degree that prompts another condition or action. It is synonymous with 'so that' or 'to the extent that' in English. This is especially used to indicate a high degree of something or to express cause and effect correlation between situations.
formation: Verb/Adjective + 토록 + Sentence or Verb ~ 토록

examples.kr: 그는 노력하다 못해 자신의 건강까지 희생하려 했을정도로 프로젝트를 성공시키고 싶었어요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun noryeoghada mothae jasinui geongangkkaji huijeungharyeohaesseuljeongdoro peurojegteureul seonggongsikigo sipieosseoyo.
examples.en: He worked so hard to the extent he was willing to sacrifice his health just to make the project succeed.

examples.kr: 그녀는 회사에 늦지 않기 위해 일찍 일어나기로 결정했을정도로 회사에 애정이 많아요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun hoesaeneun nietji anhgi wihae iljjik iryeonagiro gyeoljeonghaesseul jeongdoroho hoesae aejeongi manoayo.
examples.en: She loves her company so much to the extent she decided to wake up early not to be late.

examples.kr: 여기서 살 자리가 줄어들었을정도로 인구증가가 심각하게 상승했어요.
examples.romaji: Yeogiseo sal jariga jur-eodeul-eoss-euljeongdolo ingujung-gaga simgag-age sangseunghaess-eoyo.
examples.en: The population has increased so dramatically to the extent that the living space here has been reduced.

examples.kr: 가난이 심해져서 밥 한 그릇도 어렵게 먹을 수 있었을정도로 어려웠어요.
examples.romaji: Ganani simhaejyeoseo bab han geuleutdo eolyeobge meog-eul su iss-eoss-euljeongdolo eolyeowoss-eoyo.
examples.en: Poverty was so severe to the extent that we struggled even to eat a bowl of rice.

title: ~하게 되다 [hage dweda] (End up doing)
short_explanation: Used to express that something ends up happening due to certain situation or circumstance, often beyond one's control.
long_explanation: '~하게 되다 [hage dweda]' is a verb ending used in Korean to indicate that something ends up happening as a result of a situation or circumstance, often implying that it was not the original intention or out of one’s control. It is frequently used to express an unexpected or unintentional result or event. This verb ending usually implies a feeling of surprise or uncertainty.

examples.kr: 그렇게 많은 숙제가 쌓여서 나는 결국 주말 내내 숙제를 하게 되었어.
examples.romaji: Geureohge manheun sukmjaega ssahyeoseo naneun gyeolguk jumal naenae sukmjaereul hage doeeoss-eo.
examples.en: So much homework piled up, and I ended up doing homework all weekend.

examples.kr: 보통은 말하지 않겠지만, 어제는 상황이 그래서 너에게 모든 걸 말하게 되었어.
examples.romaji: Botong-eun malhaji anhgetjiman, eoje-neun sanghwang-i geuraeseo neo-ege modeun geol malhage doeeoss-eo.
examples.en: Normally I wouldn't say it, but the situation was such that yesterday I ended up telling you everything.

examples.kr: 처음에는 운동하기 싫었지만, 친구가 자꾸 권해서 헬스클럽 회원이 되게 되었어.
examples.romaji: Cheoeum-eneun undonghagi silh-eossjiman, chinguga jakku gwonhaeseo hellseukeulleob hwe-won-i doegae doeeoss-eo.
examples.en: At first, I didn't want to exercise, but my friend kept encouraging me, so I ended up becoming a health club member.

examples.kr: 시험을 공부하려고 했는데, 재미있는 드라마를 보게 되었어.
examples.romaji: Siheom-eul gongbuharyeogo haessneunde, jaemiissneun deurama-reul boga doeeoss-eo.
examples.en: I was going to study for the exam, but I ended up watching an interesting drama.

title: ~하고 있다 [hago itda] (Is doing)
short_explanation: Used to describe a continuous or ongoing action.
long_explanation: '~하고 있다' is a grammar pattern used in Korean to express an ongoing action or a state that continues to exist. It is equivalent to the English 'is doing' or 'am/are doing'. It is formed by combining the verb stem with '하고 있다'. One thing to note is that this form focuses on the progression of the action, not on the result or completion of the action.

examples.kr: 요즘 한국어를 배우고 있어요, 그래서 아직 완벽하게 말할 수는 없어요.
examples.romaji: Yojeum hangugeoreul baeugo isseoyo, geuraeseo ajik wanbyeokhage malhal suneun eopseoyo.
examples.en: I am learning Korean these days, so I cannot speak it perfectly yet.

examples.kr: 지금 점심을 먹고 있어요, 바쁜 하루 중에 잠시 쉬는 시간이에요.
examples.romaji: Jigeum jeomsimeul meokgo isseoyo, bappun haru junge jamsi swineun siganieyo.
examples.en: I am eating lunch now, it's a short break during a busy day.

examples.kr: 어머니는 저녁 요리를 준비하고 있어요, 맛있는 음식을 기대하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Eomeonineun jeonyeok yorireul junbihago isseoyo, masissneun eumsigeul gidaehago isseoyo.
examples.en: My mother is preparing dinner, I'm looking forward to delicious food.

examples.kr: 우리 강아지는 밖에서 산책하고 있어요, 이렇게 해서 운동을 통해 건강을 유지하죠.
examples.romaji: Uri gangajineun bakkeso sancaekhago isseoyo, ireohge haeseo undongeul tonghae geongangeul yujijyo.
examples.en: Our puppy is taking a walk outside, it maintains its health through such exercises.

title: ~하고 나서 [hago naseo] (After doing)
short_explanation: Used to express sequence of actions; 'after doing'.
long_explanation: '~하고 나서 [hago naseo]' is a sentence pattern in Korean that means 'after doing something'. It is used to express that one action is done first before the another action is taken. The sequence of actions is crucial in the sentence with this grammar point and the latter action only happens after the completion of the first action.

examples.kr: 공부하고 나서 놀러 갈 거예요, 그래서 시간을 잘 관리해야 해요.
examples.romaji: Gongbuhago naseo nolreo gal geoyeyo, geuraeseo siganeul jal gwanrihaeya haeyo.
examples.en: I will go out and play after studying, so I have to manage my time well.

examples.kr: 아침 식사를 하고 나서 운동을 합니다, 그렇게 하면 하루를 활기차게 시작할 수 있어요.
examples.romaji: Achim sikshareul hago naseo undongeul hamnida, geureohge hamyeon harureul hwalgichage sijakhal su isseoyo.
examples.en: I exercise after having breakfast, by doing so, I can start the day energetically.

examples.kr: 숙제를 다 하고 나서 친구들과 영화를 봤어요, 그래서 즐거운 시간을 보냈습니다.
examples.romaji: Sukjereul da hago naseo chingudeulgwa yeonghwaleul bwasseoyo, geuraeseo jeulgeoun siganeul bonaessseubnida.
examples.en: I watched a movie with friends after finishing all my homework, so we had a good time.

examples.kr: 회의를 마치고 나서 점심을 먹었어요, 그런데 배가 너무 고파서 힘들었어요.
examples.romaji: Hoeireul machigo naseo jeomsimeul meogeosseoyo, geureonde baega neomu gopaseo himdeureosseoyo.
examples.en: I had lunch after finishing the meeting, but it was hard because I was so hungry.

title: ~하고 싶다 [hago sipda] (Want to do)
short_explanation: Expresses a desire to perform a certain action.
long_explanation: '~하고 싶다 [hago sipda]' is a verb ending in Korean that indicates the speaker's desire or wish to perform a certain action. In English, it is equivalent to the form 'want to do something'. It is commonly used to express personal wishes or plans, making it a very important grammar point for daily life conversations.

examples.kr: 저는 한국어를 유창하게 말하고 싶어요, 그래서 매일 열심히 공부하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun hangug-eoreul yuchanghage malhago sip-eoyo, geulaeseo maeil yeolsimhi gongbuhago iss-eoyo.
examples.en: I want to speak Korean fluently, so I'm studying hard every day.

examples.kr: 내가 가장 좋아하는 가수의 콘서트에 가고 싶어요, 하지만 티켓을 구하기가 어려워요.
examples.romaji: Naega gajang joahaneun gasuui konseoteue gago sip-eoyo, hajiman tikeseul guhagiga eolyeowoyo.
examples.en: I want to go to my favourite singer's concert, but it's hard to get tickets.

examples.kr: 나는 운동을 많이 하고 싶지만, 너무 바빠서 시간이 없어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun undong-eul mani hago sipjiman, neomu bappaseo sigan-i eobs-eoyo.
examples.en: I want to exercise a lot, but I'm too busy and don't have time.

examples.kr: 요리를 배우고 싶어요, 그래서 요리 수업에 등록을 생각하고 있어요.
examples.romaji: Yori reul baeugo sip-eoyo, geuraeseo yori sueobe deungrogeul saenggaghago iss-eoyo
examples.en: I want to learn cooking, so I am thinking of registering for a cooking class.

title: ~하기로 하다 [hakiro hada] (Decide to do)
short_explanation: Used to indicate that a decision about doing something has been made.
long_explanation: '하기로 하다' [hakiro hada] is used when you want to express that a decision to do something has been made. It can be about a personal decision or it could be a mutual decision made by a group of people. It translates to 'decide to do' in English. The action that is decided upon is indicated by the verb it is attached to.

examples.kr: 우리는 휴가를 가기로 결정했습니다. 주말에 휴식을 취하러 해변에 가기로 했어요.
examples.romaji: Urineun hyugareul gagiro gyeoljeonghaessseubnida. Jumalen hyusigeul chwihareo haebyeone gagiro haess-eoyo.
examples.en: We decided to go on vacation. We've decided to go to the beach for a rest on the weekend.

examples.kr: 나는 영화를 보기로 결정했어. 오늘 밤에 집에서 미드를 보기로 했어.
examples.romaji: Naneun yeonghwareul bogiro gyeoljeonghaesseo. Oneul bam-e jib-eseo mideureul bogilo haess-eo..
examples.en: I decided to watch a movie. I decided to watch a drama at home tonight.

examples.kr: 그녀는 한국어를 배우기로 결정했습니다. 그녀는 올해 한국어 수업을 듣기로 했습니다.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun hangugeoreul baeugiro gyeoljeonghaessseubnida. Geunyeoneun olhae hangugeo sueobeul deutgiro haessseubnida.
examples.en: She decided to learn Korean. She decided to take Korean lessons this year.

examples.kr: 회사는 직원들에게 보너스를 주기로 결정했다. 고용주들은 내년에 직원들에게 연봉 인상을 주기로 결정했다.
examples.romaji: Hoesaneun jikweondeul-ege bonuseu-leul jugiro gyeoljeonghaessda. Goyongjudeul-eun naenyeon-e jikwon-deul-ege yeonbong insang-eul jugiro gyeoljeonghaessda.
examples.en: The company decided to give the employees a bonus. Employers decided to give employees a raise next year.

title: ~하기는 하다 [hakineun hada] (Do to some extent)
short_explanation: Used to admit that something is done to some degree, but not fully or enthusiastically.
long_explanation: ~하기는 하다 [hakineun hada] is a Korean grammar point that is used when someone does do something, but not completely, regularly, or with excitement. This grammar form shows an extent of participation or happening, but implies some sort of limit or lacking. It's a way of acknowledging that something happens or is done but suggesting that it is done in a less than ideal, satisfactory, or usual manner.

examples.kr: 나는 요리하기는 하는데 맛있게 하는 건 아니예요.
examples.romaji: Naneun yorihagineun haneunde masitge haneun geon aniyeyo.
examples.en: I do cook, but it's not that I cook deliciously.

examples.kr: 그는 운전하기는 하는데 안전하게는 운전하지 않아요.
examples.romaji: Geuneun unjeonhagineun haneunde anjeonhagejeun unjeonhaji anhayo.
examples.en: He does drive, but he does not drive safely.

examples.kr: 어머니는 영어를 이해하기는 하지만 말하기는 좀 힘들어하세요.
examples.romaji: Eomeonineun yeongeoreul ihaehagineun hajiman malhagineun jom himdeureohaseyo.
examples.en: My mother does understand English, but she finds speaking it somewhat difficult.

examples.kr: 나는 운동하기는 하는데 정기적으로 하지는 않아요.
examples.romaji: Naneun undonghagineun haneunde jeongigjeogeuro hajineun anhayo.
examples.en: I do exercise, but I don't do it regularly.

title: ~하기보다 [hakiboda] (Rather than doing)
short_explanation: Used to express preference or a better option; 'rather than'.
long_explanation: '~하기보다 [hakiboda]' is a grammar point used in Korean to indicate a preference over something or to suggest that a particular option is better than another. It is equivalent to 'rather than' in English. This phrase is used to compare two alternatives and to express the speaker's preference or the better of the two.

examples.kr: 강아지를 사 주는 것보다 입양하는 것을 추천드려요.
examples.romaji: Gangajireul sa juneun geosboda ibyanghaneun geoseul chucheon deuryeoyo.
examples.en: I recommend adopting a puppy rather than buying one.

examples.kr: 택시를 타기보다는 버스를 타는 게 더 싸요.
examples.romaji: Taeksireul tagibodaneun beoseureul taneun ge deo ssayo.
examples.en: It's cheaper to take the bus rather than a taxi.

examples.kr: 많이 먹기보다는 품질 좋은 음식을 먹는 것이 더 중요해요.
examples.romaji: Mani meokgibodaneun pumjil joheun eumsigeul meokneun geosi deo jungyohaeyo.
examples.en: It's more important to eat good quality food rather than eat a lot.

examples.kr: 친구에게 거짓말하기보다는 진실을 말하는 것이 낫다고 생각해요.
examples.romaji: Chinguege geojismalhagibodaneun jinsireul malhaneun geosi nasdagosaenggakhaeyo.
examples.en: I think it is better to tell the truth to a friend rather than lie.

title: ~하나 [hana] (But, however)
short_explanation: Used to express contrast or contradiction, similar to 'but' or 'however' in English.
long_explanation: '~하나 [hana]' is a conjunction often used in Korean to indicate a contrast or contradiction between two ideas or situations. It introduces a contrary point of view, or an exception to a previous statement. It can be likened to the English terms 'but' or 'however', and is thus used to present different, often opposing, points. It is commonly used in both formal and informal speech and writing, and is placed at the beginning of the sentence or clause it is intended to contrast.

examples.kr: 나는 그 일을 마친 줄 알았는데, 하나 사람들은 아직 끝내지 않았어요.
examples.romaji: Naneun geu ireul machin jul alatneunde, hana saramdeureun ajik kkeutnaeji anatseoyo.
examples.en: I thought I had finished the work, however, the people had not finished it yet.

examples.kr: 그녀는 예쁜 것 같아요. 하나, 성격이 너무 나빠요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeoneun yeppeun geot gatayo. Hana, seonggyeogi neomu nappayo.
examples.en: She seems pretty, but she has a very bad personality.

examples.kr: 이것은 어렵게 느껴질 수 있으나, 하나 연습하면 쉬워질 거예요.
examples.romaji: Igeoseun eoryeopge neukkyeojil su isseuna, hana yeonseubhamyeon swiweojil geoyeyo.
examples.en: This might feel difficult, however, it will become easier with practice.

examples.kr: 우리는 집에 돌아가야 하는데, 하나 차가 없어서 걸어야 했어요.
examples.romaji: Urineun jibe doragaya haneunde, hana chaga eopseoseo georeoya haesseoyo.
examples.en: We needed to go home, but we had no car so we had to walk.

title: ~하면 할수록 [hamyeon halsurok] (The more... the more)
short_explanation: Used to express a proportional increase or decrease; 'the more... the more'.
long_explanation: '~하면 할수록 [hamyeon halsurok]' is a grammar structure used in Korean to illustrate that the increase or decrease of one thing causes a proportional increase or decrease of another. This pattern implies that as one action or state progresses or increases, the other action or state does as well. It is similar to the English expression 'the more... the more'.

examples.kr: 저는 한국어를 공부하면 할수록 더 재미있어지는 것 같아요, 한국의 문화와 역사를 더 이해할 수 있게 되니까.
examples.romaji: Jeoneun hangugeoreul gongbuhamyeon halsurok deo jaemiisseojineun geot gatayo, hangukui munhwa wa yeoksareul deo ihaehal su itge doenikka.
examples.en: The more I study Korean, the more fun it becomes, as I understand more about Korean culture and history.

examples.kr: 이 집안에서 책을 읽으면 읽을수록 더 많은 지식을 얻을 수 있어서 저는 항상 책을 읽는 것을 즐깁니다.
examples.romaji: I jiban-eseo chaeg-eul ilgeumyeon ilgeulsurok deo manh-eun jisig-eul eod-eul su iss-eoseo jeoneun hangsang chaeg-eul ilgneun geos-eul jeulgibnida.
examples.en: The more I read books in this house, the more knowledge I gain which is why I always enjoy reading.

examples.kr: 요리를 하면 할수록 자신감이 더 생긴다, 그래서 나는 항상 새로운 레시피를 시도해본다.
examples.romaji: Yorireul hamyeon halsurok jasin-gam-i deo saeng-ginda, geulaeseo naneun hangsang saeloun lesipileul sidohae-bonda.
examples.en: The more I cook, the more confident I become, so I always try new recipes.

examples.kr: 그녀와 함께 시간을 보내면 볼수록 그녀를 더 사랑하게 되는 거 같아요, 그녀의 성격이 정말 매력적이니까요.
examples.romaji: Geunyeo-wa hamkke sigan-eul bonae-myeon bolsurok geunyeo-leul deo salang-hage doeneun geo gat-a-yo, geunyeoui seong-gyeog-i jeongmal maelyeogjeog-inikka-yo.
examples.en: The more time I spend with her, the more I fall in love with her, because her personality is really charming.
